Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have finished with you, my son, this book, which is the latest of my scientific works on medicine with the addition of this one, and has been completed in this way by the exposition of its contents and the declarations which are found in it, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this treatise which is a part of the art of surgery, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery with the hand is a new art in our time and at a remote period: until perhaps its science has perished and its trace has been erased: nothing remains of it except for slight descriptions in the ancient books, which have been altered by the hand: and thereby there has arisen error and hesitation, until its intentions have been closed and its scope extended: It seemed to me that I should bring together in this treatise, according to order, its positions and declarations, and its brevity: and that I should explain the forms of the instruments of cautery and other instruments of the art, together with their addition and preparation which is necessary
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	However, it is not possible to find a good artisan of this art with his hand in our time: because the art of medicine is long, and the author must exercise himself beforehand in the science of anatomy, as Galen has narrated, until he knows the movements of the limbs, their forms, and their connection, and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, nerves, and lacerations, and the number of these things, and their emergence, and the pulsation of veins, and quietness, and the exit of places.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for this reason Hippocrates said, that the name is much with the name, and little with the work, and especially in the art of the hand
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have indeed spoken of this at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For he who is ignorant of what we have said concerning anatomy will fall into error, and will thereby harm men. As for me, I have seen many who have learned of this science without study or experiment.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Since I have seen a stupid doctor attempt to remove a swelling from a woman's neck by cutting her arteries, and she died between his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another doctor who attempted to extract a stone from a patient's bladder, though the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He did this with the result that he extracted the stone along with the bladder itself
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	And the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I myself was called to extract it: and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would certainly die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I have seen another doctor who was paid by a certain Duke of our land for his medical skill: and it happened to a black slave who was with him, that he fractured his leg near his heel: and the doctor, with his ignorance, bound the fracture with nails and strong stitching, and did not allow the wound to drain.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	And as a result the slave died according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then he dismissed him after a few days, and commanded him not to move his ligament: and he remained like that until the swelling of his leg had gone down, and his foot and leg, and as a result he died.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called to him again: and I found him perfectly calm and free from pain
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	And indeed corruption was confirmed in the limb: and I could not restrain it
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	When the limb has ceased to suffer corruption, it is no longer liable to further damage.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	When the limb has ceased to suffer corruption, it is no longer liable to further damage.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	When the limb has ceased to suffer corruption, it is no longer liable to further damage. That is, because when the cancer is pure and black, it does not require any further support, except in the limb which will tolerate it, so that the whole of it may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And thus, my son, you must know that an operation is divided into two parts: the one which is associated with health, and the one which carries the peril in various conditions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I am excited in every place in this book concerning the operation in which there is fear and terror
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore you must be cautious and discreet concerning this, and do not make any boasts or empty promises
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Receive with humility the measure with attention and protection, and the sick with kindness and firmness, and use the better way for healing thanks to God to obtain lasting glory and praise: and banish the grievous anxieties which make you fear, so that there may be no hindrance to your faith and comfort
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For in this world there remains only the glory of God, and the perfume in this life, and finally in the number of your souls.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galen indeed has said concerning some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not be afraid of the black bile: do not speak evil of the physician
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have indeed divided this treatise into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	First Chapter.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	First Chapter.
Capitulum secundum.	Second Chapter.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On section and perforation, phlebotomy and packing, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows and similar matters: and the whole chapter is arranged in the order of the instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Third Chapter.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, and dislocation, and treatment of twisting, and similar matters: the chapter is arranged from the head down to the feet, and the order of the instruments
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory be to God.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the application of the dressing, and the use of the cautery: and on what complexions it is suitable, and at what time: and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before we speak of any operation, it is necessary to mention the quality of the dressings and instruments: and in what complexions it should be used
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the discourse concerning the quality of the cautery dressing and its name is a prolonged, subtle, scientific, and secret discourse.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And many wise men have spoken on this matter, and they have differed among themselves: and indeed little is to be gained from their discourses, fearing the length of the discourse itself
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that the cautery is useful for all complexions, whether with material or without material: except for two complexions which are the hot complexion without material, and the dry complexion without material
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In the hot and dry complexions with material they disagree.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some indeed say that the cautery is harmful in these matters.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	Others have said otherwise, namely that Cauterium is not suitable for wounds caused by heat and dryness: for the nature of fire is heat. It is unsuitable to heal wounds caused by heat and dryness with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	Others have said the opposite, namely that Cauterium makes an ointment in all wounds caused by heat and dryness, which happen in the bodies of men: for when you compare the body of a man and moisten it, to the nature of fire, you find the body of a man chilled.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I myself have learned from experience that this is true
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	It is not enough to learn only from this sermon; one must also learn from experience the last exercise of the Cauterium course, and have recognized the diversity of the dispositions of men, and the causes and accidents of their wounds, and their speed
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Except in the cases of the most delicate complexions, there is no fear of them: and especially in the case of cold and moist wounds
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all the physicians agree on this: and they do not hesitate to use Cauterium on them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And behold, the sons of Alexander say that the secret of the treatment of wounds by Cauterium with fire, and the benefit of it over Cauterium with burning medicine is because fire is simple, whose action does not extend except to the part that is cauterized: and it does not harm any other connected limb except for a slight burn
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The medicines of burning have an action that extends beyond the part that is cauterized: and perhaps makes it difficult to heal the wound of the limb, and perhaps even causes death.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, on account of its subtlety and the excellence of its substance, does not cause this [pain], unless it be excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	I have learned from experience, on account of the length of my service and study with art, and the position over truth of things: and because of this I am excused from the length of the speech.</start_of_turn>
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And even if it is not permitted for this book of mine, I will declare a secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in the bodies of its expulsions, which expels ailments with a philosophical demonstration that agrees with the minds of the learned.</start_of_turn>
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know this, my sons, that they themselves dissent in the time when it is necessary to make a cautery, and they say that it is better to leave it alone.</start_of_turn>
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that a cautery is useful in all times: for in fact the document [of the ailment] is absorbed by the fat at the time of healing, which is attracted by the cautery.</start_of_turn
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if the cautery is for necessary and strong pains, fasts, which do not tolerate delay: for they fear the fire, which brings about greater harm than the slight damage done by the ailment itself.</start_of_turn
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	Do not let the minds of the learned or the sons think that because of this it is not useful, except for madmen and foolish doctors, for the ailment which is healed by a cautery is not always cured: they take this for consequence, and it is not so: for a cautery is not, except in the case of medicine, which alters the complexion and dries humors which are the causes of the ailments.</start_of_turn>
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Truly, a cautery surpasses medicine by its speed of action, the excellence of its operation, and the certainty of its mastery: and it is possible that the ailment will be cured at some later time according to the complexion of the patient, the location of the ailment, and the excellence of the treatment: and that which is prepared in his body from the collection of superfluous humors in it: and that which comes to him from the cause itself, except in the case of an ailment in which a cautery is administered.</start_of_turn>
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Acute pain in a limb with few supernumerary hairs and moisture, like the cautery of a tooth, because of pain, and similar to it, is possible that it will not return in that place because of the pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	However, this is in few cases.</start_of_turn>
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	Indeed, the saying is correct: the cautery of a tooth is the last remedy in medicine. It is the correct thing to say: because they believe that there is no cure that can be compared with medicine, neither with anything else after the cautery.</start_of_turn>
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	However, the thing is contrary to this, and the intention that the cautery is the last remedy in medicine is not true, except when we administer other modes of treatment for some ailment, and these do not yield: then we administer the cautery at the end, and it yields. It is thus that the cautery is the last remedy, not in accordance with the intention as the vulgar people and the multitude of doctors understand it.</start_of_turn>
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that the cautery with gold is better than the cautery with iron: and they did not say this except because of the equality of gold, and the fineness of its substance: and they said that it does not form pus at the place of the cautery.</start_of_turn
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	However, this is not absolutely true: for I have seen this to be the case, and I have found that it does not cause this in some bodies without other things.</start_of_turn>
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cautery with the substance itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you burn the cautery with gold in fire, you are not to declare that this is the case when you ignite it according to the quantity you desire, because of the redness of the gold: and when it approaches the substance itself and if you add more fire to it, it liquefies in the fire, and turns into leaves.</start_of_turn
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why does the artificer depart from that to engage in this occupation? And because of this, Cauterium with iron is used by us more quickly and closer to the operation, from its rectitude to the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	I have also set out this Chapter on Cauterium, following the chapters: and I have set them out from the head to the feet: so that they may satisfy anyone who desires something from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	Regarding the manner of cauterizing the head in the coronal commissure.
Caput II.	Chapter II
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here is the cauterization is performed with regard to the lord of humidity and frigidity over the brain: which are two causes of swelling, and of the multitude of flows of humors from the head downwards to the eyes and ears, and of the multitude of sleep, and pain of teeth, and pain of the throat: and generally all ailments which arise from frigidity, such as palsy, swelling, epilepsy, apoplexy, and the like of these ailments.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is as follows: immediately when the patient arrives with the disease, along with a physician who uses a soothing solution, the head should be bathed three or four nights, according to the nature of the disease, and the age of the patient, and his custom
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then command him to make a circle with his hand over his head with the nail.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands which are placed square, so that your hands rest on his chest
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever his middle finger points, that is the place where the cautery is to be applied with the flame
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then apply the Cauterium with Olive Oil: which is like this in shape
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it over the marked place with the cautery, descending slowly, so that your hand is gradually constrained, and you withdraw it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then draw your hand quickly and grasp the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that some part of the bone has been broken by the quantity of the head of the ulna, or by the quantity of the herb, then draw your hand again
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, draw your hand again with the iron itself, or with something else which is cold: until you see the bone which I told you of
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take something of salt and dissolve it in water, and soak in it the bottom, and put it over the place: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then put over it the soaked bottom in butter, and leave the bandage over the place until the eschar is consumed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents of four herbs, until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	I have said that the more the wound is open, the more pus it emits: which is better and more useful.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them say that the skin should be cauterized until the bone is reached: and keep the Cautery firm, until something of the thickness of an ossificated bone is burned
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then loosen that which has been burned from the bone, and then heal it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it is necessary that when the cautery is finished it should leave an imprint in the bone like a footprint, so that the bone will be broken: or an instrument which women put inside the small letter: and they say that from this place steam of the head arises, and the wound is opened for a long time
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it cares until it is consolidated.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	Then it cares until it is consolidated.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And discharge it; it is better for me that way with the health of the patient.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head weakens from the resolution of its natural continuity: as we have seen in other limbs: and especially when the head of the patient is weak by nature: the first kind of cauterism is the most safe and good for me, and that is what I shall use: for I work with it for the health of the patient.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	In this way it is cauterized for the whole pain of the head.
Caput III.	Head Chapter III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When in the whole head there occurs a chronic pain: and it persists in the patient, and there is heat, and swelling, and purulent discharge, and oil, and application of things like these
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized once with that which we have mentioned, and nothing more is added to it: then consider it
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the patient is strong in nature and not weak, and there is cold that comes upon it: then cauterize with another cautery under that little one
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over all the corners of the head with the cautery, so that it does not go through the skin, and uncover the quantity of bone from which we have spoken.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it once with the cautery in the nape of the neck in the place which is called the uas: and it is the place where the wind is placed: and raise your hand up in this, and do not uncover the bone
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	The patient is relieved because of that cold which comes upon it, and different from the pain of other cauteries of the head in general
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I say this concerning the Cauterium: it must be that the Cauterium be such that it may cauterize the horns of the head and the back of the head more finely, while it cauterizes the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	Regarding the method of cautery in hemicrania, both with medicinal poultices and with the iron.</start_of_turn>
Caput IIII.	Chapter III.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When in the part of the head there is pain and swelling, or if the pain extends up to the eye, and it is driven out with medicinal poultices, and other treatment is administered as I have said in the discourse on diseases, and it does not suffice: then cautery is done in two ways: either with acute burning medicine or with the iron.</start_of_turn
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But as for cautery with acute burning medicine, you take a piece of wood about the size of a barleycorn, and burn it until it is red hot, and then you touch the diseased area with the burnt end.</start_of_turn
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the area of pain at the same time as you perform phlebotomy on the side, until there is a bubble under the skin where the tooth is caught.</start_of_turn
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Insert it into the wound until it reaches the bone: then bind over it with a bandage of moderate constriction, and leave it in place for fifteen hours. Then remove the dressing and give the wound two or three days’ rest. Finally, apply a wet compress over the wound until the pain has gone away.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do it with some of the burning medicines which I have written about in the twelfth tractate on Burning Remedies.</start_of_turn
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Burning of the veins with iron is according to this method.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Burning with iron is performed in this manner
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	It is called Clavicle because its form is like that of a key, in which there is a slight curvature, and in the middle there is a small protrusion.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it upon the place and hold your hand: and slowly draw the iron away with the amount that has been scorched from the thickness of the skin, like half of it
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand so that the artery below does not burn and the blood flow does not increase
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak the area in salt water, and place it upon the place, and leave it for three days: then place the area with butter: afterwards care with unguent until it has healed
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if necessary, burn the haematoma with the second degree of the cautery iron.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	Burn from the incision of the artery in this haematoma, not directly over it.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	In the old way, cautery was performed by opening the haematoma.
Caput V.	Chapter V
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you have treated the haematoma, when the swelling has subsided from the treatment we mentioned before, and the cure has not taken hold: and if you notice swelling which the first or second cautery with medicine or with fire did not cure, then you must burn the cautery iron with a knife until the sign of pain disappears on the place, which is as long as half of a finger, or like that: and hold your hand firmly until you have pierced the artery, and keep it like that until you reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	It is necessary to check for any possible cause of jaw displacement, which may occur during mastication, to prevent its becoming flattened or its nerve being damaged, from which spasm arises.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	This action must be taken with great caution, and the haemorrhage of the artery must be arrested cautiously.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in its division there is fear, especially for him who is ignorant of what he is doing, and is not skilled or experienced: and he abandons the operation at once
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will remind you of the regimen of the flow of blood which is accidental to an artery according to its custom, and in its place is found in this book of mine
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If the fever from the illness does not suffice for this Cauterium, and the patient's body tolerates Cauterium in the middle of the head, as we have mentioned, take care of the wound, until it is healed
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	If you wish, apply Cauterium as we said in the chapter on the extraction of an artery with Cauterium which has two blades.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For Cauterization is better than excision and more effective
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	Concerning the method of Cauterization in the pain of the Ears.
Caput VI.	(The text continues on the next page.)
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When it happens in the Ear that there is pain from cold, and it is cured with poultices, and the rest of the treatment which we have mentioned previously, and the pain is not relieved, then apply Cauterium: and this is called the Punctum, which has this shape
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then make the Punctum after you have ignited it around the whole Ear, as it is rolled around: or around both, if there is pain in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And prolong thee with the Cauterio from the root of the ear towards the parumper, after you have marked the place with the encaustro: and let the quantity of the Cauterio be ten points in every aure, and so on.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	And then care for the place until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	In this way cauterize in the Tortura.</start_of_turn>
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.</start_of_turn
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	A burn which can be cured by cautery is not except from those which arise from phlegmas, as we mentioned in the discussions of the causes of diseases.</start_of_turn
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And you must cauterize the species which arise from exication and spasm of the nerve.</start_of_turn
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you have cured this species of torture with baths, and purging, and gargling, and the cure does not suffice, then it is necessary to cauterize the diseased three times with the Cauterio: once at the root of the ear, and the second a little lower from the ear, and the third at the junction of the two lips.</start_of_turn
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And put the Cauterio on the side opposite the diseased part.</start_of_turn
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For the softening does not take place except in the part which appears healthy.</start_of_turn
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cautery is that you cauterize the Cauterio itself at the root of the outer ear under the corner of the ear a little: and the other at the temple: the length of which is as long as the thumb.</start_of_turn
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And hold your hand with the Cauterio until the quantity of the middle third of the thickness of the skin is consumed.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the Cauterio, and it is like a knife whose form is shown above: indeed it is not finer than that of an awl: and it is necessary that the knife be of a suitable thickness.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed.
Caput VIII.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When the old apoplexy has passed, and you are treating it as we have said, and no medicine helps it, and the patient does not have a fever, then burn him with four burns over all the horns of his head, and burn in the middle of the head, as we have said, and burn in the nape of the neck, according to what preceded: and the manner of burning should be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed
Caput IX.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that in the first instance in the sick man a large dose of hyra, and mild pills for the brain be given.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If, however, you desire to make an addition, and the patient is able to tolerate it: then make for him a Cauterium in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you desire to make an addition: then cauterize it over two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then care for it until it is healed: and let the Cauterium be applied according to its form, as is prefixed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	As to the cauterization of Paralysis, and the softening of it.
Caput X.	Chapter X.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	You must proceed in the softening of the head with urine, and with that which we have mentioned.</start_of_turn>
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then touch the head of the patient: afterwards make a Cauterium in the middle of the head, and a Cauterium over every horn of the head, and a Cauterium over the back of it, and three over the spines of the neck.</start_of_turn>
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If, however, you find in the softening of the body of the many of these, and the patient is able to tolerate it, and the sickness is strong: then make for him four Cauteriums over the spines of the back, and the last one with a Cauterium, until it is burnt from the surface of most of it, and lift up your hand.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for it until it is healed: and thus apply the Cauterium.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	How to cauterize in Epilepsy.</start_of_turn
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.</start_of_turn
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic patient is not cauterized, except for him from whom the epilepsy is from phlegm.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	You must therefore soften his brain in the first place with urine, and with the rest of the cure which we have mentioned: when the patient is great, or is tolerant in accepting the medicines.</start_of_turn
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, a boy endures not medicines, then gargarisma is administered, and nourishing bites which temper the brain, many days before with advantage to the food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then the head is bandaged, afterwards it is cauterized with one cautery in the middle of the head, as it has been before in this manner: and with another cautery on the nape of the neck, and over all the corners of the head with a third cautery.</start_of_turn>
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient is strong and tolerates, then cauterize with cauteries which have been mentioned in those with paralysis, and softening of the body over the cervical vertebrae and the vertebrae of the back: and let the Cautery be of olive oil according to the manner which has been mentioned.</start_of_turn>
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If the patient is a boy, then apply a mild cautery according to this manner.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in melancholy.</start_of_turn
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize with the cauteries which we mentioned in those having paralysis.</start_of_turn
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is excess of moisture descending to melancholy, and the body of the patient is wet, then give him something to drink which will temper the brain, as has been mentioned previously: then bandage the head of the patient, and make immediately after a pendant tortellum which is made from linen, like a circle.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the patient sitting upright is to be held from all sides.</start_of_turn
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply liniment.</start_of_turn
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	It is more worthy from the old butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	Heat it over a moderate fire until it becomes warm to the touch, as much as the finger can bear when it is introduced into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it into the middle of its head in a circle, and keep it there until it has cooled down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this every week to the sick person along with the rest of his treatment, until he is healed
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small punctures on its surface, besides which you must keep the hand firm with the cautery: it will give off an odor.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then put on it a cover soaked in butter, or fat from a hen
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	In descending water concerning the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the water of the eye is declared by the signals I mentioned before, then begin to instill it and give the patient a drink, along with which it will temper the head of the patient.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep it away from all moistness, and let him sit in a bath for a few days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then order him to turn his head and cauterize it in the middle of his head
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it over two tempora with two cauteries, if there is an incipient recession of the water in both eyes simultaneously: or from one side only, if there is an incipient recession of the water in one eye only: and cut away with the cautery all the veins and arteries which are under the skin: and let there be cauteries in their length in the width of the temples: and burn from the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see that something has happened from this, then immediately cut it off with whatever medicine is available: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and the cutting off of them, and the precautions against the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when it is cauterized on the surface of bone under two ribs, two cauteries must be made at the end of it
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	In the ancient lacrimal glands, in this way cauterize.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIIIII.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient, they are sticky: and they are over the nails, and the arteries which are in the manifest head outside, it is verified that this is from the superfluousness of cold, phlegmatic: then cauterize with the same cautery which I mentioned in the beginning of the descent of water, the cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauteries over two temporal regions, and two cauteries on the surface under two ribs
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if the addition is not digested, then cauterize it in all the side of the eye cautiously over the eyebrow with a small cautery
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	In the manner of cauterizing the nose in the foetore.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating this, with what we have said in the discourse, and the medicine does not help: then cleanse, and give in the drink of the patient three nights: then shave its head, and cauterize it with the middle cautery, with olive oil cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with the claw cautery with two cauteries, over two superciliums under the hair a little bit
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard the artery, so that you do not cut it off.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	This is the shape of the Clauilis cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	And this is the form of the Clauilis cautery.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the Palpebra of the eye is softened by brittleness or moisture: then cauterize the Palpebra with one cautery, like a lunar cautery.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you will, cauterize the upper two eyelashes a little more than two cauteries at a time: and stretch them out for two times: and let the length of each cautery be according to the length of the eyelash: and do not bring your hand too close to the cautery, but according to the quantity which is to be cured of the third of the Palpebra.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of lunar cautery.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	Chapter XVI.</start_of_turn>
Caput XVII.	When the eyelashes are burned with a cautery, the tears fall out from the eye.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	There are two ways of cauterizing the eyelashes: with fire or with a burning medicine.</start_of_turn
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	But in the cautery with fire, command the patient to be beforehand that he expel his hair, if there are any which are moving, until they are prolonged and equal.</start_of_turn
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If however they are burned at the root: then hold his eyes closed with the thumb and the index finger, so that they do not move, until they are burnt.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are burnt and equal, then put the patient's head in your lap: then mark over the Palpebra of his eye with charcoal, a sign which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf: and let the beginning of the sign be near the eyelashes.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place the soaked cushion in albumin or: on the mucus of the hair above the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply the cautery, which is shaped like this
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then burn over the outline, which you will mark gradually in many veins, until the surface of the skin is burned, which is like the shape of a leaf of Myrtle, throughout
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the success of your work is: if you touch the eyelash of the eye with your hand, and pluck the hair at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Raise your hand then: and let it go in three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place above it the cushion with butter, until the pus is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguent until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If some hair remains after an hour, and you soften the eyelash: then burn the cautery once more in the same place as before
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If they are in the lower part: then burn the cautery there, until they are raised to their natural place: and make sure that the eyelashes do not burn the eyes
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	In the same way, burn with the cautery which is mixed with medicine.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	Just as with the principal diseases, that it sends away the hair, until it is prolonged and equalized
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from paper in the form of a leaf of Myrtle
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from the soap which has been boiled, and from the unsoaked heel of a garment a weight of about an ounce or almost as much: then mix these things together with good contrition, and make it with a fine motion, so that it does not become cold.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from the pan from which you took the charcoal and put it over the parchment which you have made like the form of a myrtle leaf, and put it on the eyelid of one eye, or two.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	Put under the eye a piece of cotton soaked in vinegar: and the head of the patient should be in your lap.</start_of_turn>
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	Put your finger on the doctor's chest and press it lightly.</start_of_turn>
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you should move it whenever the patient feels the biting of the medicine: for its biting is like fire.</start_of_turn>
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While you are doing this, you will have found out the biting of the medicine; then take away the medicine and move it with your finger.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the biting has subsided, then take away the medicine and wash the eye with water.</start_of_turn
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	Consider then, if the eyelid is swollen, whether it swells up with contraction like fire, or like an incision, is good: and if not, then repeat the medicine upon the place where the medicine does not touch, without injuring it, until your operation is complete and the eye is healed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then put upon it a piece of cotton with butter, until the skin of the swelling has disappeared.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with an ointment of diaphanicon, or something else, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you during the operation, to keep an eye on the last thing, that nothing of the medicine should fall into the eye.</start_of_turn
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	For if the eyelid becomes softened after a day, and something from the hair gets into the eye, then repeat the medicine upon the place where the eyelid softens of itself, as you did at the beginning.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	This is the form of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	You know that the eyes of men differ in size and shape
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore consider this: do not conceal the rightness of this art which is its study
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	Concerning the cauterization of the fistula of the tear duct
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you have treated the fistula and it does not yield to your care: then it is necessary to cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Command the patient to place his head on your lap, and hold his head between your hands in such a way that it does not move or shake with his head
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then put a soaked sponge in the eye of the sufferer, or in the mucus of his eyelashes over his eye: then apply the Cautery, which is of this shape.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Hold it concave, like the shape of a penknife whose handle is cut off at one end, as the Cautery is: and if it is penetrating too far, or if it is too high, do so with care
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	It is better to do this concave than flat
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and remove the pus from it, and dry it: and if it is not open, then open it and remove its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then put on the Cautery again, which is now lit cold.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand alongside the Cautery from the eye to the part of the nose, so that your hand does not slip or move the patient: and place the Cautery on the fat of the eye and burn it through
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If, therefore, you keep the Cauterium close to the bone from the beginning, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	If not: then repeat the Cauterium once or twice if you find it insufficient: and leave it off for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place the bandage with butter, and care for it with an exicator until it heals
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If for forty days it has not healed: then place above it an acute corrosive medicine, until the bone is exposed: and do the same as is stated in the chapter itself
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method for Cauterizing fistulas, which some of the first men have said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Direct it to the place of the fistula, and find it: then place under the opening of the fistula a thin cushion, that is, a needle of a thin kind, whose form is like this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it the quantity of lead which is equal to a drachma, liquefied, and keep your hand firm with the needle securely retained, and do not move the patient in any way, so that it does not run or cause the liquefied lead to go into his eye
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to place above the eye of the patient a bandage soaked in albumin or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	The lead will burn away the place of the fistula, and will heal it with a miraculous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	When the fistula is healed, with what we have said of the Cauterium and the care, that is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not: then it is necessary to administer a nasal opening and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what is stated in its own place
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	Regarding the cauterization of fissures of the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many wounds occur in the lip, which are called "Pili," and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you are treating these wounds, when you have done what we said in the instruction about treating ailments, and the cure has not helped, then you must burn the little wound with a small knife, according to this shape
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let the cavity of it be according to the sharpness of the knife
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then put the burning fire quickly into the wounds, until the cauterium has reached the depth of the wounds.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the cautery until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	And in the fistula of the mouth you should cauterize with greater caution.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When swelling occurs in the root of the tooth, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it makes pus, and swells up: afterwards it becomes black, and pus comes out, and a fistula is formed: then you must treat it, and do not be deceived by the cure, then you must burn with the cautery according to the quantity that is in the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then put the burning fire into the cavity of the fistula, and hold your hand, until the iron is burnt through to its depth, and its end: do this once, or twice at most
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it afterwards, as we said about the treatment, until it is healed
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore it breaks, and is healed, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to remove the place, and take out the corrupted bone according to what comes to light in its head
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On how to cauterize in the Gingiues and soften teeth.
Caput XXII.	On how to cauterize in the Gingiues and soften teeth.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When softened by moisture, the gums swell and move the teeth. Then put the patient's head in your lap.</start_of_turn>
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then burn the cautery, whose shape will follow, so that you can put a gauze over the tooth: and introduce the burning cautery into it quickly. Keep your hand away from the patient, until he feels the heat of the fire reach the root of the tooth.</start_of_turn
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift your hand away. Then repeat the cautery several times, as you wish.</start_of_turn
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient rinse his mouth with salt water, and keep it for an hour: and then spit it out.</start_of_turn
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	The tooth will then be firm, the gums softened and stretched, and the corrupted moisture will dry out.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On how to cauterize for toothache.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXIII.	When the toothache comes from inflammation of the tooth, then put the patient's head in your lap and apply the cautery to the head of the tooth, until the inflammation subsides. Then wash out the tooth with salt water.</start_of_turn
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache comes from cold, or from cold or from worms, and the cure is not helpful with the physicians: then burn the cautery in two ways: either with butter or with fire.</start_of_turn
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The butter must be taken whole, and the cautery must be burnt with the butter in a pan or on a tile.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take cotton and put it over the end of the tooth.</start_of_turn
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse the affected part in boiling butter: and place the part upon the painful tooth quickly, and hold it firmly until it cools: then repeat the process several times, until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	Or if desired, immerse wool or cotton in cold butter and place it upon the painful tooth: and place upon it a burning iron until the fire reaches the depth of the cavity of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cautery of the same with fire is to be done so that the air canal or the iron tube is opened.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be something of bulk in the body of the tooth, so that the fire does not penetrate too deeply into the bone of the diseased tooth
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then burn the cautery in the shape that pleases you: and place it upon the cheek of the tooth: and hold your hand firmly until the cautery cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will vanish, or in the same day, or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary to press the cautery into the impression, so that it may fill the diseased bone with good butter, and hold it for an hour: then expel it.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Burn with whatever extremity you like, according to what is possible: and this is the form of the tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	In this manner the cautery is to be performed on the molars.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the molars are affected by phlegm, and by cold humors, and do not yield to medicines, and you wish to speed up their digestion: then burn the cautery with a cavity, which is of this shape
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, like smoke escaping from Cauterium from the other limb: place the flame on the latter and, if it does not suffice, continue until it reaches the depth of the cavity.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the cavity is small: then place Cauterium according to the size of the cavity.</start_of_turn>
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then remove the flame after three days and place above it an ointment of butter, until the burnt area has subsided.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for the area with tooth unguents until it has healed to its original shape.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	In the case of raised veins or constricted windpipe.</start_of_turn
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.</start_of_turn>
