Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When moisture accumulates on the windpipe, and especially when it is accompanied by cold of complexion, then it is necessary to evacuate the patient at first with the physicians' solutions.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then burn in the shadow at the root of the gullet in a depressed place: and burn carefully, so as not to reach the gut or the skin, except for what is necessary.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then burn again with another Cauterium at the junction of the neck at the end of its last rib: and let the Cauterium be blunt according to the manner which preceded.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for the area which has preceded until it has healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	In the case of pulmonary abscesses and tumors.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.</start_of_turn
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When there is cough and pulmonary congestion caused by cold moisture, and the patient has neither fever nor phthisis, nor old consumption: then burn with two Cauteriums above the rib in depressed places, on the cartilage, on the bone.</start_of_turn
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And the cautery is applied in the middle of the chest between two nipples: and let the cautery be according to the shape which preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish the cautery to be punctate with the cautery, which is called Punctum, whose shape preceded in the puncture of pain of the ear: and let there be punctures from thirty punctures up to almost as many
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself with that which preceded, until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And let the cautery be of three branches: according to this shape
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Because it alleviates with this when you do it with three Cauteria at once.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	In this way the cautery is to be applied in Titillico, in dislocation of the Humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn>
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the adductor is displaced by the cause of humidity, and does not return to its place in an hour after displacement, until it has become accustomed to the repetition of the displacement, then it is to be displaced by a slight movement which happens as we have testified above; then it is necessary to reduce the displacement in the first place.</start_of_turn>
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the patient is laid down on his back, or on his sound side.</start_of_turn
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then raise the skin which is in the interior of the Titillico towards the upper parts with your left hand: and if the dislocation has gone inwards.</start_of_turn
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take two cautery needles.</start_of_turn
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose shape is this.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it pierces through to the other side, and the figure of the cautery will appear with four cauteries.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when a cautery is made with a cautery having three hairs, thereby the figure of the cautery is made six cauteries: and the hairs are taut according to their substance.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	This is the form of a cautery having three hairs.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when one is added above in this way, thereby there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place over the cautery salt-covered pork-skins.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the patient adhere quietly, so that the limb does not move at any time, until it is comfortable
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if displacement has gone up, and this is rarely the case, then cauterize it above the elbow with a needle cautery, or with multiple punctures
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is closed and moisture is expelled: and the patient is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	In this way the stomach is cauterized.
Caput XXVIII.	Part eight.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and much moisture happen in the stomach, until you take it out from its complexion, and multiply blisters to it, and apply diligent means of treatment, and do not confer: then it is necessary that the patient lie on his back, extend his limbs, and move his hands
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries, a cautery under the breastbone measuring the quantity of one finger with a needle cautery, and two cauteries below from the two sides of one cautery, until the figure of the cauteries becomes triangular
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen between each one so that they do not join, when pus is made
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cautery is the quantity of two-thirds of the thickness of the skin
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cauteries be according to this form without addition: and if you wish to cauterize a great cauterium in the middle of the stomach according to this form: let there be a cauterium which is like this one according to the figure of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And let the stomach be cauterized by puncturing it with that which returns from this cauterium: and it is that the signs over the stomach be punctured according to quantity, as much as you wish with the incisions: then cauterize the same with the cauterium of the puncture: then care for the same with care, which preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	In this manner let the cautery of the liver be cold.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When it happens in the Epate that there is pain from the cold and humidity, or from great windiness, until it departs from its natural composition by excessive evacuation, and the patient is cured, as we have said, and does not suffer in this: then it is necessary that the patient be placed upon his bed, and signs be made three cauteries according to this form and this quantity over the lower Ep from the underbelly, where the cubit of a man reaches: and let there be space between every cauterium according to the thickness of a digit: and let the cauterium be according to the length of the body rectum: and do not press your hand too much with the cauterium much.</start_of_turn>
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of the latter be that which is absorbed from the thickness of the skin, the middle quantity of it not being added: and let the patient stand on his feet.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If he is not standing, then let him be lying down, who has extended his limbs and raised his arms.</start_of_turn
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	It is also possible to use these needles for cautery with the knife cautery, when there is subtlety and skill in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	Beware lest you go too far with the cautery, and burn the whole skin, for the body is thereby burned throughout, and it reaches the intestines: for the skin there is thin, as you know well.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	Regarding the cautery of the posterior portion of the liver.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When the exitus [of blood] occurs, and you wish to write, if that [area of] the apostema is in the liver flesh, or in its covering: if it is in the liver flesh, there is dull pain and swelling without sharpness: and if it is in the liver covering, with sharp pain and swelling: know that it fatigues the physician to care for it.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore let the patient lie over his bed.</start_of_turn
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the figure of the place of the apostema with the cautery: then ignite the cautery which is absorbed by the heat.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with that one cautery until the whole skin is burned, and it reaches the spleen, until all the blood is gone: then take care of the care of the bleeding, until the patient is healed.</start_of_turn
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	It is not appropriate for anyone to perform such cautery except one who has studied the art of medicine for a long time, and who has experience of these things: for otherwise, you will hear of such an operation.</start_of_turn
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	It is better for her to depart from me.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	In the case of cauterization of the pleura.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 1.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	They say the ancients, when cauterizing the cold pleura with aristolochia roots, did it in this fashion
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is that you take some dry aristolochia roots, cut one of them in length equal to the thickness of a finger
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then plunge it into oil and light the thing in the fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	And with one cautery, under the angle of the collarbone, and with two smaller cauteries under the guidance of little incisions to the part under the beard
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two cauteries also in that which is between the fifth and sixth ribs, slightly towards the back: and with one cautery in the middle of the chest, and one above the stomach
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauteries from behind: one in that which is between two ribs: and two cauteries from both sides of the chest, the lower cautery being between two ribs
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And you must not press your hand with the cautery, but rather that it should smell openly from the skin.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some of the ancients say that there are men who make use of a cautery like a nail of iron: they burn and then put it inside the body between the ribs, until it is expelled along with the thing to which it was applied, and it comes out whole: just as we said concerning the apposition of the liver
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with the cautery there is fear that either the patient will die immediately or that a fistula will form in the place of the cautery, which will not heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	How to cauterize the spleen of the head.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you are treating a spleen ailment, as we have mentioned in the treatise on the treatment of ailments, and the treatment does not confer healing, then cautery is to be used in this [case] according to three methods, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of them is to make three or four cauteries in line along the length of the spleen according to the shape of the cautery for the liver, which precedes this figure.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be between every two cauteries the thickness of a finger, or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the method of cautery be as we have mentioned for the cautery of the liver
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	Do not press your hand with the cautery: let the patient lie recumbent above his back
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another method of cautery is to make the cautery with two handles like that which we mentioned in the chapter on dislocation of the humerus: and raise the skin which is over the spleen directly above the patient's elbow: and raise your arm as high as the patient's body, so that the cautery will fall along the length of the body
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two handles of the cautery which are lit on one side until the fire penetrates the skin from the other side: then withdraw the cautery: four cauteries will be made thus.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with another cautery which has three handles.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cautery after you have finished using it: let it emit pus for several days: for that is more effective than any other method which has preceded it in the treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	How to cauterize in hydropathy
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter III.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cautery does not fall into Hydropsism, except as the proper ascleptics do.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you are treating Hydropsism with the methods of treatment which we have mentioned in the preceding discourse, and the treatment does not suffice, then it is necessary to cauterize the four cauteries around the navel, one on the stomach, one on the liver, one on the spleen, and two behind the ribs between the vertebrae, and one in the middle of the chest, and one in the middle of the abdomen: and the quantity of depth of the cautery should be proportional to the thickness of the skin
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then draw out the cautery slowly, so that pus may be emitted over a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not remove the patient from the treatment after the cautery: because it is necessary to combine two intentions with it: and it will quickly recover with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the cautery which is used for the belly is the claw: according as its shape is; and the form which is used for the back is the olive, according as its shape is.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	Note: The provided text does not include any information regarding the method of cauterizing feet or limbs, so I am unable to translate that portion of the sentence.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When the limbs are apostematized in Hydropsism, and the cavity is filled with lemon juice: it is necessary to cauterize on the back of the foot in the nook, which is between the heel and the toe: and raise your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then raise your hand again: and do not move it at all
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The lemon juice will rise up again, and the cautery should be in the same form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make over two crura two cauteries in every limb, and make the cautery with the extremity of the knife of the cautery: and make the cautery according to the length of the limb, one under the knee and the other below the knee, about the middle of the limb: and over every hip make two cauteries. And draw out the cautery without treatment for a long time: until something from it comes away with some water. Then care for the rest as we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	Then make over two crura two cauteries in every limb, and make the cautery with the tip of the knife of the cautery: and make the cautery according to the length of the limb, one under the knee and the other below the knee, about the middle of the limb: and over every hip make two cauteries. And draw out the cautery without treatment for a long time: until something comes away from it with some water. Then care for the rest as we have said.
Caput XXXV.	Then make over two crura two cauteries in every limb, and make the cautery with the extremity of the knife of the cautery: and make the cautery according to the length of the limb, one under the knee and the other below the knee, about the middle of the limb: and over every hip make two cauteries. And draw out the cautery without treatment for a long time: until something comes away from it with some water. Then care for the rest as we have said.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the belly is in a state of solution from cold and moisture, until the power of retention and digestion is weakened in the stomach and intestines: and this is cured with the methods of treatment, and not by nature. And the broth tolerates the excessive power of the cautery: then make the cautery with a large knife over the belly, as it was before with the circular cautery, and four cauteries around the navel, below the ribs, and a cautery under the rib, and a cautery over the fatty tissue above the hips, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if the broth moistens the excess, and the patient tolerates this, then make the cautery with a knife over the loin, and a cautery over every hip: and perhaps add two small cauteries near the large one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	There exists a most effective treatment whose application does not err.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	There exists a most effective treatment whose application does not err.
Caput XXXVI.	There exists a most effective treatment whose application does not err.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old hemorrhoids in the rectum, either one or several, and they are from gross, cold, or moist humors, they are cured when treated as we have said above; and no other treatment is required: then cauterize three times with the cautery over the lower part of the spine under the almonds and triangular, and cauterize under the navel as with two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is stiff and his food does not digest, and his face is pale and his feces are watery, then cauterize him over the stomach with a large cautery, as we have said before: and cauterize over the liver and over the spleen and over the tail, with a closed cautery: and leave the cautery open for some time: then care for him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	There exists a most effective treatment whose application does not err. When the uterus has been cut, and there are many small blood vessels which are liable to bleed, cauterize over them with a small cautery, without causing damage to the vessel.
Caput XXXVII.	There exists a most effective treatment whose application does not err. When the uterus has been cut, and there are many small blood vessels which are liable to bleed, cauterize over them with a small cautery, without causing damage to the vessel
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut the uterus, then you should apply the cautery which contracts the vessel.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the burning part of the cautery into the cut uterus: and move your last hand until the cautery reaches the opening of the vagina, from which blood flows: do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many blood vessels in the uterus, then cauterize each one as we have said before
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for it until it is cured, when that which is given from unguents has been administered.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize it with great heat over the wound, that is the last resort in treatment.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	As to the cautering of a fistula in the rectum.</start_of_turn
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.</start_of_turn>
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not obey the section and the work that we have mentioned in its place, and returns from it, perhaps he will be cured by cautery.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When this happens to any fistula, and it becomes old, pus comes from it, and the tissues are softened.</start_of_turn
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is necessary to explore it with a subtle hook.</start_of_turn
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then learn the depth of it with the hook.</start_of_turn
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then apply the cautery, which is like a knife.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then enter the burning itself into the fistula and the amount in which the clamp has entered.</start_of_turn
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cautery above until all the corrupted bodies are consumed, once, or twice, or three times, according to the necessity.</start_of_turn
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard against overheating the nerve, if there is any, or the great veins: or if the fistula goes to the bladder or the intestines, then guard against those places as well.</start_of_turn
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	Do not do this except when the fistula is in a fleshy place: and remember that it is not penetrating.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the place until it is cured.</start_of_turn>
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If, however, the place is sealed and materials are detached from it, and it remains thus for a long time: then you know that it is completely healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	If it is not detached from it by materials, then you know that it is penetrating, or that there is a broken bone beneath the surface, or almost like this: whose memory will come to the place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	In this way, concerning cauterization of the Renes.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When it happens in the Renes that there is pain from cold or from great swelling, and that it is diminishing because of that which is causing the infirmity, then it is necessary to cauterize it over the marrow above the kidneys, with cautery over every kidney along with the nail, the precursor of which is memory
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we must cauterize it also in the very marrow.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	For there will come three lines.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore there will be two last things in the treatment
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	In this way, concerning the cauterization of the Vesica
Caput XL.	Chapter XL
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When there is weakness in the Vesica due to gravel and humidity until the infirmity does not retain urine, then cauterize it in the lower part of the belly above the Vesica, where the hair of the flanks begins, and cauterize from the right side of the belly and from the left side of it: and let the length of the cauterization on the side be according to the quantity of the node of the thumb: and cauterize with a lower cautery or with two, if you wish. And let it be according to what precedes the cautery nail
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	In this way, concerning the cauterization of the Matrix
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When in the Matrix cold and moisture abound, and it is forbidden by this [condition] from impregnation, and its menses are corrupted, and its production is delayed, and there is pain added to its companion, then it is necessary to cauterize three times around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of the bladder, and cauterize over the lower belly skin, or two cauteries: and let the cauteries be blunt.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	In dislocation of the Ancham, cauterize three times around the navel, as we said above.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When moisture of the mucous membrane flows down to the heel of the Ancham, and is the cause of its displacement from its place: the sign of this is that one thigh is prolonged over the other, when compared with the thigh on the same side: and the place of dislocation is found in that groove.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	It is therefore necessary to cauterize the diseased part above the heel of the Ancham with a circle: after you have marked the sign with the cautery around the circumference of the heel, as if you were rolling: and that the heel itself falls in the middle of the circle.</start_of_turn
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cautery be of the form which we mentioned in the cauterization of the stomach.</start_of_turn
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cautery is not present, then cauterize it three times with a large olive cautery: and let the depth of the cautery be according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin altogether.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	(The text continues with instructions for treating sciatica.)</start_of_turn>
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain arises in the ankle bone, and the cause is coldness and moisture: the physician should treat the patient with what has been mentioned previously [in another section], and if no benefit results, he should dry it up: then it is necessary to remove the patient from the thick humours with foul pills or artificial pills, and like these.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the mode of cautery in this case is in two ways: either with cautery and astringents, or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	Cautery with fire is done in many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of them is to cauterize over the ankle bone itself with three triangular cautery instruments, according to this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make the burn either deep or shallow
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And let the space between every two cauteries be of the quantity of the breadth of a finger: and let the cautery be round
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	When, however, the cautery is done in the middle over the ankle bone itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Then there are four cautery instruments
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize in a circular fashion, whose form precedes the cautery of dislocation of the ankle, one: so that it may contain the whole ankle
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the whole thickness of the skin.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the mode of cautery in Sciatica, when the pain is adherent to the ankle itself, and does not extend up to the knee and thigh
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If, however, it extends up to the knee and thigh, then cauterize the two cautery instruments over the knee, over the place where the patient feels pain there, and cauterize your hand over the heel of the foot to the outer side: and let the cautery be with a knife
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	The depth of the burn should be in accordance with the depth of the hair of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the patient complains that the pain extends up to the toes, then burn only in that place as much as the burn of a point, a third, or a fourth, or even more, as is necessary for that area.</start_of_turn>
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	If it is said that the pain is under the knee and above the ankle, then burn only in that place with a single knife.</start_of_turn>
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And burn always in your cauterizations, that you do not reach the nerves or great vessels, and that you do not cause excessive pain or contraction.</start_of_turn>
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	I also know of one who cauterized over the knee and left the last burn until the leg was swollen, until the foot was completely swollen and perforated, and the whole leg was corrupted: then the belly burst open and there was death after that.</start_of_turn>
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If the pain is in two parts together, burn both of them in this manner.</start_of_turn
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men say concerning the cauterization of an abscess, that this is the manner.</start_of_turn
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a resemblance like iron, whose diameter is a middle of the palm: and let it be at a distance from its orifice equal to the length of the kernel of the thumb, or less: and there let there be the third part within.</start_of_turn
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let there be space between every part of the three that is equal to the quantity of the wrist-knot: and let the burn be open from two parts: and let its height be like a knot, or two knots: and make the handle of the iron centered in the burns.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is ignited in the fire until it turns red, and it throws sparks: then it is placed upon a cushion of felt covering the painful side over the healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	It is cauterized with three round cauteries in one vessel
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let it be withdrawn three days later.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterward it is plastered with butter: and let the wound be opened for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, concerning this kind of cautery, of the son of the blacksmith, we use it little, because of its fearsome appearance: and because of this, we find few who are willing to endure it over it
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Indeed, from the good cauteries it is useful to him who suffers, and it is found with him in its place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cautery, however, with the physicians who are accustomed to it, is useful as when you make two holes in the arm of a man who has a wound of the artery of the wrist: from which the bone of the hand comes down, either of iron or of lead, the length of the wall: of which two knots should be made at the height of these.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And there should be a space between each quantity equal to the thickness of a finger, and there should be an opening below and above: and it should contain itself inside, according to this form
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then put it upon a cushion of felt covering the painful side over the healthy side
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand over the cushion of felt many times
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles of hot water, which is warmed with fire a little, and keep it for the quantity of an hour: and the patient will tolerate the biting of the cautery, and he himself brings it to himself, for he finds the biting to be like fire until it rests.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then raise your hand with the instrument and bathe the whole area with warm water and sweet water: then leave it for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put butter on it, until the black of the wound has subsided: and leave it for a few days, and pus will flow out of it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	This is the last thing to do.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents, until it heals
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the hip or the knee: make for it a bath containing as much water as you did in the whole area
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	This is the way of warm water: and I have written it in the treatise on medical rectifications.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and unburnt lime, mix both in an equal amount: put each of them in a new vessel, whose lower part is pierced with a small hole according to the quantity which is to be included: and put under the bottom of the vessel another vessel filled with vinegar: and pour over the alkali and lime solution sweet water, which submerges both by a finger: and then press your hand firmly: and leave the vessel until the acute water has descended from the lower part of the treated vessel.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather up the whole water, and pour it over the lime: and leave it, until it recovers
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	These are themselves strong and acute, which are administered in many medical operations and in the cauterization of the rest of the limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it makes the operation of fire itself
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from the physicians, who cauterize the area, even as for testicles, and mas, and almond oil, and lime with soap, thus that both are mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	Galen also reports that a certain man from ancient times received treatment for pain in the buttocks and sciatica: and he praised his diligence.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	He said that no other treatment was required, and that he was healed by one bath alone.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	It is as it is said of the physician: if the patient does not improve with oil, let him be bathed with hot water; and let him be massaged frequently with much fat, and let him be placed upon the buttocks, where the pain is, or the thigh, or the hip: and it shall be bound, and it shall be left for three hours, or for as long as the patient feels relief from the pain.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then let him be put into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When his body is softened, put him into the tub.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain will depart, and he will be healed
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you know that no other cauterization should be used with these medicines, except after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	Dioscorides also says that the dung of goats, when cauterized with it, gives relief to the sciatica: and it is cauterized in this way.</start_of_turn>
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Let a lancet be taken, and let it be soaked in old oil, and let it be placed upon the deep place which is between the thumb of the foot and the heel, and is closer to the heel.</start_of_turn>
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take the dry dung of goats, and burn it in the fire, until it is black.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then put it upon the lancet, and leave it until it is extinguished.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera illud.	Then do it again.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Then do it again until sensation returns above the mediation, and the pain has ceased.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	This is the method of cautery known as the Vaccinum cauterium.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Of the cautery of back pain.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.</start_of_turn
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When there is pain in the back from numerous causes, or from a wound, or from a blow, or from excessive evacuation, or in similar cases, neither cautery nor any other remedy will suffice, except for one kind which is made from the infusion of cold and moist matter.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary, therefore, after evacuation of the patient with foul pills and similar substances, to make three lines on the back where the pain is, alongside the palm of the hand, and when signs of scorching appear in every line after having made five cauteries, or more according to the patient's tolerance.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if desired, cauterize three or four times with the middle cautery, according to this form.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Of the method of cautery in the groin.</start_of_turn
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.</start_of_turn
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This pain often occurs in young children.</start_of_turn
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	The sign of its inception in children is: when there is a tightening in the belly at inspiration near elevation, and movement: and it is found in the last vertebra of the back and the nodes of the back, which begin to stand out over the rest.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you have done that, and you wish to make that, then burn it with the cautery which is circular in shape according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	The cautery shall grasp every part of the bone equally: and if you wish to burn around the bone with the cautery, make two or three points, and let the points be close to one another
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place, until it is healed as we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And burn, lest you administer the cautery to a callous person, which is in the spasm of a nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	In the same way as for cautery of the foot and the joining pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of the joints are from cold humors which flow upon every limb of the body, then when such pains happen in the feet, it is customary among physicians to call it Podagra
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore Podagra is cured by the coldness of causes, with methods of treatment, and the pains are not removed, then the cautery will remove them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is necessary to burn around the joint of the foot after the evacuation with many cauteries: and let the cautery be of Olivewood
Cuius haec est forma.	Which has this form
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you do not wish to make holes on the face of the foot, then make it with the point of the cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	And if the pains ascend up to the knee, or remain in the other joints, and many such things happen, then burn the whole knee with three, or four cauteries, with the same cautery of Claudius.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If necessary are more of these for the cautery, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	Do not immerse your hand with the cautery, but rather keep the thickness of the skin at a distance from it.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If, however, pain rises to the knees and back: then manage what we said concerning the cautery in its chapter
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If the pain is only in the hands: then prick in the circumference of the fingers, as two lines are unrolled
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If, however, the pain remains in the digits: then prick throughout the node of the digit, over every point of the digit, and over the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If, however, the pain ascends after a day to the elbows or shoulders: then cauterize both of them from all sides
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not aggravate the sick person by harsh methods, but by the advice of doctors.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regimen is made, and the phlegm is evacuated, the healing will be aided by God with this cautery
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	On the method of cautery in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, and the intestine or bladder descends to the testicle, and this is at the beginning close: then it is necessary for the patient to vomit immediately on that day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And to evacuate from soft things, so that the stool may descend from its belly
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then sit between your hands on your back: and command him to hold his breath until he vomits, or until the bladder or intestine appears
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce the finger with your thumb, and sign with the sign of the encaustro below the rupture above the bone of the knee, with the sign whose extremity is similar to the middle of the circle towards the upper parts of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then apply the cautery, which has this shape, until it turns white, and then remove the cautery.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine or the bladder to their own cavity
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then place your hand on the place, so that the intestine does not escape: and you have opened between the ribs of the patient, and placed under it powder, and another servant on his ribs and another on his chest which holds the hand.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cautery on that sign, your hand with the cautery standing straight up
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it there, until you follow the bone: or do it again with it another way, if you have not followed it with it from the beginning until the bone
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And observe prudently the exit of the intestine in the hour of your cautery, so that you do not burn it, and that it comes out through that over the patient or the wound, or great malice.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not follow with the cautery the bone, your operation will be in vain
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery be fine for infants, according to their measure
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the rest of the wounds, until they are healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the patient lie on his back for forty days, until the wound has healed
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you give the patient nourishment throughout the time of his cure, so that it softens his belly: so that the intestine does not escape through the wound and be evacuated
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wishes to rise after forty days, he must manage the ligament which is made central and keep it for forty days more.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	He will abstain from labor, and take nourishment of food and drink, and use of strong medicines.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he follows this regimen, he will be restored to complete health.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will speak of the treatment of ruptures with incision in his chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When however ruptures happen in the remaining part within, and are just beginning, and you wish that they should not grow larger, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its quantity: and let it be so that from that time forward it will endure as much as a third of it
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for it as we have said: and do not add to it
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some say that the rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this form
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	When it is signed with encasement, and a line is drawn through the width at the upper side of the rupture, and a line to the lower side.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the cautery handle.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	In like manner the cautery is to be used for pains caused by swelling or percussion
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When anything has happened to any limb by swelling or percussion and the pain persists for a long time, and does not yield to treatment with physicians: then it is necessary to cauterize with the Puncti cautery
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery be of the size of the limb, and its degree, and its hardness, and its toughness, and the place of torsion, and the pain from it
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If the patient has recovered from the first cautery, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat the cautery above the first one.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For the custom of these pains is that they change from member to member approaching the one that is most proximate to them.</start_of_turn>
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore one must follow these with the cautery until the patient is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	Concerning the cautery of Lepra.</start_of_turn
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.</start_of_turn>
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Leprosy sometimes requires the greatest cautery.</start_of_turn
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially those kinds of leprosy which are caused by the corruption of phlegmas and melancholia: in such cases one must carefully consider the very act of cautery.</start_of_turn
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If the leprosy is not severe, and the swelling has gone down as we have mentioned previously, and has not reappeared: and the time has come for the patient, who has suffered corruption throughout his body: then burn him five times with the cautery: one in the middle of the head, one below at the front near the hair's end, and two on the two horns, and one at the back on the nape of the neck.</start_of_turn
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And finally, touch his hand with the cautery lightly, until you make an imprint in the bone, and the cortex is fractured: so that the great vapors will be driven out from it, and burn the spleen also with the cautery, as we have said before.</start_of_turn
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If however the leprosy has spread throughout the body and is obvious: then burn with these cauteries which we have mentioned in the head, and cauterize the tip of the nose, and two on the two cheeks, and two on the two cheekbones, and six on the vertebrae of the neck, and one large one on the flanks of the buttocks and one above the kidneys: and two on the buttocks: that is one on each buttock, and two on the knees: one on each knee, and two on the biceps, and two on the triceps, and two on the chest, and cauterize the whole of the joints between the fingers and toes, and the heels of the feet.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And take care that from the nerves which are above the heel, so that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	When the cautery is applied above the heel, and also above the ribs, and also above the spleen.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you add of the cautery, the more damage is done, and the more likely it is to cause harm
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the sickly man does not feel pain from the cautery, just as the healthy do: because the body of the sickly man is already stunned
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	It is necessary that the cautery should be of appropriate size, and in proportion to the members and the joints: according to what preceded from the kinds of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the cautery with an herb paste with honey, and the rest of the treatment, until the wound is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	As to the cautery of the heel...
Caput L.	...See to the cautery of the heel...
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When some limb is stiff and cannot be cured by physicians, and oils, and poultices, and it does not heal, then cauterize the stiff limb with cautery, according to the size of the limb or its proportion
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let the cautery not penetrate too deeply into the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with an unguent, until it is healed
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	When the cautery is applied to some stiffness of the hand or foot, in the joints of the back near the exit of the nerves which move that limb: then the stiffness will be removed
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But do not be rash over this, except for one who is learned in the anatomy of the limbs and the course of the nerves
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	How to cauterize in Albaras.
Caput LI.	How to cauterize in Albaras.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albaras has hardened, and no remedy from medical knowledge can be found: then cauterize over the cauterium itself deeply but sparingly, according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin, until the white is removed, and the color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with barley flour and lentils with oil of rose, and arnica leaves, and poppyseed, and hyacinth blood: take a part of each: mix them together, and spread over the wound, and adhere to the place, until it heals
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	How to cauterize in Cancer
Caput LII.	How to cauterize in Cancer
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When Cancer is beginning, and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with the cauterium in a circle around its circumference, as it returns
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But the wise men say, that one should cauterize in the middle last of all.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	I do not see that: for I fear that it will ulcerate: and I do see it often.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better to cauterize around it with a circle, as we said: or with many cauteriums.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	How to cauterize in Adubelati
Caput LIII.	How to cauterize in Adubelati
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When anyone has Adubelati, and it is delayed in maturity, or because of excess fat making it fat, or because of age which makes it frail, or because of weakness, or because of time, and he wishes to hasten the maturity of the Adubelati: then cauterize around it with many small cauteriums puncturing
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then depart from it.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	Then depart from it. For itself will hasten with maturity.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If, however, you wish to perforate it with a cautery, then ignite the cautery, whose form is this.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the Adubelati, until it penetrates the skin: and let the cautery be away from that which follows the diseased, in order to diminish the course of the pus.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	In a corroding wound, cauterize cautiously
Caput LIIII.	Day 42.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A wound is not corrosive except for corruption in a mobile limb, and it corrupts it: like fire consumes dry wood
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If therefore you wish to cauterize the corrosive in a place where it tolerates it with fire, then ignite the cautery frequently, make the blisters small and large, according as it will be convenient in the place where it is corrosive
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all sides until you have eradicated the whole corruption, and let nothing remain of it except for the very little
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then leave it for three days, and put upon the cauterized place powdered sulphur with oil, until all the scabs are eradicated and the whole corruption is gone
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for it with nourishing poultices of flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If therefore you see that after three days new flesh is born healthy, in which there is no corruption, it is good
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then repeat the cautery over that which remains of the corrupted places
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	A wound is treated with acute medicine when necessary
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	It itself arises from the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	Indeed, it arises from the place of the cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	For indeed, the cautery is of quicker healing when applied to ulcers and boils.
Caput LV.	It is of quicker healing when applied to ulcers and boils
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	Many times this ailment occurs in the lower parts of the feet: and it is a great, swelling, painful thing that affects the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And the cautery is of two kinds: with fire and with hot water
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	When the cautery is done with fire, it is like branding a goose feather: this is done with iron according to the amount that it contains in the limb from every side: and it must not touch the edges
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then put the fire on the limb.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then withdraw the limb with the cautery around the limb until the cautery reaches the depth of the limb: and leave it for three days until it begins to discharge pus
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then cover it with coarse sand, sprinkle with salt: and leave the dressing on it overnight
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	And it will itself disappear from its root
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place where the flesh has been burnt, until it has healed
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not cauterized, and appear many times on the surface of the body, especially on the hands and feet: then administer the cautery with hot water: and take a piece of iron, or a piece of wood, or a feather from a bird: and put it on the limb, or on the ulcer.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a small quantity of hot water into the cannula: hold your hand steady and withdraw the cannula with pressure on your hand near the root of the claw, so that the mark of the cannula may be impressed on the root of the claw. Then find the hot water up to the root of the claw: and the patient should expect relief after an hour of the hot water treatment.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then withdraw it, for the claw is eradicated with its roots.</start_of_turn>
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do so with one hand after the other, until you reach above all that is in the body.</start_of_turn>
