Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for the wound after it has been eradicated, with what is generated from the split flesh.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	In Tremore, cauterize in this way.</start_of_turn
Caput LVI.	Chapter 66.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to anyone to have a tremor from cold in the nerve, or from a quartan fever, or something else: then it is necessary to cauterize four times, or five on the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra cauterize, and in the chest cauterize, and on the stomach cauterize.</start_of_turn
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	The tremor will cease with the cauterization of olive oil, and health will quickly return from the cold sickness.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	Thus cauterize Albathir.</start_of_turn
Caput LVII.	Chapter 67.</start_of_turn
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When there are expelled from the body of Albathir wounds, that is, abscesses, which are formed from corrupted thick matter.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	It is necessary therefore in the first place when they appear to cauterize over every head of the abscess with a fine cautery with a twig of myrrh whose extremity is kindled with fire.</start_of_turn
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	As with the root of aristolochia longae.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or as with the cautery of a lentil
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And sometimes when cauterizing the blood clots, at the beginning of their expulsion, they do so in this way: and do not grow: and rupture the superfluity that makes them, and heal from within.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it must be done after evacuation with a bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	As to the cautery in the flow of blood from an artery to the wound
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Many things happen with the flow of blood from an artery that has been incised at the wound, which happens both outside and at the incision of the apostem, or by the cautery of a limb, and the like: and this makes it difficult to stop the bleeding
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	When this happens to anyone, then act promptly with your hand at the orifice of the artery, and place above it your finger index: and tighten it much, until the blood is stopped under your finger, and does not escape from there again
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put in the fire a small olive cautery, and many in number: and blow over them, until they are ignited thoroughly
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then grasp from the thing one, or a little, or a lot, according to the wound and the place where the artery is ruptured, and place the cautery upon that very place: and when you have moved your finger away quickly: and hold the cautery, until the bleeding is stopped
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	And if it is expelled when you remove your finger from the orifice of the artery, and extinguish the cautery, then grasp another cautery quickly from those which are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Do not cease to perform it until the blood is severed.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	Do not burn the nerve that is there, and add over the sick some other malice.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	Know that when blood flows from an artery, then it is not possible to sever it: especially when the artery is great, except with four fingers.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said before.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or by extraction, when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its extremities are contracted, and the blood is severed.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is bound with a strong ligature
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or there are placed over it medicines of the property of severing blood, and it is bound with a nail of constriction of descent
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever performs the severance with a ligature, and tightens with a bandage or position of the burning things, or the like, does not give it sufficient pain, except rarely
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If however it is done to someone, and there is no physician present, neither medicine: then begin with the position of the index finger over the orifice of the vein itself, as we have said, and its constriction above, until the blood is overcome from the upper part of the wound, and over the artery
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger is not moved, except with cold water or ice always, until the blood is congealed, and has become firm, and is severed.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile consider what is needed from the cautery, or from the medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in Wounds, and Similar Procedures.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already said in the first chapter that all diseases in which fire and burning medicine concur, and their occasions, their causes, and their instruments, and the forms of cautery
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I shall treat of the chapters following from the head to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	I shall pursue this chapter in the same way: as one who seeks an answer to his inquiry
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	Before I begin, it is necessary to tell you what is omitted from this chapter in comparison with the first chapter on cautery
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	Therefore it is necessary to exercise caution in this operation, because in this chapter there falls out evacuation with blood in many places: in the opening of the vein, or the incision over the bone, or the opening of an abscess, or the care of a wound, or the extraction of an arrow, or the incision over a stone, and such like things. From all of these things there is associated tremor, and fear, and falls in many of them blood
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	I warn you, do not be afraid of this, for in this art there are many people who have become skilled as men in health have become skilled in sickness.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For from this is he who flees from his ailment, and is light in the face of danger: because of his gentleness which he has from his ailment and the length of his experience
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when an ailment comes from fear, it signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	From him also is the one who gives you his staff, and tells you that he is with you, hoping for your health, and his ailment is mischievous.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	It is not proper that you consent to those who come to you from outside, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	You should be cautious with them, more so than with love and your own possessions.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	Do not presume anything about them, except after certain knowledge has been revealed to you, which confirms that their actions are worthy of praise
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	Use your care in treating all female patients, in prognostication and indication of the thing which is conducive to their health
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in this lies your help in acquiring fame and glory, and memory and praise
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, his son, your intellect, and do not take from you direction and inspiration: for this is in his hand
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I, too, have ordained this chapter distinguishing it by chapters, according as it follows the chapter of Cauteries, from the navel until the feet: that you may fulfill your desire and what you need from this.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Concerning the treatment of water which accumulates in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You know that this ailment often happens to children at birth: or when the midwife tightens the head of the child without gentleness
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And sometimes it also happens for an occult cause which is not known
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	I have not seen this illness in anyone except children: and for all those whom I have seen among them, death has been the consequence: for this reason it is fitting for me to send away the operation in this case
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have also seen among children whose heads were filled with water, and their heads would swell up every day, until they were unable to sit on their own because of the size of their heads: and the moisture increased until they died
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And thus also is moisture, either collected between skin and bone: or collected under bone upon the fat.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And in that case, if there is moisture between skin and bone, and the swelling is slight, one must make a single incision in the middle of the head, about the length of two knots, until the moisture is drained.</start_of_turn>
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the shape of a sponge.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If there is much moisture and the swelling is great, then one must make two incisions according to this form.</start_of_turn>
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	If the moisture is under the bone, and its sign is that the edges of the head are open from every side: and water is driven out when you press your hand into the interior, and it is not hidden from you: then one must make three incisions in the middle of the head according to this manner.</start_of_turn
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision drain out all the moisture.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then stitch up the incisions with silk and wool.</start_of_turn
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then bandage it above with wine and oil until the fifth day.</start_of_turn>
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligament and care for the wound with tension and care.</start_of_turn
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not tighten the head too tightly.</start_of_turn
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And give the patient little food and much dry food until the limb is comfortable and healed.</start_of_turn
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is to consider the size of the swelling and the collection of water.</start_of_turn
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes in the skull there is more, or in the eyebrow, or on the right, or on the left.</start_of_turn
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Rise therefore when the incision is made where the swelling appears and the water is poured in: and cut that according to what is possible.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	Observe, lest you cut an artery, and the blood flow increase, and the patient die from that flow with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Concerning the incision of the arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter II
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When any swelling comes about in the eyes or the chest, and the disease persists, and no remedy is of avail: then the last remedy is the incision of these two arteries
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	It is necessary therefore when you wish to make an incision, that you remove the patient's head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then scrape the place with rough cloth, so that the arteries appear
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then bind the patient's neck with anything he has of his own cloth
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the pulse of the vein lies
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places where both are located are those which are behind the ears depressed: and they are rarely hidden, except in some men
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with a burn on each side: and cut each one with a needle as sharp as possible, cutting through to the bone: and do this through the breadth of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert a sponge under the artery, and cut above with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be like two joined fingers
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the artery is cut, blood flows out with the pulsation, which leaps inside with great jumps
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If however the artery does not appear to the sense, then it is necessary to measure three digits from the ear.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then signs with incisions, and find until the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what should be emitted from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps more or less is emitted from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All this according to the quantity which you see from the patient's wound and the filling of its artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider for the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything remains at the bone from the scraping, then cut that away, so that there does not happen a stiff swelling: then bind the wound with strips of linen cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment, until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Concerning the extraction of arteries, which are in the temperaments.</start_of_turn>
Caput III.	Chapter 3.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man an ancient headache, or acute catarrh because of acrid humilities and warmth in the lacerations of the temperaments, or ancient soda, which is harmful, and similar to these: and it is medicated with the methods of medical treatment, and does not depart from it: then we are experts in the extraction of arteries from the temperaments, or their cauterization, as we have narrated.</start_of_turn>
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the manner of the operation in the extraction of these is that the patient shaves the hair which is in the temperaments, and exposes the apparent artery in the temperament.</start_of_turn
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	It itself is shown to you from its pulse, and rarely is it hidden except in a few people, or because of excessive cold.</start_of_turn
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you, then the patient should bind his head with anything he has: then rub the place with rough cloth.</start_of_turn
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Until the steam rises to the surface like hot water, the phenomenon shall be evident.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then grasp the sponge, which is before your eyes in its form.</start_of_turn>
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then strip off the skin with it [the sponge] until you reach the artery.</start_of_turn
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then throw the ligature into the loop and draw it upwards, until you have pulled the ligature out from the skin, and made it retract from the tunics beneath it on all sides.</start_of_turn>
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is small: then loop the ligature around the extremity of the needle.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from it the part according to the length of its extremities, and tighten, and the blood flow will cease.</start_of_turn
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut through, or if it is not severed, the blood will not ascend fully.</start_of_turn
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then wash from the blood about six ounces, until three.</start_of_turn
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then it is necessary to ligate it in two places with a strong thread, of silk: or with horsehair, so that it does not become putrefied before the wound has consolidated, and the blood flow is restored.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the surplus, which is between the two ligatures.</start_of_turn
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this in an hour, or an hour later.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if necessary, cauterize the skin with a cautery until the extremities of the ligature have been cut through, and it has stabilized in the place of the work.</start_of_turn
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	It is better to do the work when the patient has a normal temperature, or slightly feverish, than when the patient is feverish.</start_of_turn
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Since the cautery is from the earth, which moves towards the completion of moistnesses.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore is the application better.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of the arteries, that the cautery be applied to the old place: and that it be placed over the middle of the wound.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the closing it is to be cared for with dry medicines, which make the flesh grow, and with sponges, until it is healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Which if, during the work, blood flows from the artery, then it is proper to cut off the same with the cautery, or to place the cautery at the place of the blood vessel: and hold your hand, until the blood is stopped
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	Which if nothing of these is present, then put over the place your finger, until the blood congeals
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And embroider the place with cold water, until the pain is quieted, and be bound according as it is necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And from this it is evident that it is more easy and manageable to extract the artery, when this cautery has two blades: and that the sharpness of the two blades is similar to that of an almond
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	Yet are these of much less sharpness than two blades.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Since if they are sharp, like two blades, both are apt to cause frost: and they do not cut the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Since therefore in the earth there is somewhat of thickness, it is held in the earth the heat of fire, and the flesh is quickly cut off: with this therefore the work is better in all respects, and easier, and more manageable
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space which is between the two blades be as much as the thickness of a finger, after you have marked two points with the cautery: and place both of them alight, until they reach the bone, and cut the artery in two places: that it may be prolonged which is between the extremities of it.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	They do not solidify with this deep burn.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the burn.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Be attentive to acute tear-lachrymal fluid from the eyes
Caput IIII.	Chapter III
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are viscous and flow from the eyes, which are above the outer part of the head: then it does not require any medical treatment from physicians, and the liquid makes the face of the patient red, and he feels a wandering in his face like the wandering of ants: and his eyes are swollen and wet, as though they were corroded by something: and his eyelids are reddened from the intensity of the tears. Then the old people say in the treatment of these things by means of an operation, and they call this treatment "Ense".
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	It is also necessary to remove the hairs in front of his face from the patient
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions at an equal distance from each other according to the length of the forehead: and let the length of the incision be like two fingers, and let one incision be at an equal distance from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length of the lower lip, and the third from the other side: and cauterize from the arteries which are in the two sides. And extend your hand from the continuation of your two mandibles, and let the space of the incision be as much as the thickness of three fingers together. And let a sponge be prepared, or dry cloth, with which to soak up the blood.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert the sponge of two acute extremities, whose following shape is like this.</start_of_turn>
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is at the temple, up to the second incision: and scrape with it all the skin which is between the two incisions, with a sponge, which is over the bone.</start_of_turn
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do it also from the middle incision up to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract the sponge and introduce another instrument, which is called the sharp scalpel, from one wide side, not from the acute side
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its acute side towards the flesh attached to the skin, and its wide side towards the bone: and push it in until it reaches the middle incision: and cut through everything that descends from the head to the eyes: except that which appears on the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do it also from the middle incision up to the second incision
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when blood has flown out in an equal amount, express the place from coagulated blood clots
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place in every incision a patch of coarse cotton, and put over that soaked wool pads in wine, and oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that no swelling occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day heal the ligament, and give an abundant infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it from the ointment of basil, and leave the rest of the wounds to heal: until they are healed
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	Concerning the care of sharp tears and catarrh to the eyes from the inside of the head
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When these occur to anyone with acute, itchy, sticky tears: and when their eyes are extended, parched, and the sight is impaired: and the eyelashes are ulcerated, and hair falls out from the eyelids, and there is acute pain in the depths of the head, which brings about sneezing: then take away from these causes all those matters, and the catarrh will not come from these unless from many tears.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	The best treatment in these cases is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	The best is to shave the patient's face thoroughly.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make a single incision in the middle of the face, or on the other side along the width, and commence from the left ear towards the right ear: and reach the incision up to the bone: and stretch your hand from the edges of the wounds which move with chewing until the bone is reached: and you will extract all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate the two lips of the wound with wool or strips of linen
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind up above with threads: and soak the threads with wine and oil, so that they do not cause a cold abscess
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	When you have finished, and you see that the abscess is about to disappear: then it is necessary to rub the bone until new flesh begins to form on it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for yourself with a regimen of nourishment that promotes the growth of flesh: such as if you were to take from wheat flour two parts and from barley four parts: and prepare from these a paste, and administer it to the wounds
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	Concerning the care of these things that fall in autumn.
Caput VI.	(The text ends here.)
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls in autumn is of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something like a stone, such as iron, or gold: or it is from a plant, such as lentil, and beans: or it is a fluid substance, such as water, and vinegar, and blood, or something similar to these things.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When such a stone or kind of stone is fallen in autumn which does not grow in autumn from the earth, it exposes the autumn to the sun: if you wash the stone, then distil from oil or vinegar something from the earth in autumn.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then manage the extraction of it, and make the patient sit upright with his head supported, and anoint the nostrils near the site of the incision, after you have placed around the circumference of the ear a piece of cloth or wool, and extended the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Many are the things that depart with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If, however, they do not depart, then manage the extraction of it with sponges, that is, fine sponges: whose form is like this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If they depart with the sponge, that is good
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then manage the extraction of it with a blunt needle of small size.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If it does not depart by this, then make a hole in the air, and insert the extremity of the needle into the ear much, and anoint what is around the needle with fat, so that there be no air in it: then draw out with your hand with force.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Many are the things that depart with this which we have said.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If it does not depart in this way: then take from chaff or from blood, that is, prepared gluten, with which one captures doves, a remedy: and place it in the extremity of the radius after you have encircled above the knee bent downwards: then insert it into the ear with ease, after you have dried the ear from moisture
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If it does not depart with all that we have said, then prepare for cutting, before the swelling becomes great, or spasm.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the manner of the incision is like that of a phlebotomy in the forehead: and draw out from the blood according to the measure of its virtue.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the patient sit between your hands, and support his ear upwards, and find the opening of the ear close to its fat in a depressed place: and let the incision be in the shape of a crescent, until you reach the bone: then take out the instrument with that which you are able.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then seal the wound from this hour with speed, and care for it, until it is healed.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If a foreign body has fallen into the wound from one grain which is growing and swelling, then administer its extraction.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not obey your command to come out, then take hold of a soft sponge, fine and smooth, according to this shape.</start_of_turn
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the excision of that kind from the grains that have fallen into the wound, and do not make that which you think is moist from the vapor of the ear, until you have put on many plugs: then extract them with hooks, or with fine fingers, or with suction, as we have said, for its extraction alleviates it.</start_of_turn>
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But when water enters the wound, the patient must be ordered to sneeze forcefully at first: and immediately moisten the wound with a little bit of old cloth: and it is placed over the wound which is in the water.</start_of_turn
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If it comes out through this, that is good.</start_of_turn
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of a finger, round, smooth, and warm them with fire slightly, and let the patient put one finger into his ear: and salt his foot one from this side, and strike with another stone against the stone which is in the wound.</start_of_turn
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Do not cease doing this with the stone and the stone, until all the water has come out.</start_of_turn
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And when the water comes out like this, take from the fire, or from a single jug, and introduce one extremity into the wound: and kindle the other extremity with fire, until most of it is consumed.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat the procedure with another sponge, making it much more thorough, until all the water has drained out: and extract the sponge with a tube as directed previously in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of an animal within the body, if it is small in size, like a flea or its kin, take care of it as I have said in the instructions.</start_of_turn>
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if the body is large, which appears to the sense: then manage the extraction of it with hands and instruments: and thus its matter will be easier for all who hold it in the hand.</start_of_turn
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	In the extraction of a worm that has generated in the gold, when you have cured it as we have said in the instructions on distillation, and in the treatise on the distillation of urine, and its cure does not suffice: then you must burn the gold in the sun.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If anything appears there from the worms, then extract it with hands or with fine instruments.</start_of_turn
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If nothing appears there, then take a tube whose shape is like this, narrow below and wide above: and insert the lower extremity into the gold according to the amount that the sick person tolerates: then suck with it.</start_of_turn>
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Make it much more thorough, until all the worms have drained out.</start_of_turn
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If they do not obey you with regard to the draining out, then smear around the circumference of the tube with lead, as I have said in the stone.</start_of_turn
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not drain out with this, then perform distillations which the ancient experts are experienced in concerning the junction of worms: and you will find this in the treatise on distillations.</start_of_turn
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your effusion be such as that which flows out of oil and medicines into the gold with this instrument whose shape is like this.</start_of_turn
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As for wounds made from silver or from air, below is a stricture in which there is a small hole, and above it is broad.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Thus as for wounds inflicted by silver or air, below is a stricture in which there is a small hole, and above it is broad.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	If you will, take a sponge, and moisten its extremity with a poultice of lint: then pour oil, or succum, or whatever you will of these medicines into the tube: and let it be well closed: then introduce the sponge with the poultice above, and compress it with your hand until oil is squeezed out into the ear, and the patient feels it inside: and that which is poured into the ear should be made warm with a little fire: and beware lest anything be distilled in it when cold: for medicine does not bear that.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	And concerning the care of wounds inflicted by gold.
Caput VII.	(The provided text does not include any information regarding "The care of wounds inflicted by gold," so I am unable to translate this sentence.)
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Whenever some children come out of their mothers' wombs unperforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And sometimes it happens also that some people have their ears opened up by a wound, or by meat being born in it
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this opening up happens sometimes in the depth of the ear-hole, which does not follow the usual course: and sometimes it happens outside the small hole of the ear, and follows the usual course.</start_of_turn>
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which happens in the depth of the ear and which is not comprehended by the aspect, is in many dispositions difficult to heal.</start_of_turn>
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And as for that which follows the usual course, it is necessary to place the ear of the patient in the sun, and to press on it: then if the wound appears, open the hole with a fine lancet whose form is like this which follows, and let its extremity be in the part which has a small width, and whose part is acute: and the rest of the lancet should be soft on both sides: so as not to harm the ear.</start_of_turn
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If, therefore, the swelling has arisen from the meat of the ear: then hold one finger under the skin, and pierce with ease until the whole flesh has been removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the swelling is deep in the ear: then take a fine needle, thread it, and burnish with fire: then remove it from the meat of the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you feel swelling with pain, which the sick person has with a weighty ear, try to open it with ease: and be careful, lest you damage the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put in the ear a quantity of unguent according to the extent of the opening which you made in the Egyptian bandage: do this for a few days, until you are certain that the wound has healed
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a salve and mix it with rose-water, and sprinkle over it fine powder of burnt ochre, and use it thus.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you wish to remove the swelling from the ear: then it is necessary to extract the salve and leave it with another salve which you mix with rose-water, which you put in a vessel made of beeswax: let the swelling become cold: then care for it until it is healed
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If blood flows: then immerse a sponge or cloth in cold water and put it on the ear: and use the rest of the treatment which expels the blood which is said in the treatise on distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	(The text continues with instructions on how to treat eye ailments.)
Caput VIII.	(The heading of the next section is not included in the provided text.)
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These are the Althelis which happen in the eyes when they are humid and are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	It is necessary therefore to hold them with nails: or with a finger, and pierce them with a needle from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place above the wound a piece of sponge.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If blood flows from the wound, then cauterize it with a fine lancet.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	It is better to cauterize after the incision has been made.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	Many things return when something remains of their root
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	When they are cauterized with fire, those roots burn and do not return
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Take care of the great palpebrae of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Many things happen in the palpebrae of the eye that assimilate Crandinum in its substance, and its hardness, and because of this it is called Great: and it is an accumulation of thick moisture in the upper and lower palpebrae.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation is like this: if there is a Greatness proceeding from the palpebrae, which appears from the palpebra and moves to all parts, then it is easy to remove it
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Find it above the opening by its width
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it out from all around with ease until it is removed
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a thread and cut it off.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If it is not prepared to be cut, except when you pierce the palpebra with a small incision, then it will be harmful to the patient in some way.</start_of_turn>
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the incision is large: then join it together with a suture: and take care of it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, it will not cause any harm from it.</start_of_turn
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The ointment restores itself and becomes flesh.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	If it is large and extends deep into the ear, turn the ear inwards and suspend the greater part with a hook: for it is not necessary to make an incision, and press upon it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	And if the palpebra is prolonged by an incision, it does no harm in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision with salt water: and care for the place with it which has become flesh, until the patient is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the care of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	The eyelids are greasy substances which are generated in the upper eyelid tissues: and most of them happen to children. And they weigh down the eyes of them, and cause tears to fall from them in the mornings, and they cannot see the sunlight because of this, because the tears run down their faces, and because of this the eyelids are always wet under the eyebrows, which are swollen from the inflation: and the prominence of the Axirnath is seen in the eye, and when you press on it with your fingers, you feel the Axirnath between your fingers.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the way to treat it is to put the patient's head in your lap
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a piece of linen, and prepare in it a hook, and make from that hook a circle according to the quantity which contains the Axirnath from all sides
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	And put it on the eye, and press with your fingers from all sides, so that the Axirnath is collected in the middle of the circle
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of it humidity with slippery ointment applied to the split, and do not make a split greater than that which is made in phlebotomy at depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Either the entire skin must be stripped off, until it reaches Axirnath, or from the fissures the latter proceeds from, following the shape of the white fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Either the entire skin must be stripped off, until it reaches Axirnath, or from the fissures the latter proceeds from, following the shape of the white fat.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If, however, Axirnath does not appear at the beginning of the fissure, you must add slightly in the fissure until Axirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract the fat as we have said before.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse the fat in vinegar and water, and place it on the place, and bind it with threads.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And from men there are some who anoint salt, and put it into the cavity of the fissure, so that it liquefies what remains of that moisture
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If, however, blood appears in the place of the clot, then care for it with cold compresses until it heals
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Regarding the treatment of the eye, that is, when the eyelids are softened, from which it results that the eye becomes red as it should not.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When in the eyelids of the eye hairs are added beyond their course under the natural hair, and are increased: then they harm the eye, and cause diseases such as excessive tears, and softening of the eyelids, and mucus, until it becomes the cause of the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And Ataxmir of the eye is treated in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp instruments, as is prescribed in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or Ataxmir is treated by incision and stitching.</start_of_turn>
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by needles, as I shall say.</start_of_turn
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must place the head of the patient in your lap.</start_of_turn>
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then grasp the lower eyelid with your left hand.</start_of_turn
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it is grasped, that is good.</start_of_turn
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: introduce the needle through the skin at the place where the lash hair originates, and pass the needle together with the thread, and bring the thread up through the skin near the hair roots, where the hair arises: and draw the thread upwards towards the eyebrow, and tie it securely.</start_of_turn
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find in the inner part of the eyelid under the added hair the fat that hangs down from the larger lacrimal gland to the smaller lacrimal gland.</start_of_turn
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then draw out the thread, and put under the eyelid a small piece of cotton wool or gauze: then mark over the eye with ink, so that it looks like the figure of a myrtle leaf.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	It is true that the figure must be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: for this varies in different people.</start_of_turn
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	And from this it is evident that the amount of excision which should be made from the eyelid is great, according to the amount that is softened by the eye.</start_of_turn
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then when the fat is found above two lines which you have marked, and you have reached from the larger lacrimal gland to the smaller lacrimal gland, make a single incision near the natural hair, as thick as the radius.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then strip off the entire skin.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then join together the two lips with a suture, with needle and fine thread: and drain the blood, and make fast what is superfluous from the threads above the two superciliums, with some useful material, if you wish to do so: or if not, do not care
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then remove the suture and thread for three days, or four: then care for it
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, remove the wound without suture, and care for it with oil, which will dry and harden it
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelids swell up at the sealing of the wound and its collection: but the future is better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	Such a way of treating was taught by the ancient Ataxmirans
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	It is true that there is concern over the infirm person, but this comes from a good operation, and not from fear
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method in Ataxmir is as follows: and it is that the sign on the eyelid should be like the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separate hooks, or joined together, according to the shape of this sign, then cut away what is superfluous with small scissors, according to this shape, with the equality of the incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If, however, it is not possible for you to hold the hook, and it is not equal: then grasp the point where the thread is, and insert it in the middle of the sign: and insert another thread near the greater lacrimal gland, and another thread near the smaller lacrimal gland: and join together the two threads with the equal length of the suture
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then elevate your hand equally high: and elevate the skin above that which is marked on the limb, as we have said.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then close the two lips of the wound with suture: and care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If indeed swelling occurs at the incision of your wound, or a tear of the wound: retain that swelling with earth, and with like things, from unguents sitting.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And whenever the eyelids also swell, so that their hair is twisted: convert their hair.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is necessary therefore that you use what we have said concerning the incision: but the suture of both is an artificial thing.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	As for care of Ataxmir with dogs.</start_of_turn
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is, that you cover the eye, and split the tear which is inside, according as I have said.</start_of_turn
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two incisions, or two small sticks under the lash: whose length is according to the length of the eye, and the width of them less than the width of the pupil: and I shall insert the thread at the extremities of both from both parts where you hold the thread.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then close both with a suture over that which is superfluous from the eye, and bind the two threads from both parts strongly, and let go of it every few days.</start_of_turn
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	The skin will therefore become strict, and will die, and will become black, until it falls away of itself.</start_of_turn
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If indeed it is delayed, then cut through it with scissors.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When the bone is firmly set, elevate the eyelids: and do not puncture the hair.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	This is the shape of two nails, which you make according to this figure and their quantity in length and breadth.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	About the elevation of the hair piercing in the eye with the needle
Caput XII.	Chapter XII
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in this is that you take a fine needle and introduce it through a fine silk thread, soft
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then gather its extremities and knot both knots with a fine knot: and let the length of the thread be one palm
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then make a second fine knot under this in a short space, and knot its extremities if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then put the patient's head in your lap, and let it rest close to the cheek so that the operation is evident: because the operation is slight, or even almost insignificant.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then introduce the needle with the thread under the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly, until you have pulled out the natural hair
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw out the hair up to the thread: and introduce into the thread the light of one, or two, or three hairs, not more
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand away with it, until the hair comes out with the thread in the eyelid with the natural hair
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If, however, you pull out the thread, and the hair does not come out with it: pull out the thread to the lower part, with the thread which you made in it, until the thread comes out from the upper hole, and you see the eye: then indeed pull out the thread and the needle: and close the eye: and keep it closed for two days, or three, until the hair has adhered to its place and has grown over the wound
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either associate with it a long hair from natural hair, and elevate it with it; or let it go, until it has elongated over space, and then elevate it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	If the hair is short, then either associate with it a long hair from natural hair, and elevate it with it; or let it go, until it has elongated over space, and then elevate it.
Caput XIII.	Of the care of the upper eyelid.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this occurs with the eye, it is called the Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	This care is either natural or accidental
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental care is thus done by the consolidation of a wound, or section, or cautery, and the like
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the mode of the operation in this is that you find the consolidation, and that you separate the lips, and put between them a piece of linen, and bind it, until it is healed
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And do not use in the care of this that which excites and contracts: for if you do this, the Alxatrati will deteriorate more than before: rather use those things which soften, such as chaff: and mix with water, in which barley is boiled, seed of flax: and oil of lard, which is liquefied with some oil: and apply it with the linen, and care for it
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your skill in the care of this is that you are able to concoct with every ingenuity, so that it does not solidify, according to the form which was in the beginning
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this care, which we have mentioned, is not except for some rectification of the Alxatrati, so that it does not regain the form of the place which was throughout
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Of the care of the Alxatrati which is done in the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkle or contraction upwards to the right and left
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 123.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	The lower part of the head is called the Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	It is natural and accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	It is caused by a wound, or a fracture, or a burn, or things like these
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way to perform the operation in this case is to take hold of the needle which has two threads, and pass it through the meat from the left tear duct to the right tear duct, until the thread comes out at the two extremities of the meat
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the meat upwards with the needle, and cut the vein with a broad blade.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If the outline of the eye returns to its proper position, it is good
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	If not, take a suture, and pass it through the wound, and tie it with the eye: and find two holes in the inner side of the eye, and let the two ends of the holes come out from two angles of the incision, until they meet and form an angle: and when they meet they will form the figure of the eye once more. And this is the Greek laudation letter
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	And remove the meat to the amount of its acute lower angle from the eye which follows the eye-lash
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	And join the separated parts together: sew them with a thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them as we have said, with soothing medicines and ointments, until they heal
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if the Alxatrati occurs from a wound, or a suture, or a burn: then you must find a flat wound under the eyelashes, even as before
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate the two lips with a liner as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And thus the conclusion of the discourse concerning the care of Alxatr [i.e. the surgeon] is that when he is above or below, his care in this operation is as it is prepared according to the form of Alxatr.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For there are many varieties in form: and a prudent artificer prepares the ingenuity in whatever way is possible for him, until he brings the figure back to a natural form, or almost so, and even the patient himself, according as it is convenient for him from the operation and the instruments in various arrangements
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Concerning the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva, or the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.
