Whenever such a consolidation happens to many people, it is like the consolidation of the upper eyelid with the white of the eye, and it hinders its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	You must therefore introduce the extremity of the radius under the eyelid, and lift it up: or stretch it out with a hook: then cut through the adhesion with a fine spatula, which should not be as acute as the incision of the spatula, but rather blunt and shallow: so that it does not irritate the patient during the operation, and that it may be easily withdrawn, and that the eye may return to its natural shape: and that the adhesion should be entirely healed
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour water and salt into the eye, with water washing it out: or instill it from a sieve made from millet seeds boiled in water
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate the lip from the eye with a liner of linen: and place above the eye lanolin infused with alum or wool: and on the third day remove the sieve and the solids, until it is healed
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On the incision of the nail and the prominence of meat near the tear-ducts.
Caput XVI.	On the incision of the nail and the prominence of meat near the tear-ducts.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You know that the nail is according to two modes.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is fleshy: and is similar to soft wax, thick and brittle
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not fleshy, resembling frozen white moisture: which, when it touches iron, or when you try to grasp it with a hook, breaks off and does not remain in it
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both of these kinds do not begin until from the greater tear-duct, until it has proceeded somewhat, until it covers the useful thing, and excludes light and movement of the eye
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the manner of working in its incision is: as you place your diseased head in your lap
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open its eyes, and lift its eyelid with your hand
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather the nail with a hook a few times, and stretch it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take the needle, and pierce the meat through the hair of the horse, and blood, or fat: and let the thread be strong, and double the end of the needle at the base, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and pierce the nail with the needle, and ligate the nail with the thread, and stretch the nail upwards: and remove the skin surrounding the nail which follows the pupil, as if you were scraping the nail with the skin until its extremity
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	And then cut the rest in the root of the tear-duct with a fine sponge, or with small forceps: and let the natural meat of the tear-duct go, so that it does not impede the course of the tears from its incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	When the finger is stretched out with only one (digit), or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it should be scraped with a soft sponge, the shape of which is as follows.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	Take care that the sponge does not touch the tough tunic of the cornea, and that you make an incision in it, and perforate the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then, after the incision, pour into the eye some powdered salt, or extract it from barley, and leave it in for another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	And take care of it until it is healed
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the finger is neither nerve nor bone, and does not bend inwards, and does not swell, then this kind of finger heals in many ways with the doctors, and heals as I have said before
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish to make an incision, then open the eye of the patient, and take out the tough inner membrane, soft, thin and acute, according to this form
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And cut off the fingernail above the root with sharpness.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it is becoming rare and crumbling, and has burst in the root, then pour out from your hour glass into the eye from barley, or from red barley, or powdered salt: and anoint the eye until tomorrow
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat the operation until it is completely healed
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Except that there is a soft callous in the eye: then leave it in and care for the callous until it is healed
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation above with care until it is healed
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	The prominence of the tear sac, if it is causing great pain in the eye, is to be grasped with one finger, and cut off a part of it: do not make the incision at the end, lest you cause the flow of tears to be blocked
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then stop the bleeding from the tear-gland with a red sponge, or made from sponge-grass, until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	After the excision of the gland and the natural elevation in the eye
Caput XVII.	From the excision of the gland and the elevation of the tissue in the eye
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes in the eyes of men there is a red substance composed of blood, or superposed, which covers the pupil, approaches or tightens over the eyelashes, and perhaps turns the eyelashes outwards: and it is absorbed like the dust of roses
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And there is also an operation for it, that you put your hand over his head.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes, and gather all the flesh with the nails that are convenient for that: and hold that with one hand, or grasp it with your hand.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh at first, until you have finished all of it with the chisel
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And burn away from the eye, so that you do not damage it during the operation: and make your incision as we said in the excision of the nail: or with fine scissors, with which you collect the fat, as it will appear after this head
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When your incision is complete, and you have removed all the gland, then put the eye out from salt that is ground together: or distill into it a powder of red, and things like these from corrosive physicians: and put over the eye a foreign cover with white wool or linen: to prevent from the heat.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If anything remains of the gland, and you dominate the hot blood, and wait for the swelling to subside: then let go of the eye, and care for it with that which will settle the swelling
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat over it with the operation, until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	Proceed in like manner as when meat is added which has happened in the eye from this sort.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	Proceed in like manner as when meat is added which has happened in the eye from this sort.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	In like manner as when meat has been added and has occurred in the eye of this kind.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	The veins which are red and cover the eye, and which prevent the liquid from operating: and they weaken the eye with the length of the days.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore, first of all, you must consider whether the eye in which there is Sebel is strong and there is no other injury in it except for the Sebel: then collect the Sebel from it
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is fitting to place your head on your lap
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those veins with one hook or two, according to your prudence: and let the hook be of fine wire, like a double thread, or two hooks be graduated in one body, like this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect with fine forceps those veins with caution, and drain blood an hour after an hour, until you have removed the veins from the eye and they have dissolved: and take care not to damage the eye with the tips of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation be in the middle of the day before the sun, and be firm in your operation so that you do not cut anything except for the veins
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then instill in the eye a little oil, or blood: so that its sharpness may restore what remains of the Sebel.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	If it is not possible to collect the whole in this hour, then plaster the eye with wax, which will soothe the eye's pain. And send it away for a few days until the pain has subsided: and keep it away from a warm compress. And then repeat over it again in the same manner until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	This is the form of the shears.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	On the reduction of the swelling of the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Doctors call the swelling of the nose "Fistula," which they cure with cautery or with acute medicine burning, as the case demands
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no wisdom in that: except that you find a boil on the swelling near its origin, and you extract all the moisture that is in it and pus, until the bone is clean
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When the bone is thus extracted, and the cavity is washed, or blackened, then fill it again with the instrument whose form is this
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	This is called the "Asperation of the head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Make it of iron, and let its head be round like an azure, which is pierced with the point of a lime, or with the point of an awl, or with a fine puncture: and place it upon the place of the corrupted bone
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then pull it out between your fingers, and you press your hand near, until you know that the corruption is gone: and do it quickly
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with medicinal astringents.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If thus the place is consolidated, and there is formed in it flesh, and the swelling subsides: and there remains for forty days, and it does not rise again, and there is no inflammation, and no accident occurs in it: then you know that it is healed
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	If not, then it is not in the ingenuity of that man, except to reduce the fistula to the opening of the nose, according to this fashion.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	If not, then it is not in the ingenuity of that man, except to reduce the fistula to the opening of the nose, in this fashion.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place that over the bone itself: and let it be close to the lacrimal gland: and stretch out your hand from the eye a little.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then turn your hand with the thumb, until it penetrates the bone, and feel that it is painful: by this you will know that the air has escaped from it, when you keep your hand over your nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore, then restore the place with the physicians who are stifling, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When the flesh has healed, and the place has hardened: then the matter which flowed outwards returns to the nose: so it is easier to do that over the painful area.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	¶ Regarding the reduction of the swelling of the eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye swells completely, and does not yield to any treatment, neither by reduction nor by medication: then it is necessary to dissolve the swelling: then perform a bloodletting: afterwards place poultices in the cavity without making an incision, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then place over the eye a unguent made from acacia, and aloe, and oil, and gum arabic.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye above over the dressing with many sponges.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the way of making the sponges is: that you take fine sponges, many, and double every sponge over four: make many from them: then place one over another, according to the quantity which the eye needs: then bind over them with strong leather
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	Repeat the procedure with the stomach using suction without incision.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Repeat the procedure with the stomach, and keep the eye closed for a day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If the ligament is again softened, it must be tightly bound: then remove the ligament after a day and night, as we have said before
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If blood therefore escapes from the eye again after the application of the ligature, it is good: but if not, then repeat the application of the dressing, the sponges, the tight dressing, and the suction, until the patient is healed.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Regarding the incision of the abdominal cavity.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a disruption occurs in the abdominal cavity, then it will protrude and proceed outside the eyelids like a grain of sand, and will be formed like a man due to that: then it is necessary to make an incision in that place. The operation in this case is as follows: and it is that you insert a needle into the root of the intestine from the lower part to the upper part
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then insert another needle where there is a doubled thread from the lacrimal part, and make it pass through: and remove the first needle according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then pierce the place of the doubled thread, and bind it around the part of the intestine with the needle: and tighten it much.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then remove the needle, and place above the eye a lanolin swab in albumin: and leave it there until the thread is cast out with the intestine
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the eye with it, which comforts it, until the wound is healed
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And when the intestine is tightly bound from all around with a circle of cloth, until it has added the eye a great prominence.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then it is pierced with a fine needle which reaches the depth of the eye, and moisture of albumin flows out, and the eye descends, and immediately fills: then bind it up until it is healed.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	Then it is pierced with a fine needle which reaches the depth of the eye, and moisture of albumin flows out, and the eye descends, and immediately fills: then bind it up until it is healed.
Caput XXII.	Then it is pierced with a fine needle which reaches the depth of the eye, and moisture of albumin flows out, and the eye descends, and immediately fills: then bind it up until it is healed.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This ailment which is called Alcomnati, is not simply an inflammation, but a healing which has gathered in the eye, similar to descending water, and is not the ailment itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the way of dealing with it is to make the patient sit over a prepared seat, or directly
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take hold of his head with your hands from two parts, and move it around until you see the healing return to the lower part of his eye
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then tighten it up, and do not let it descend, and open the pupil: and the patient will see as well as before: and if it does not descend further, you know that it is water
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if the healing of the eye is not prepared to descend with that which we have said, then make the patient sit between your hands
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a fine needle and pierce with it above the corneal membrane at the circumference where it joins the cornea in a crown, until the healing comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When it has come out, then instill in the eye lukewarm water in which honey has been mixed: or water in which barley flour and honey have been boiled: then treat with the rest of the treatment until it is healed
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	When it has come out, then instill in the eye lukewarm water in which honey has been mixed: or water in which barley flour and honey have been boiled: then treat with the rest of the treatment until it is healed
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	I have spoken of ten kinds of water in the process of irrigation, which are declared and explained by the expert; take them according to the soundness of the patient.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then you must make the patient sit with his shoulder blades against your hands, opposite the light, near the heel: and bind his eye securely, and tighten it: then take hold of the eyelid of his eye which has the water in it, with your right hand, if the eye which has the water is the left, or your left hand if the eye which has the water is the right.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take your right hand with the thumb, if the eye is left: or your left hand if the eye is right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the thumb at the crown near the apparent white of the smaller lacrimal gland: then push the thumb with force: and you will know when the thumb has gone through to the bottom of the eye socket
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the thumb should reach the depth of the eye socket, measuring the space from the pupil to the end of the black part: which is the cornea of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see this in the pupil of the eye, because of the clarity of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the thumb until it reaches the place where the water is
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then push the lower eyelid downwards one after the other.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If, therefore, water comes down immediately, then the patient should shut his eye immediately and the thumb will be in his eye
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest for a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If water comes down again, then remove the thumb once more, except when the thumb is coming out
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When the limb hangs down and does not rise up: then extract the foreign body easily and you will gradually restore your hand.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve in water something from clear salt crystals: and wash with it when the eye is closed.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place over the eye the whole wad of cotton, or wool soaked in rose-water, and alum: and bind with it the healthy eye
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	We, however, and those who are with us in this time, place upon it a firm compress with alum.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If it does not yield to the foreign body at the entrance of the eye because of its hardness, because it is from a man whose eye is hard and cold: then you must take a sponge, which is called Alberid, whose shape is like this
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Fetch the sponge with the hand itself only, and do not touch the hand with the thumb: and do not do anything except to put the foreign body in its proper place under the eye
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the foreign body, as we have said
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And in addition to that, prepare a soft bed in the center of the room, on which he may lie with his face downwards in a dark room: and prevent all movements, and from coughing: and give him food that soothes his nature: and do not move his head to the right or to the left at all.</start_of_turn>
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And keep the dressing in accordance with its custom until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then take it out of that dark room and let him see: and make him drink something.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the dressing until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And do not do this at the hour of treatment, or immediately after the incision: rather do it when others are there: because water ascends quickly through a wide opening
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If, however, the boil becomes hardened: then it is necessary to drain the eye before the seventh day. And rectify that with what rests upon it that sits upon the boil until it subsides: then truly to make use of the eye itself, and place over its face an oral bandage which regulates the use of the eye for a few days, even though it exists in the dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	The eye must be gradually withdrawn from the room and returned to its place.</start_of_turn>
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	Know that in the dark one must not be excused from vision for a long time: then indeed he will hear of the operation.</start_of_turn>
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed it happened to us some from Alayrach, who said that in Alayrach a magdan was perforated by a needle, through which water was sucked out.</start_of_turn>
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	Truly, no one in our land has done this: neither have I read of it in any ancient book: and it is possible that it is new.</start_of_turn
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	These are the forms of the demons which appear from the magda, as they rest upon that which they know not.</start_of_turn
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be of their own air: and their extremities be like those of a triangle with the acute angle.</start_of_turn
Formae magda.	The forms of the magda.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	Of the care of the newly born flesh in the nose.</start_of_turn
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIII.</start_of_turn
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	When various meats are born in the nose of a carnas, from which there is something that is assimilated by many scorpions' feet: and from this there is a cancerous flesh, a stone, of a dusky colour: and from this is what is soft flesh, not of a dusky colour.</start_of_turn
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	If any flesh from these carnivorous animals is soft, not fraudulent, nor cancerous, you must make the sick man sit with his hands opposite you, open his mouth, and expel the tongue from his flesh: then draw them out to the exterior, and cut off what you have apprehended from them with a fine, acute scalpel from one side, until you know that the whole flesh has been excised.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	If anything remains of that from whose excision is impossible: then cut that with a fine instrument easily, until nothing remains of it.</start_of_turn>
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If blood should dominate it, or a thick clot adhere: then oppose it by that which is appropriate: or that from malignant clots, then cauterize it until the blood is severed, and remove all the flesh.</start_of_turn>
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then expel it through the nose after the incision of the vein, and water, or liquid.</start_of_turn>
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If indeed the nose is opened, and moisture proceeds from it up to the palate, then you know that he is already healed.</start_of_turn>
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If indeed moisture does not penetrate, according to what is appropriate, then you know that flesh has been born within the upper bones of the nose, which does not come out with the incision of the instrument.</start_of_turn
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Therefore it is necessary to insert a thread of fine caliber which has some bulk, and to knot it in such a way that there are many knots in it: and put between every knot the quantity of digit, or less: and the patient shall blow out one end of the thread through the nose with the greatest possible force: and he shall expel the stench until it reaches the heel, and depart from his guttur.</start_of_turn>
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And many do the like of this like the young boys in the schools: and it is easy for him who wishes it.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place two extremities of the boy, one which projects above the nose, and the other which remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then secure the flesh with sutures at the points which are in the boy's flesh.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is again with the knots of the boy.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then draw out the thread: and place in the nose after the bleeding has ceased a little of the unguent which you drank with the Egyptian ointment: do this for three days, or more, until the ointment has eaten up all that remains of the flesh
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then place in the end of the matter in the nose a lead cannula for a few days, until he is healed.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If, however, treatment is needed which exceeds this, use something else.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For a head injury make a cautery, with which oil is distilled, and other medicines in the nose, do this of silver, or of brass: which is like the nut of the fennel, opened like a conch shell: and its passage is like that of the reed
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed cannula, like a tube.</start_of_turn>
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the tube of the instrument for making a head injury be full, detected: which has a handle at its back, with which you grasp it, when you heat it in oil, or when you wish to take from wax, and from fluxes.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	This is the form of the instrument.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	Of the care of the eye of the nose.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXV.	Day 25.</start_of_turn
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Many times the eye of the nose is born in the extremity of the nose of Thelus, and it grows large, and increases with the days, until the wound has become like its aspect.</start_of_turn
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And therefore it is necessary, that in the beginning of its appearance, it should be cut through in order to evacuate its entirety.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place above it either a cautery or a burning medicine which is placed in its place
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If, however, its incision is delayed until it has become large, then consider whether it is a stone, hard or brown in color, with little sensation: then do not touch it with the iron; for the tumor is cancerous.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For there are many waters which issue from the incision of tumors, and which cause great harm to the body which had them
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	If, however, the tumor is soft to the touch, not brown in color, and the waters which issue from its incision are possible throughout its entirety, then evacuate the sick person and cut it without fear, without pain: and care for the place where it was excised until it is healed
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	As for the suture of the nose, the lip, and the ear
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You know that when a solution of continuity happens in cartilaginous matters, it offers little support in that operation, except in some people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary, therefore, when anything happens from that, that you consider whether there is a wound which has been made with blood: and then join the edges of the wound with a suture: then care for it until it is healed
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the continuous solution of the lips has already been separated, and each part is sound: then it is necessary to scour all the parts from the skin outwards until they bleed again.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then join the lips with a suture, and bind them, and sprinkle above it dragon's blood and balsam: and place above the powder a plaster plug, and some other solid plaster: and leave it bound for two or three days
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then solve it yourself, and move the medicine: and let it go, until the threads are severed by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the unguent, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	As for the way of stitching, it is such that it joins the solution of continuity, or with a weight, as we say in the stitching of the belly: or join the solution with the thread, as you have been told.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	Concerning the extraction of lip knots.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people suffer pain in the insides of their lips because of hard bumps resembling seeds of herbs. Some of these are small, and some are large.</start_of_turn
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore it is necessary to cover the lips, and find over every bump of it, and suspend it with a thread, and cut it away from all around.</start_of_turn
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place after the incision with dry wool, until the blood is clotted.</start_of_turn
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then bandage it with vinegar, and care for the place with it, where there is a styptic, until the wound is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	Concerning the incision of the flesh of a newly-formed tooth on the gum.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.</start_of_turn
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Many are born on the gum, flesh added by the ancients, whom they call abuluss.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore it is necessary to suspend it with a thread: or grasp it with forceps, and cut it at the root of its socket, and let the blood run, or the pus go out.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place upon the site of the wound a piece of beeswax, or other adhesive powders, and soak them.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If the flesh returns to its place after treatment, which often happens, then repeat the incision a second time, and cauterize it: for it will not return after cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	Regarding the tooth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	When they gather on the surfaces of the tooth from the inside and outside, and between the gums there are rough and hard coatings, and when they decay, and the dentine becomes soft and greenish, until corruption reaches the gum, and inflammation of the teeth results.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	It is necessary therefore to keep the hand steady between your thumbs, and to place the head of the instrument in your mouth, and to grasp the tooth and the socket, where you see the coatings, like sand: until something remains from it, and do the same with black pigment, and greenishness, and yellowness, and other things until they are gone.</start_of_turn
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If therefore the thing which is in the tooth from the beginning of the treatment is removed, that is good: and if not, then repeat the treatment on the third day, and the fourth, and the fifth, until you have finally completed the study of that which you desire.</start_of_turn>
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And you know that teeth need different rasps of various forms, many figures: according to the preparation for your operation: because the rasp which files the tooth from the lower part is different from the rasp which files between the teeth, according to other figures.</start_of_turn
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these figures of rasps are prepared for you, which you will find.</start_of_turn
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	Chapter XIX.</start_of_turn
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	The teeth must be cured of their pain with all possible skill, and afterwards their eradication is to be aimed for.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	There is no remedy for it [tooth pain] which does not vanish when the tooth is eradicated: for its substance is lofty; except when there is no other remedy to be had, then it is permitted that the sick man eradicate it, that it may harden, and that he may be certified by thee that the tooth is painful
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Many, indeed, deceive the sick with their pain and assert that it is in the tooth itself and eradicate it: but the pain does not vanish until the diseased tooth is eradicated.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we do not see that it [tooth pain] departs from the operation of phlebotomy.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When it is certified by thee that the tooth is painful itself, then it is permitted that you sacrifice around the tooth with sponges, in which there is some skill, until the gum is separated from all sides: then move the tooth with thy fingers, or with fine forceps at first slowly, until you have broken it
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place there [the forceps] in a great location well: and the head of the sick man between thy knees: for it is well held thus, because it does not move: then draw out the tooth according to its right, so that you do not break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not come out, then take some of those instruments and introduce it under it from all sides with ease, and move it, as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If the tooth is perforated or corroded: then it is permitted that you fill that hole with wool: and string it with the extremity of a fine radius, so that it does not break in the hour of your constriction over it with the forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is permitted that you should take great care with the scarring around the gum from all parts much
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	Be strong and resolute, lest you break yourself, and let a part of you remain, so that you may depart from the infirmity greater than the pain which was in it at first.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	Do not attempt that which you know not, for phlebotomists in their frenzy often do harm rather than good. Be courageous in its extirpation, but let us administer what we have narrated
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	Many indeed make their wounds grow worse by touching great illnesses of men, for the greater part of them is liable to break, and leave roots of themselves behind, or to draw out the whole with some bones of the jaw: as we have been told.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then it is to be closed with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If there is a discharge of blood from the place (for many indeed thus happen), then there is something from the vessel there, and implement with it the place: and if not, cauterize it if it does not suffice to restore the vessel.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The forceps which are used to grasp the tooth in the first place should be of fine form, their handles long, their thumbs short, their bodies broad, so that they do not bend when pressure is put on them when they are pressed against the tooth: they should be like strong fingers, until when they are bound to the tooth, they do not bite the tooth itself, neither do they bend: the handles should be short, and they should be made of iron, or of well-fashioned steel, with directed handles, and in their handles there should be teeth, some of which are retained in some way, and which bind the constriction loosely, strongly
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And when the handles are of such a shape as the beak of a bird which is called a ciconia, and are strong, there are strong constrictions.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	On the eradication of teeth, and the extraction of fractured bones of the jaw
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 1.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When the tooth remains at the root, and breaks something, then it is necessary that you place butter over the place of the tooth for one or two days, until the place is softened: then introduce into the cavity a sponge or forceps: the extremities of which absorb the pulp which is called ciconia.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	This is the form of the forceps.</start_of_turn>
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Their extremities are made like a file or like an awl.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If, therefore, they do not yield to these forceps, then it is necessary that you place the jaw over the root, and remove the whole flesh, and introduce an instrument which is called a small spatula, which is shaped like this.</start_of_turn
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	The handle of the instrument should be short and broad: and it should not be wet, lest it break.</start_of_turn
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If the root comes out through that, it is good: and if not, it is necessary to bite with these instruments again.</start_of_turn
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The first triangle of the extremity has some thickness.</start_of_turn
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The second triangle of the extremity is thin.</start_of_turn
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It is also used with this instrument which has two branches, which has this shape.</start_of_turn
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and materials which are necessary for the reason of the teeth.</start_of_turn
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	It is also necessary to bite with this instrument which absorbs a large bone, of this shape, triangular extremity rotated, which has some thickness, so that it does not break: and it should not be wet.</start_of_turn
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	Know that the instruments for teeth are many: and like the rest of the instruments, they do not all work in the same way. And a skillful craftsman, skilled in his art, will himself discover the appropriate instrument for each operation and its related ailments.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	For since the ailments for which instruments are needed are diverse, the ancients did not speak of a single instrument for all of them
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, the jawbone is fractured from the mandible, or from any other bone of the mouth, or if it becomes putrefied: then one must examine the area carefully with the instruments and forceps that I mentioned in the extraction of teeth, and handle it with care, for its form is like this
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	And let there be something of length in it, so that it may be tied up or held with the bone, and that it does not slip away and break, until the bone has been extracted: and restore the place with the physicians who are suitable for that.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If, however, there is a small putrefaction in the bone, then remove it from its putrefaction and care for it, until it is healed.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Concerning the closure of teeth that protrude over others.
Caput XXXII.	End of book.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth protrude abnormally from their natural course, a wound is made by that which gives them that shape: and especially when it happens in women and girls, because of their soft gums.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary therefore to take care of this
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if a tooth has been born after another tooth and has not been positioned, or if it is possible to close it, or to file it down: then extract it: and if it is connected with another tooth, then cut it away with this instrument which has this shape
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small face, and is made of iron, with acute extremities.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your incision be such as you would make in many days, because of the hardness of the teeth, and that it does not break through the teeth of others.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, there is an exposure of the edges of the teeth: then ligate the teeth with a file made of iron, whose form is like this.</start_of_turn>
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	It is all of iron, and its handle has small points like a file: like a file with which the tooth is ground little by little in many days with ease, so that it does not break through the tooth, and falls out: then soften it, and afterwards polish it with some abrasives.</start_of_turn
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If there is a tooth from which a part has broken off, and has wounded the tongue: then it is necessary to ligate it also, until the sharpness of that fracture has gone, and it is equal: and flatten it, so that it does not wound the tongue, or corrupt the speech.</start_of_turn>
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	¶ As for the reposition of teeth with gold wires.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When it happens that the front teeth have concussion and displacement from a blow, or in a case: and it cannot be held together by the teeth themselves so that it does not fall out: and if swelling appears with blood clots, and treatment does not suffice: then wisdom dictates that they be bound with gold wire: because silver is easily tarnished and putrefies after a few days: but gold never changes.</start_of_turn
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the wire be of moderate thickness and strength according to the quantity that it can grasp between the teeth.</start_of_turn
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of the reposition is that you take hold of the wire, and pass through a loop of it between two healthy teeth: then you tie it with two extremities of the wire between the teeth that are loose, whether one or more, until you have secured it until you reach the other healthy tooth.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Repeat the procedure until you reach the part from which you commenced. Then grasp your hand with caution and wisdom, until it ceases to move forward: and establish your constriction as you would string a thread at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not slip away.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Repeat the procedure until you reach the starting point. Then grasp your hand cautiously and with wisdom until it ceases to move forward: and establish your constriction as you would string a thread at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not slip away.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it is dissolved or if it breaks, string them together with another thread and keep them stable for the whole time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is the form of teeth, and the figure of the rotation of two healthy teeth and two moving teeth, like water
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And when it has happened that one tooth or two have fallen out due to an abscess or other cause in their places, and they have returned as we have said, and remain: this does not happen except by an artificer, a prudent and experienced person.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And when some bone or cartilage has been adjusted: and it is made like a tooth in shape, and is placed in its place, from which the tooth was extracted and stringed as we have said: and it remains, and serves its purpose for a long time
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Regarding the incision of the ligament which happens under the tongue, and which hinders speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	When this ligament which is under the tongue happens naturally, as it is when a human is born, or accidentally, due to an injury which has healed over
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation in this case is to open the mouth of the patient in your hand, and elevate the tongue: then cut through that nerve of the ligament throughout its width, until the tongue is freed from its retention
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there be anything hard and nodular in it, and if that be from the consolidation of a wound: then project into that the hook, and find that by its breadth, until you cut through the ligament, and the nodulation will be dissolved.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Take heed, that there be no fissure in the depth of the flesh, and cut through the artery there, and blood flow will be restored.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then collect in the wound the residue of the incision with rose-water, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then put under the tongue a bandage of linen, which will hold the patient firm throughout the night: so that it will not solidify again
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If blood flow should happen to be restored, then put upon the place a wet compress.</start_of_turn>
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If blood boils, then cauterize the place with a blunt cautery, which is appropriate for this: then care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	Of the extraction of the ranula which is under the tongue.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 5.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	When there happens under the tongue a swelling which assimilates the small ranula, prohibiting the tongue from its natural operation: and perhaps it increases so much, that it fills the mouth.</start_of_turn
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	The operation in this is, that you open the mouth of the patient at the root of the tongue: and consider the swelling.</start_of_turn
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If there be blood of a dark or reddish color, hard, which the patient does not sense: do not touch it, for it is cancer.</start_of_turn
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it inclines to whiteness, where there is moisture, then project into it the hook, and cut through it with a fine scalpel, and free it from all around.</start_of_turn
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If blood flows upon thee in the hour of thy operation, then place upon it a dry sponge, until the blood is severed: then return to thy operation, until thou hast extracted it with its complement.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	And bind it with vinegar and salt: and care for the rest with such treatment as is fitting for this, until it is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	Concerning the treatment of the two wounds of the amygdala.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XVI.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	When they happen between the gullet of the gods, that is, the glands which resemble almonds, which happen outside: and which are called two amygdalae: when you have cured them with what we mentioned in the discourse, and they do not heal, then consider them
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If there is a hard wound, of a dark color, with little sensation: then do not touch it with iron
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is red in color, and its root is large: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing the flow of blood, rather leave it alone, until it is healed
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then you will either perforate it: or it will rupture by itself
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is white in color, round, and its root is thin: then you must cut it off.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation in this is as you consider before your operation, if the wound of it has grown cold peacefully complete, or if there is imminent decrease: then do this: make the patient sit with his head towards the sun: and open the wound of him, and take hold of the flesh between your hands, and pull the tongue downwards with an instrument, which has this shape
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Make from silver, or from air, which is subtle like a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When thus you have said the word and the limb is exposed, and falls upon the part you wish to reach: then grasp the hook and hold it in safety, and draw it outwards as much as you can, without tearing anything from the tunics.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then proceed with the instrument whose form follows this.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	Like scissors: truly the extremities of these are bent inwards, so that the opening of each is directly opposite the other at an angle: where care must be taken lest it should slip from the iron or be soaked in alum.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If however this instrument is not present, then proceed with the sponge, whose form is like this
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	It is acute from one part, not from the other part.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have incissated one side of the flesh, incissate the other according to this same kind of incision
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then let the patient gargle with cold water, or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If however blood flows from him, make him gargle with water in which coriander seeds are boiled: or leaves of myrtle, and things like these from sponges: until the bleeding ceases: then care for him until he is healed.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And when there are left in the gullet other abscesses, besides the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Proceed with these in the same way as for the two tonsils.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And indeed I have cured a woman of an abscess which was in her throat, which was bringing her to a fainting spell, with little sense, because she was swallowing with difficulty: and the woman breathed with difficulty through a narrow passage, and I forbade her from eating and drinking: and she died within one or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the after-pulse will ascend only as much as two branches emitted, until they go beyond two nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	And the after-pulse will ascend only as much as two branches emitted, until they go beyond two nostrils.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	And then I draw it out, and from that part is a great portion taken out
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	And then I cut it off at the root of the nose
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	And then I do the same for the other nostril.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	And then I open its mouth, and press its tongue: and afterwards I fix the hook in the after-pulse: then I cut off a part of it, and there does not flow much blood from it: it is absolutely like the gut of a woman, and immediately starts to drink water, and then accepts food
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	It does not cease to cut from that after-pulse for a long time: and the after-pulse follows the place from which I cut, until it becomes prolonged and joins with it.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I devised, and cauterized the after-pulse between the gut
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	It remained from the addition: then I went away from the place, and I do not know what God did with it after me
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the incision of a small after-pulse.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 7
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When catarrus descends to the lower part and there is an after-pulse, and it is long: then it is called a perpendicular one: and if it is in the lower part large and round, then it is called a great one
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is cured with what we said in the explanation, and the cure does not suffice: and you see that the after-pulse has become soft and quiescent from it: then it is necessary to cut it off
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And whatever is gathered round that is round, and has no length, and is blood-stained, or of a dusky colour, or black, and has no sensation: in such a case it is necessary to make an incision of it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	And there is fear of the disease upon the patient.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.
