It is necessary therefore when you are performing the cure as I have mentioned from the white, and of its length, so that you make the patient sit forward facing the sun: and you will grasp his tongue with an instrument whose passage was mentioned before, and fix the flesh in one place, and draw it downwards: and cut through it with one of the two instruments which I mentioned in the incision of two abscesses.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you do not cut from that, except that which is added beyond the natural limit without addition
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut from that more, you will wound the bowels and the speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	And then after the incision use what we mentioned in the incision of two abscesses: and care for him until he is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however the patient returns from the incision: then it is necessary that you use your skill in cauterization without fear and without hesitation.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the method of cauterization in this is not with anything except with acute water: and it is that you place the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	And then grasp his tongue with the instrument which we mentioned before.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	And then take from the water which I mentioned before and mix with burnt charcoal, and place it not thick, neither sparse, and touch it from that side which has the concave shape of this instrument
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	So that its extremities are in that side which holds the medicine in a concave way, like the concave shape of the radius of a conch shell
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	Place the instrument with the medicine above the wound: and let the patient lie with his side open, so that the discharge from his mouth may flow out from within the medicine, so that it does not descend to the gut of the patient, and cause him pain.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.</start_of_turn>
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first touch it over the wound for the quantity of half an hour, until you see that it has become softened, and rest the biting pain of the medicine.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take hold of the limb, and cover it with the medicine over the end of the radius, and inflate the limb with medicine, and insert the radius into the cannula above, until the limb adheres to the wound.</start_of_turn
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times, until you complete what you wish concerning the cautery of the vein.</start_of_turn>
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then remove the medicine: for it itself will dry and fall off in three days, or four.</start_of_turn
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	And if you think that the medicine has not been digested, repeat it: and after the cautery, remove the surrounding skin of the vein with the finger, and soak it in butter, and bandage it with that which is around it from the medicine: and cool it with cold water.</start_of_turn
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And care for the outside with stitches, and for the inside with gargles, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Thus is this kind of treatment safer than an incision and longer lasting in fear.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And when the wound is healed even with the subtlest of cautery and incision: it is healed by fumigation, according to this method.</start_of_turn
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamine, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and sassafras, and chamomile, and wormwood, and similar herbs: and mix them all together, or some of them in a pot, and immerse them in vinegar, and boil: and cover the pot with a lid: and put a hole in the middle of the pot, above which is made a concave instrument according to this method.</start_of_turn
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let air or metal enter: and the extremity is introduced into the cavity containing the pomegranate, until the vapor ascends to the upper opening of the cannula, until the opening is obscured by much.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over the same [procedure] several times, until it heals.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, do not perform this treatment in the beginning of an attack of inflammation.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	The procedure is useful only in a cold inflammation: and it must not be performed except when the inflammation has subsided.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If however this instrument is not present, then take a needle and make a hole in the extremity and introduce cork or resin: so that it does not burn the bone: because the cork or resin hinders the vapor from burning the bone: and this is a good treatment with safety.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	Regarding the extraction of thorns and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many things adhere to the throat, such as bones of fish or thorns.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	It is necessary therefore to extract what is seen to have fallen into the throat, after having previously drawn the tongue with an instrument at the angle of the jaw, and to declare that it is in the throat.</start_of_turn
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what is not seen but is hidden in the throat, it is necessary to make the patient vomit before food is eaten in the stomach.</start_of_turn
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps therefore it will be discharged through vomiting.</start_of_turn
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the patient swallows a piece of poppy seed, or the root of licorice, or swallows a piece of dry bread: or grasps a piece of dry sea sponge and binds it with a thread, then swallows it.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When the limb approaches the place where the bones or spines are extracted, it is then driven out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If it does not come out spontaneously as we have said: then use an instrument of lead according to this fashion.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the radius of a bean, and at its end there must be a curvature, which intrudes into its gut with ease: and it must have its head elevated above
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	Beware of its touch to the epiglottis, that it does not cause him to cough, and drive with it bone, or spine, or the doctor himself must introduce it with his hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But that the patient should introduce it himself: this is better: because of his knowledge of the place of the annexed thing: and he drives downwards, or pulls his hand upwards with the instrument, the whole thing according to the quantity that is prepared for him, until it comes out
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Of the extraction of the blood vessel.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the bleeding vessel is being treated with that which I have mentioned in the treatise on the treatment of wounds by the hands of doctors, and it does not stop, then consider in the belly of the patient at the root of the tongue, or behind the tongue after you have withdrawn the tongue with the instrument that I mentioned.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If your hand slips upon the bleeding vessel, grasp it with a small clamp, or with fine forceps from the center
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If this is not possible with these: then take a curved needle, and introduce it into the belly of the patient near the gut: then introduce the needle into the cavity of the needle with burning iron with fire
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this several times: and the patient should abstain from all water for the whole day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then he shall take a full measure of cold water and open his mouth wide with it: and he shall lick his own bone with it, and swallow nothing from it: and he shall drink water an hour after the other with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	The bloodsucker is like him who feels the water falling from his hand.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if he does not go away when we tell him, then we must fumigate the patient with mice, or with a sponge as an instrument which I mentioned in the fumigation of the wound
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, for it itself goes away.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the mode of operation in fumigation is that you take a vessel in which there are dates with fire: and the vessel be covered with a cover, in the middle of which is a hole: and make in that hole the end of the instrument.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then he throws the fumigation and places the patient's bone at the end of the tube and closes the bone, so that it does not escape the fumigation, until you know that the fumigation has gone away from the bloodsucker
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the bloodsucker immediately goes away.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	And if it does not go away, then repeat the fumigation many times
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient can tolerate the sitting position, and he can eat onions and garlic, and he must not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary therefore that he go away with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the fashion of the instrument with which the bloodsucker is drawn out from the gut when it falls upon the wound.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like pincers, thus: except that it has that curvature which enters into the gut
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich, which is called a ciconia, in which there is a roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	And concerning the opening of abscesses, their section, and their care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.</start_of_turn>
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	Abcesses are of various kinds, depending on the nature of the cause, for there are many causes of abscesses: and they differ in their perforation and their section in two ways.</start_of_turn>
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One kind of abscess is that which arises from humidity.</start_of_turn
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	The other kind is that which arises from the body itself.</start_of_turn
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an abscess which arises in the head is different from that which arises in the belly: and an abscess which arises in a fleshy part is different from that which arises at a joint. And each one of these has its own judgement according to its operation.</start_of_turn
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	Some abscesses do not need to be perforated until after the decay of the matter and the completion of its process: and others need to be perforated while they are still raw and have not completed their process.</start_of_turn
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like abscesses which are close to a joint.</start_of_turn
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For an abscess which arises near a joint and persists, until it has decayed, may perhaps corrupt the ligaments or nerves of that joint: which is the cause of the contraction of that limb.</start_of_turn
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or an abscess which is in a limb: for if you delay its perforation until it has matured, it will cause pain or swelling or both in that limb.</start_of_turn
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	If it is close to the anus, perforate it immediately: and it is not fitting to perforate a crude stool that is not completely digested, except when it is close to the anus, lest it putrefy deeply and extend inwards of the rectum, and form a fistula, or remain unhealed at its end.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the time of perforation of the stool, which is matured according to its completion: and it is with sedation of pain, recession of fever, and reduction of redness, and pulse, and an increased intensity of the head of the stool: and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary that you make the perforation in a lower place of the stool, and more prominent: and let the perforation be wide in length of the body, if the stool is in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of laceration, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all the places where there is no reflection
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those which reflect, do cautiously with the perforation according to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When indeed the stool is in the places of hardness: then it is better that you delay the perforation of it until its digestion is confirmed, as we said according to completion
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Because if you perforate it before that, the course of the disease from it is prolonged, and there is much dirt and putrefaction, and possibly the lips of the wound will be prolonged, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some stools are perforated according to the breadth of the body by necessity: or according to that which the member requires.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you manage in the small stools a moderate perforation, and in the large stools a wide perforation: or many sections similar in magnitude to the stool.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are from the apostemata, in which it is necessary that the skin should be concaved: and it happens when it is already made like a panus, and is made at the end, when it is already dead: as it happens with many things, as with dubelet, and with bubonibus.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are from those which are cut with a section having three angles
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And there are from those which are cut like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like the apostema of the inguinal region
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are from those in which a round section and a lunar section are administered: and similar things from sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That which does not have a head, like the superficial leninous apostemata, must be pierced through a superficial perforation, or only planely
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it must be when the apostema is thick, and when there is much surrounding healthy tissue, that you perforate it, that you do not damage it and extract all the pus in that hour: rather extract from it a part of it
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then anoint the apostema until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract some of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the degree, until the patient is expelled: especially if the patient is feeble in spirit, or a woman in childbirth, or a young child, or an old man decrepitus: for the spirit of the animal is resolved from the animal with the expulsion of the health: and perhaps the patient will die, and you will not perceive it
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Beware therefore this chapter has great caution
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have perforated the apostema, which is what you do to the apostemata, you must remove the slime: and consider
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If there is a small abscess of a vein, either cut it off level with the surface or ligate the vein above.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	If there is a large abscess and many holes of perforation, it is necessary to insert into each hole a ligature until they reach the innermost part.</start_of_turn>
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	If you have cut away a part of the skin in the abscess, or if you have cauterized around it: then you must put in an old dressing, or as when a bandage is taken off, or cover it with dry wool: and hold it in place until the third day.</start_of_turn>
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it and care for it until it has healed.</start_of_turn>
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If however blood flows in your operation in this hour: then administer cold water and vinegar, after you have swallowed it with a piece of bread: and put it over the place where the blood is flowing profusely.</start_of_turn
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If the bleeding persists, then you must administer treatment, care, and powders, which I have narrated in many places of this book, and from experience.</start_of_turn
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is winter and the place of the abscess is full of nerves: then you must instill small sponges with wine and warm fat: and put them over the place.</start_of_turn
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is summer and the place is fleshy: then you must put sponges soaked in water and fat, or in wine and fat, and all of this cold.</start_of_turn>
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until then, as we have said, on the third day you must drain the abscess, evacuate it, and administer to its care what is suitable for it until it has healed.</start_of_turn
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore necessary from the knowledge of the cure of apostemata universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the method, indeed, of discernment, as I have said concerning every apostematum, how it is possible to achieve its cure is set out individually
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Concerning the section of apostemata which occur in the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	There occur in the head small apostemata, and they are of the kind of knots which contain tunica, which are like sacks: as if they were themselves little poultry houses.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their species are many
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some are fat: and some contain moisture like mud: and some contain moisture like sweat and pus: and others like these, and there are those which are hard stones
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the section of all of them, and in their extraction, there is no fear, as long as during their section it does not make an opposite to the artery
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their section is as one must experience with the instrument which comes after this, which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, then dry it out by the superficial section: in this way.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the section from line b to line g. When therefore the moisture has been evacuated, then remove the knot which contains it, and do not leave anything behind it
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For many return if anything remains of it
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the head in Egyptian unguent, if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and apply with it a willow, and remove it until the next day
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	The substance itself consumes that which remains of the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Repeat over the substance with the aegyptio secondus, thirdus, and if it does not yield, until you are confident that nothing remains of the cyst, then indeed take care of the wound with unguentum until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the swelling contains a pimple, then dry it out in this fashion, by cutting it through in the shape of a cross: and project the nails between the two cuts, and scour it from all sides: and attempt your skill in the extraction of the membrane which contains it.</start_of_turn
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If, however, it opposes you, the artery, then do that which I shall tell you afterwards.</start_of_turn>
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	Do the same with a stone swelling, by cutting through it, and treating it in the same way as before.</start_of_turn
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the cutting through a stone swelling is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain hours of swellings which are in the head of certain people, in which there is no moisture at all.</start_of_turn
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I dried out the swelling in the head of a maidservant, and I found the swelling just like a solid stone, hard, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if I pierced it with anything, it would burst.</start_of_turn
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other swellings of the head, except for these which happen in the heads of children, and at the roots of the ears, the incision should be superficial.</start_of_turn>
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make the perforation always from below upwards, so as to aid the course of healing downwards.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for it with whatever is necessary from the cure.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Then care for it with whatever is necessary from the cure.
Caput XLII.	Then care for it with whatever is necessary from the cure.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Then care for it with whatever is necessary from the cure. Many of these post-traumatic swellings occur in the neck, under the armpits, and in the groin: and sometimes they occur in the rest of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And concerning those things which happen in the neck from the above-mentioned causes, there is one, or many: and they are generated from the bone. And every swelling of the Strophula is within its own tunic, as in the nodes and the swellings of the head, as we have mentioned
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these swellings of the Strophula
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these things there are soft ones: and there are those which contain humours: and there are malignant ones which do not obey treatment
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In this way, if a good-dispositioned liquid is found in the touch, which is evident by its proximity to the colour of the skin, and which moves to every part and is not attached to the nerves of the neck, the thyroid, or the arteries, or is not deep: it must be cut away from the upper part towards the lower part of the body along a line, from below the jawline to the groin, and the two lips of the skin should be extended with a single or with multiple sutures, if necessary, as is done in the swelling of the head, and the substance should be gradually extracted.</start_of_turn>
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is important to be cautious so that no bone or nerve is injured.</start_of_turn
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the incision not be too acute, so that it does not cause you to move your hand with the incision, or frighten the patient, and cut only what is necessary.</start_of_turn
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If, however, you cut a vein or artery, or are forbidden by the operation, then put in the wound a lump of charcoal, or some powder which separates the blood, and bind up the wound, and let it rest until the pain subsides, and the wound is softened: or else it will begin to putrefy.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For the blood is separated by this. Return therefore to your operation until you have completed it
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger whether anything remains of the other troches: if so, cut easily, and wash it clean.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If it is in the root of the trochee a large bone: then it is necessary that you do not cut that trochee from its root: rather it is necessary that you bind it with a strong doubled thread, and let it go until it falls down by itself without any support.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then apply the wound to the outer side, which you have submerged in Egyptian unguent.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of it.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the trochee is cut throughout, then it is necessary that you bring together the two lips of the wound: and hold them in place immediately, after you have washed because if it has gone too far it will not remain superfluous.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If, however, you have washed because there remains superfluous blood because of the size of the trochee, then it is necessary that you insert your finger into the root of it and extract it: and administer the suture as we said
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And what is contained in the troches, moisten it with a small perforation: that you may see the seat of its maturity: and put the perforation from this which follows below the body, as we said
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation a bandage with unguent, and similar things, so that it may consume what remains of the corruption, until when you have washed the wound is clean: then take care of it with the generation of meat, until it is healed.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the excision of the epiglottis from the apostemate within the guttur by chance.
Caput XLIII.	On the excision of the epiglottis from the apostemate within the guttur by chance.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients say that they performed this excision of the epiglottis in the guttur, and none of them in our land ever performed it: this is the report of their speech.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	In cases of spasms, however, the excision of the epiglottis must be performed: when no other remedy proves effective: for all veins and the lung are weakened by this.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a hard swelling in the mouth, or gut, or two abscesses, when there is no inflammation in the channel, it is necessary to perform the excision of the epiglottis to escape from the impending destruction caused by the swelling
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is necessary therefore, when we wish to perform this, to cut through the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small incision through the thickness, in that place where there is cartilage between two circles as much as in the cartilage itself: and this is a suitable place for the incision, because it is bare of flesh and the blood vessels from it are long.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is timid, then it is necessary to extend the skin of the guttur with a finger
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then find the skin, until it reaches the channel: there will be blood vessels if anything leaks out
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut through the cartilage as we have said: and it is known from the discharge of phlegm from it when it is ruptured, and from the cutting of the vocal cords.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let go of the wound at some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the limb is moved at the hour when the focus departs, gather two lips of the wound together and sew them alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then apply medicines which cause the flesh to heal, until the wound is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis said it.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	This is all that Albucasis has said on this matter. The exposition is not sufficient, except when the time of the setting of the sun has passed, since the patient has already departed this life, and wishes to pass beyond this life: he will grasp towards the epiglottis in order to breathe, and will expire from the wound.  Therefore it is commanded to shut the wound until the mischief of the disease has passed, which is for three days, or almost as long as that: then indeed we shall shut the wound and treat it until it is healed
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And this which I have seen myself: a handmaid took a knife and put it into the patient's gut, and it went through a part of the windpipe.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	I was called to care for him, and I found him foaming like a dead man.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I saw the wound, and I found blood which had flowed out of the wound of the little finger
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I am perplexed, for neither the wound itself nor the instruments have gone awry: the wind was going out of the wound
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I treated him, and closed the wound, and cared for him until he was healed: and the handmaid did nothing else, except spit in the water: and she returned after a few days in better health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Henceforth, know this: there is no fear of the epiglottis in the section of the wound
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the section of the hernia of the gutturis.
Caput XLIIII.	On the section of the hernia of the gutturis.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This appendix is called the hernia of the gutturis, is a large hernia, according to the colour of the body: and it is much in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two ways: either it is natural: or it is accidental
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural one there is certainly no lesion.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	Accidental, however, it is according to two ways: one of which is like a swelling of fat nodules
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other way is like an appendix which arises from the swelling of an artery
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this there is fear, and it does not seem right to assume it with iron, except in the case that it is slight: and you must prove it and investigate it with an incision.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If indeed you find it like a swelling of fat, and it is not suspected with any ulcer: then dry it up like swellings of fat are dried up: and extract it with that which contains the cyst, if it is in a cyst: and if not, then explore the whole of it
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with it which should be cured, until it is healed
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Of the section of the super-species of knots.
Caput XLV.	Of the section of the super-species of knots
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many species of knots, and I have mentioned all of them in their division: and it is necessary to say here the difference between a knot and an extrusion, when there is doubt
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say, therefore, that when an extrusion has become cold, and fever, and pain which are causing distress, until the ebullition of excess has subsided, and putrefaction is completed: then the fever and heat will cease
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When the node is not hot, neither feverish, nor painful, it contains humours that are like sacs, proper to themselves, and are according to the colour of the body: and their beginning is like millet, and they make like bataches, and are greater and less.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two kinds: either fat: or they contain moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colours of moisture are many, as I said in the preceding discourse
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary therefore, when you are performing the cure of the Node, to experience it, and to inquire about it at first with the instrument which is called the Intromissum, according as its form will appear in the chapter which follows.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the way of inquiring afterwards, and of all Nodes, is that you take this instrument and introduce it into the moist place which you find in the apostemate: and you draw back your fingers gradually, until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then finally touch your hand according to the measure of the size of the apostemate.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the Intromissum, and consider what comes out in the stain of its wound
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore it comes out running moisture, whatever its colour be: then dry it with a superficial section, according as I said in the other apostemata.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if it does not come out running moisture in the stain of the Intromissum, then you know that it is fat: dry it therefore with a section having the form of a cross, according to this form: as I have taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and scrape the skin from all around with ease: and keep the sac if you see it above that.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If however it is broken in the sac during the operation, and it is not possible to extract it whole: much happens in this case, then extract it broken, until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most.
Caput XLVI.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	If anything remains from it, little or much, it returns to Node according to most
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	Experience is also found with black lead, which unites so that through them experience fistulas, whose cavities reflect like them with their smoothness.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	There are three kinds of experience remaining
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For as from these [three kinds] are long, medium, and short, according to the quantity of the breadth of the fistula and the tightness of its structure.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of the [fistulas] is various, and there are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For as from these [four kinds] are simple, which has one curve: and there are three kinds like liquids, great, medium, and small
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from these are blind fistulas: and there are three kinds of them
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from these are double fistulas having two curves, and there are three kinds of them: and from these are triple fistulas having three curves, and there are three kinds of them: and all of these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	These are the forms of scalpels, which cut and scrape nodes, and abscesses: and there are three kinds of them, for as from these are large, medium, and small
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities which are cut are acute, their other extremities are not acute: and they are not put in such a way except when with these [instruments] an incision is made in the node in fear of the vessel, or the nerve: and that it may heal in peace, and that it may find tranquility after the removal of the cause of the inflammation than after its incision
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are magmas, and there are three kinds of them
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are formed from air, and are similar to radium, with which alcohol is made: and at their wide end is a hidden Spatumilis point: and in this runs inwards and outwards when desired, like liquids.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of the spatula which are passed between the fingers at the perforation of the apostem: these are not perceived by the sick; and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The form of the spatulas with which the flow of blood is broken: these are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be of air or of citrine, round in shape, of equal length, like wax: and let them be firm.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these spatulas be of three kinds: large and small: in order that you may break the blood quickly at need, and when there is no physician present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	Truly, you must not use these instruments for the breaking of blood in any part of the body, and must not use them except in places where there is carnation: such as wounds of the leg, and hip, and wounds of the arm, and breast, and belly, and groin, and similar wounds, from carnation, humors.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes other small instruments like the bristles of brushes are made from these instruments of a similar form: with which the blood is broken when it flows out from the site of phlebotomy, or at the incision of the vein, or artery: and sometimes they are made from these instruments of a round shape like this
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	And concerning the care of the breasts of women who are nursing infants
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of some men swell because of sleep (that is, when they begin to become soiled in sleep) until they resemble the breasts of women: and they remain with a posterior wound of the nipple.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever dislikes this should cut across the breast with a lunar section, according to this shape from the line A to the line B. Then scrape off the fat all around
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	After that, an olive oil is brought from the medicine of the incisions.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then two lips of the wound are closed with a suture, and it is cared for until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the nipple declines towards the lower parts, and is softened because of its size, as often happens with women: then it is necessary to find two points on the two upper sides of the wound, similar in shape to a half-moon, each one containing the other at the end of each, until a line greater contains a smaller one, following this shape from the line, b. to the line, g. Afterwards scrape the skin which is between the two lips, and remove the fat, and administer what we have said concerning the suture and powders, which is necessary for the cure, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, you do not wish to open the incision because of the patient’s anxiety or because of the flow of blood: then it is necessary to apply an olive oil soaked in vinegar to the wound and leave it, until that which remains of the fat has rotted away.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	As for the perforation of the apostemate, which happens under the title of Titillico.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.</start_of_turn
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These apostemata which happen under the title of Titillico are of the kind of hard Stropharia, which contain cysts, and from these are those which contain moisture.</start_of_turn
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Which are from those which contain moisture, it is necessary to cut in a lunar shape, following this shape from the line b. to the line g. and when all that is in the apostemate from the blood has been evacuated, then apply an ointment to the old wound and leave it until the next day.</start_of_turn
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the limb is raised up, and is cared for with an unguent that is suitable for it, until it is healed.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the swelling should be from a kind of knot of the Strophular kind, then it is to be cut through above it, as we said in the section on the Strophulas which are equal
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, a limb swells in this way as to emit pus, then in that case apply cautery to it, as we said before
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	As for the cutting through of a swelling that has arisen from an artery or a vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured, and the skin above it is consolidated, then many times a swelling arises from the limb: and in the same way a swelling arises from a vein, as it does in this limb from the swelling and inflation
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that the swelling and inflation are from an artery and a vein, are these: for when the swelling is from an artery, it is long and gathered in the depth of the body: and when the swelling is from an infected limb, you feel as though there is a constriction there
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is from a vein is round in the open part of the body
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	The cutting through of such a swelling is an error, especially if it is below the armpits, and the groin, and the throat, and in many parts of the body: and it is a great danger.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore it is necessary to take care of it with iron, and that which is also in the extremities, or in the head, it is necessary to take care of it
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	As for that which is from the infection of the opening of the artery, find in the cutting through of the skin in the length
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the part with hooks, afterwards the artery: and free the latter from the tunics until it is severed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce a hook under it and make it penetrate until the other side, and tighten the artery with a double thread in two places, as you were taught concerning the extraction of two arteries in the temporal region.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then puncture the place which is between two ligaments with the sponge, until blood that is in it all comes out, and the clot is dissolved.</start_of_turn>
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply a dressing which generates pus, until the ligaments fall away: afterwards care for that with suitable bandages until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If there should be a clot on account of the cutting of a vein, then you must take hold of your hand as much as is possible from the clot with the skin.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce a hook under the place where you held your hand, and make it penetrate: and be in it a double thread, until you pull it out from the other side.</start_of_turn
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie with this the clot with a strong ligature: as I have told you concerning the ligature of a vein, from two parts with two extremities of thread.</start_of_turn
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however you fear that the thread is pulled out, then introduce another hook with another thread under the whole clot at the incision of the needle: before that, and tighten your thread in four places.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the clot in its middle, until when it comes out what is in it: then cut away the surplus of skin, and discharge what is ligated from that.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place above it a little ball which you have immersed in wine, and fat.</start_of_turn
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed.
Caput L.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
Caput LI.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Then manage the treatment, which is done with licenses and unguents, until healed
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And it is from the parts of the body which are small: and it is from the parts of the body which grow up.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed I saw a man who had two testicles in his belly, which were greater than any other things like mushrooms: there was no difference between them, white, small roots, and their labia were hanging down, and they were found to be moist from the very beginning
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I saw a man who had two testicles in his belly, which were greater than any other things like mushrooms: there was no difference between them, white, small roots, and their labia were hanging down, and they were found to be moist from the very beginning.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	Many are expelled from the section of its blood: therefore if blood incites thee, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If thou seest a feeble and timid patient from an incision with iron, then take a leaden weight and suspend it from the middle, and bind it with thread: which is the way we have said, and discharge it in two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add in stricture lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease to bind the lead until it is separated, and it shall fall by itself without toil
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If the vessel be of great size of the root, then in its incision there is something fearful and feeble: especially that which is in the belly
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	It is indeed possible that thou cut through its middle
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, that it may not return
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it until the wound be healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And be careful lest thou presume to cut the vessel which is of a dusky colour, little sense, and foetid aspect: for that is a cancer: and I will remind thee of cancer afterwards.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	Of the care of the belly.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The belly swells from many wounds.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from incisions of the intestines which are above the belly: and it comes out through the opening, or the intestine itself, according as it happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood which flows from the vein, or from the artery, as has been said before
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from a distension of the belly itself.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If, however, it is due to a wound of the scrotum, and the opening of the tube: then the colour of the after-effect is similar to that of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and appears in various places.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the emission of the intestine, then its place is as we have mentioned, with a greater degree of variety in its appearance.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	As you touch it with your fingers, it is hidden: then it returns, and sometimes there is a sound with it: and it swells greatly at the entrance of the bath, and great pain ensues
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If indeed it is due to moisture, it is soft: then it is not hidden when you touch it with your hand, neither is there constriction, nor does it swell.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then it appears with these signs: the after-effect is black as night at the root of the penis
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If indeed it is due to flesh that has died: then the after-effect is thick, great, hard, and appears according to the quantity of one
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If indeed it is due to swelling, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in this is as you consider: if the prominence of the navel is due to the artery, or the vein, or swelling: then you must abstain from treatment of it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in this there is fear and danger, as I taught you in the chapter where I spoke of the after-effect due to the artery and the vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the prominence of the navel is due to the intestine, or the bladder: then you must command the patient to hold his breath, as long as he can bear it, and to remain still extending it.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with the encasement around the whole circumference of the navel
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to recline between your hands upon his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then circle around with a broad spatula around the belly in the place that you have marked with a burn
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the middle of the incision upwards with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him firmly around with thread or silk cord: and make the knot of the ligature firm.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the extended middle of the incision above the ligature
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find the gut caught by the ligature: then draw out the ligature and introduce it into the finger of the index, and push the intestine inwards: and if you find a bone, then grasp it with a hook, and cut off its excess.<start-of-turn>
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If, however, there is an artery or a vein: then circle it much.<start-of-turn>
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your work.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And grasp two needles, and introduce them through two strong threads: and introduce two needles around the circumference which you made around the incision in the form of a cross, which you make penetrate.<start-of-turn>
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the incision in four places over the needles: and if you will, remove the needles and leave the place, until the extended flesh putrefies: and it will fall away by itself: or cut it away when it softens and putrefies.<start-of-turn>
