Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with what is necessary from the unguents, until he is healed.<start-of-turn>
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	And if the swelling of the belly is from flesh that has become black in it, or from moisture: then it is necessary to concave the incision, as we have said.<start-of-turn
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And extract blood, or moisture, as you find it in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for the place with it which solidifies the location.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	And care for the cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken in the discourse concerning the species of cancer, and how it is to be treated by physicians: and caution should be taken with it when treating it with iron, lest it should ulcerate: and we have said that cancer is generated in the matrix, and should be treated with caution
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients say that sometimes when cancer is in a place where it can be eradicated, such as cancer that is in the breast or in the thigh, and those that are like them, from the members that are to be excised throughout: especially when it is just beginning and small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is old, and is great, it is not right to approach it closely
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	I am unable to cure anyone from it: neither do I know of anyone who has been able to do so before me
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation in it, when it is located as we have said, is to precede it, and to dissolve the disease with black bile somewhat.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then draw blood from it if you find it with a swelling evident
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient for the operation, in which it is placed with the operation
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then remove from the cancer nails which agree with it
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then draw the wound closed from every side with skin, according to the prescription, until nothing remains of its roots: and let blood flow freely, and do not bind it up quickly, but express the place, and evacuate the thick blood throughout the hand, or as much as is possible with the instruments.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, it causes blood to flow excessively from an artery or a vein: then cauterize the vein until the bleeding ceases.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	(Sentence continues: "Then care for it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.")
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 44.</start_of_turn>
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We shall explain in this chapter the varieties of hydropses and how water accumulates: and the signs of each kind, and their treatment by physicians.</start_of_turn>
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is cured with iron is not except the sole kind of ascites: and it is not approached with iron in the case of tympani: neither in the case of hydrops of the joints: for that is deadly.</start_of_turn
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you are treated for this kind of hydrops of the tympani by physicians, and the treatment does not help: then consider that.</start_of_turn
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if a patient is suffering from weakness in addition to the hydrops, or if there is another illness along with the hydrops, such as consumption or solution of the intestines, and similar things: then do not treat him with iron for that is dangerous.</start_of_turn
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	If, however, the patient is of robust health, neither young nor old: then the mode of operation in this case is that you lift the patient up between your hands and squeeze out the urine from his belly downwards by pressing on his belly.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a rough sponge, according to this form.</start_of_turn
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Sit two acute angles, long and acute-ended like a sponge.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	Truly, within it are things of slight size which do not pass through with it until the intestines, and which leave the wound itself.
Deinde considera.	Consider it then.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if there is a generation of hydrosis from the intestines, then it is necessary to extend [the incision] with three fingers from the navel to the lower parts in a straight line above the pelvis.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If indeed the generation of hydrosis is because of the liver: then let your incision be on the left side from the navel for three fingers
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	If it is because of the spleen, then let the incision be on the right side: and it is not necessary also that it should be on the side towards which the patient wishes to vomit, so that no fluid should flow to the delicate place
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce with an instrument the whole skin.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	And introduce your hand into the incision with the sponge between the skin, and scrape, as though you are scraping the wound itself: and the quantity which you scrape should be equal to the quantity of a nail, or thereabouts.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then scrape the sponge until the sponge reaches the empty place: and that is the place of the water
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then draw out the sponge, and introduce the instrument into the hole, which has this shape.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	It is like a cannula: it is made of silver, or of air, or of gold, soft, thin: which has in its lower part a small hole, and in its sides three holes, two from one side and one from the other: and its extremity is cut off, in the manner of a knife wound, like blood vessels: at its upper extremity is an armilla
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	For when the instrument reaches the water, then it immediately descends upon the instrument, and thus the water flows out of the water in an hour the quantity of a medium
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	If you evacuate more than is necessary from that, at a certain moment the sick man may die from the resolution of his animal spirit: or there may happen to him syncope which approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	Evacuate accordingly from that according to the quantity of his virtue, and according to what is signified to you by the disposition of the sick man from the virtue of his pulse and from his health
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then draw out the instrument, and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	Because it remains immediately by the skin which retains the opening which is over the siphon: of which I spoke, that you may perforate it according to the manner I have described
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then repeat the instrument on the other side, if you find the sick man can tolerate it: and also evacuate from the water the quantity that is appropriate.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do this several times without fear, and be cautious: until there remains from the water little or nothing.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	If however you fear for the sick man, and you discharge from the water a great deal: then care for him with burial in warm sand, and with much sweating in bath and sun, and expect upon the seat: and care for him with physicians of experience, until he is healed: and cauterize upon the stomach, and the spleen and the liver, after the discharge of the water: as I have said before.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	As for the care of infants who are born in places where the bladder is not perforated.
Caput LV.	Chapter LV.</start_of_turn>
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	When anyone goes out of the womb of his mother, and the head of his fetus is not perforated, or the opening is narrow, or is not in its proper place.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	It is necessary therefore to assist with the perforation of it immediately as it is born with a fine needle, according to this fashion.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then put in the cavity the small lead claw, and bind it: and keep it for three days, or four.
Quando ergo uult urinam emittere, remoueatur, et mingat.	When you wish to urinate, remove the claw and let it mix together
Deinde reduc ipsum.	Then withdraw it.
Et si tu non ponis plumbum, iam possibile est, ut urina quae incedit super locum, non permittat ipsum claudi.	And if you do not put in lead, it is possible that the urine which flows over the place will not permit the claw to stay closed
Ille autem cuius foramen est strictum, medicatur cum plumbo, sicut diximus, diebus multis, donec amplificetur.	The one whose opening is strict is treated with lead, as we said, for many days, until it is enlarged
Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	In those in which the opening is not in its proper place, they are cauterized
Quod est, quia ex eis qui nascitur, foramen est apud finem capitis uirgae: quare non potest mingere ad anteriora, donec eleuat uirgam manu sua ad superiora.	That is, because from the part which is born, the opening is at the end of the hair of the beard: wherefore it cannot mix forward until it lifts the hair above with its hand
Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	Neither is there any generation, because the sperm cannot pass to the matrix according to its right: and it is a grievous wound that is slow
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	And the method of operation in this is that the patient rests on his back
Deinde extende caput uirgae eius manu tua sinistra extensione uehementi, et incide caput capitis uirgae ex loco priapi, cum acumine, aut spatumili acuto: sicut est incisio calami, aut sicut tu radis aliquid, ut medium eius ueniat simile capiti uirgae: et ut cadat foramen in medio secundum quod oportet.	Then extend the hair of his beard with your left hand, and with your right hand make an incision of the head of the hair from the place of the privy, with a needle or sharp scalpel: as it is the incision of the nail, or as you would do with a radix of something, so that the middle of it comes out like the head of the hair: and that the opening be in the middle according to what is necessary
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	And cauterize yourself at the operation from the flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	Many times this happens to them
Oppone ergo ei cum eo quod abscindit sanguinem, et cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Opposition to it with that which breaks the blood, and care for the wound, until it is healed
¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	On swelling which occurs in the preparation and head of the uterus, and corruption, blackness, and adhesion.
Caput LVI.	On swelling which occurs in the preparation and head of the uterus, and corruption, blackness, and adhesion.
Multotiens accidunt istae Albather in uirga, et est eminentia carnis foedae.	Many of these swellings happen in the womb, and it is the elevation of corrupted flesh.
Et ex ea alia est maligna, et alia non maligna.	And from these there are both malignant and non-malignant kinds
Non malignam ergo oportet ut suspendas cum uncino subtili, et abscindas eam, donec mundes eam totam.	One must not make the malignant kind hang suspended with a fine thread, but must cut it off, until the whole thing is freed from the belly.
Deinde pone super eam cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio.	Then place over it a soaked bandage in Egyptian unguent
Deinde cura ipsum post illud cum unguento dyafinicon, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment of diaphthorb until it heals.
Quod si Albather est maligna, foedi coloris, tunc oportet ut administres in ea cauterium post incisionem eius et ipsius rasionem.	If the swelling is malignant, of dark colour, then one must administer in it cautery after making an incision of it and of itself.
Si autem Albather est in praeputio captiui, non circumcisi, et est pars Albather inter praeputium, et pars eius extra: tunc oportet ut auferas Albather, quae est intus in primis, donec quando consolidatur, tunc cura ipsum exterius: quoniam quando tu curas eam simul, non securatur praeputium quin preforetur.	If, however, the swelling is in the preparation and head of the uterus, not circumcised, and is a part of the swelling which is between the preparation and the uterus, and a part of it which is outside: then one must increase the swelling which is inside first, until it is consolidated, then care for the outside. For when you care for both at the same time, the preparation is not secured that it will not burst
Et iam accidunt etiam in testiculis, et praeputio nigredo et corruptio.	And also in testicles, and black preparation and corruption
Oportet ergo, ut tu concaues totum quod iam denigratum est, et quod uult corrumpi, aut iam corruptum est.	One must therefore remove all that is decayed and that desires to corrupt, or that is already corrupted
Deinde line super ipsum post illud cum melle quod iam concussum est cum farina corticum granatorum, et herbi tritorum cribellatorum.	Then place over it after this with honey which has been consumed with pounded barley and crushed herbs of thyme.
Deinde cura illud cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the remaining treatment until it heals
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra cauterium cum cauterio lunari, secundum hanc formam.	If blood flow increases, then apply the cautery with the lunar cautery, according to this shape.
Cauterium enim est iuuatiuum ad duas dispositiones simul, scilicet ad fluxum sanguinis, et uulnus quando corrumpitur.	The cautery is applied to two positions simultaneously, that is, to the blood flow and the ulcer when it is ruptured
Quod si corroditur caput uirgae, et destruitur totum in hora: tunc oportet ut intromittas in meatum priapi cannulam ex plumbo, ut mingat infirmus super eam.	If the head of the vein bursts and is destroyed throughout in an hour: then it is necessary to insert lead into the marrow of the bone so that the diseased part may be absorbed above the wound
In adhaerentia uero praeputii cum capite uirgae, et haec quidem adhaerentia non accidit, nisi in eo cuius praeputium est sanum, et non exigitur super ipsum circumcisio: et quandoque accidit adhaerentia propter uulnus, aut apostema: oportet ergo ut excories eam cum Spatumili obtuso, donec soluatur ligamentum, et liberetur caput uirgae ab omni parte.	In connection with the covering of the head of the vein with the caput uirgae, and this connection does not take place except in the case where the covering is sound and not required to be excised: and when it does take place through the ulcer or swelling: it is necessary to strip away the covering with blunt forceps until the ligament is severed and the head of the vein is freed from all parts.
Quod si est difficile discernere ea exquisite, tunc oportet ut excories aliquid ex capite uirgae, et ex praeputio.	If it is difficult to discern between these two, then it is necessary to strip away something from the head of the vein and from the covering
Quod est, quia praeputium quando est subtile, fortasse perforatur propter subtilitatem suam uelociter.	For the covering is sometimes perforated because of its slightness or its speed.
Deinde separa inter praeputium, et caput uirgae cum panno lini subtili, qui iam madefactus est in aqua frigida, ut non adhereant iterum.	Then separate the covering from the head of the vein with a fine linen cloth which has been made wet in cold water, so that they do not adhere to each other again.
Deinde curetur cum uino stiptico, donec consolidetur.	Then care for it with balsamic vinegar until it has solidified
¶ De mundificatione infantium, et curatione ex errore eis accidente.	Concerning the treatment of infants, and the care for an error from an accident.
Caput LVII.	Chapter 57.
Circumcisio non est solutio continuitatis, sicut reliqua uulnera: uerumtamen cum sit ex operatione nostra, uoluntate nostra, et usus eius sit in pueris proprie, est necesse ut signemus in ea operationem meliorem, et uiam leuiorem perducentem ad salutem.	Circumcision is not a continuous solution like other wounds: indeed when it is carried out by our operation, with our will, and when it is in children of their own kind, it is necessary to show in this operation a greater skill and to remove as little as possible of the surrounding area.
Dico ergo, quod antiqui non dixerunt circumcisionem in aliquo suorum librorum: quoniam non utuntur in legibus suis, et non est nisi quod acquisiuimus per experimentum.	I say, therefore, that the ancients did not speak of circumcision in any of their books: for they did not use it in their practices, and there is nothing except that which we have learned through experience.
Quod est, quia ego inueni maiorem partem artificum, et phlebotomatorum uti mundificatione, circumcidendo cum nouacula, et cum forficibus: et utuntur alfecati, et ligaudo cum filo, et incisione cum ungula.	Indeed, for I have found a greater part of surgeons to be engaged in artificial methods, such as phlebotomy and cautery, using the knife with a nail and with scissors: and they employ them for all sorts of affections, and bind with thread and suture with a needle.
Et ego quidem iam probaui omnes istos modos, et non inueni meliorem mundificatione cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo.	I have also tried all these methods, and I have not found a better method of healing than the use of scissors and thread binding.
Quoniam in mundificatione cum nouacula, multotiens effugit cutis.	For in the use of the knife with a nail, a great quantity of skin flees.
Quoniam cutis praeputii duas habet tunicas: ergo forsitan inciditur cutis superior, et temanet tunica inferior: cogitur ergo ad incisionem ad incidendum alteram, et dolorem futurum.	For the skin of the prepuce has two layers: therefore it is possible that the upper skin may split, and the lower layer will be threatened: it is therefore necessary to make an incision to split the other, and to avoid the future pain
Et cum mundificatione quae fit per alfecati, id est, digitalis, quo utuntur sutores, non securatur incisio extremitatis uirilis membri: quoniam fortasse ingreditur in foramen eius.	And when the healing is done by means of the cautery, which is what the physicians use, the incision of the extremity of the limb is not secured: for perhaps it enters the opening of the canal.
In mundificatione autem cum ungula, fortasse euadit ferrum, et corrumpit operationem tuam: et cutis quidem pueri est breuis natura, et multotiens nascuntur taliter, quod non indigent mundificatione: et iam uidi illud.	But in the use of the needle with a hook, perhaps the iron will go through, and will corrupt your work: and the skin of a boy is of little strength, and many are produced in this way, which does not befit healing: I therefore reject this method
Mundificationis autem cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo, bonum experimentum detexit mihi: quoniam forfices sunt proportionalis incisionis: propterea, quod acuitas quae est superius, est sicut acuitas quae est inferius.	Healing by means of the knife and thread, however, has proved a good experiment to me: for the knives are proportional to the incision: therefore, as the former is greater, so also is the latter.
Cum ergo premis manum tuam, proportionantur duae acuitates, et incidunt secundum operationem unam in tempore uno: et fit compressio simili figura, continens cutem uirgae ab omni parte, cum qua non cadit error omnino.	When you have therefore grasped your hand, the two acutenesses are proportional, and they cut according to the operation of one at the same time: and it makes a similar compression of the figure, containing the skin of the member from all sides, so that no error is made at all
Et modus operationis propriae est, ut facias extimare, puerum praecipue, si est ex eis qui intelligunt parumper, quod tu non facis, nisi quod ligas filum in uirga sua tantum: et dimittas ipsum usque ad diem alium.	And the manner of performing the operation is thus, that you make the child understand, especially if there is one who understands fully, that you do not do this unless you bind the thread in its place: and you dismiss him until another day.
Deinde fac eum gaudere et laetari omnimodo quo possibile est tibi illud, ex eo quod recipit intelligentia sua.	Then make him rejoice and be glad in every way that he can, from which he receives his intelligence.
Deinde fac eum stare inter manus tuas praeparatae staturae, et non sit sedens: et occulta forfices in manica tua, aut sub pede tuo, ne uideat eos puer omnino, neque aliquid ex instrumentis.	Then make him stand between your prepared hands, and do not sit down: and hide the shears in your sleeve or under your foot, so that the child sees nothing of them, neither anything of the instruments.
Deinde intromitte manum tuam ad uirgam eius, et suffla in cutem, et trahe eam sursum, donec egrediatur caput uirgae.	Then insert your hand into the wound, and blow into the skin, and draw it up, until the head of the wound comes out.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex eo quod aggregatur in ea sordicie.	Then bind up the rest that is gathered in that cavity.
Deinde liga locum signatum cum filo duplo.	Then bind the place marked with a double thread.
Postea liga inferius eo parumper ligamentum secundum.	Then bind below it with the same thread as before
Deinde tene cum indice tuo, et pollice locum ligamenti inferioris retentione bona, et incide inter duo ligamenta.	Then hold with your index finger and thumb the place of the lower binding securely, and cut between the two bindings.
Deinde eleua cutem sursum uelociter, et extrahe caput uirgae.	Then lift the skin up quickly and remove the head of the wound
Deinde dimitte sanguinem currere paulatim (est enim melius) et pone puluerem desuper: et super puluerem pannum in quo expansus est uitellus oui decocti in aqua rosata, concussum cum oleo ros recenti bono: et dimitte eum super ipsum usque ad diem alium: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then let the blood run slowly (for it is better thus) and put powder on it: and put a bandage over the powder on which the swollen part has been immersed in rose-water, pounded with fresh rose-water: and dismiss him until the next day: and care for the rest of the treatment until he is healed.
Forma autem forficis ad mundificationem haec est.	The form of the shears for this dressing is like this
Sint hebetes duae extremitates, et sint incidentes: ne egrediatur in eis ramus claui: et sit longitudo duarum acuitatum, sicut longitudo duorum manubriorum aequaliter.	There are two handles and two blades, and the handles should not extend into the wound: and the length of the two blades should be equal to the length of two thumbs together
Error uero cadens in mundificatione est: quoniam fortasse effugit cutis intrinseca tota, aut pars eius apud incisionem.	An error often occurs in excision: because perhaps the entire intrinsic skin has escaped beyond the incision.
Ergo oportet, ut extendas eam ex hora tua cum ungue tuo ante apostemationem loci: et incidas eam secundum aequalitatem.	Therefore it is necessary to extend the time from your hour until your nail has passed beyond the margin of the wound: and then make the incision according to the degree of equality
Quod si non potes tenere eam cum ungue tuo, tunc extrahe eam cum uncino, et incide eam.	If you are unable to hold the wound steady with your nail, then extract it with forceps and make the incision.
Si autem praeterierint ei tres dies, et remanet quod est sub uirga inflatum, apostematum: tunc dimitte illud, donec sedetur apostema calidum, et excoria illud cum facilitate, et incide illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi: et caue tibi a capite uirgae.	If, however, three days have passed and what remains under the swelling has become soft, remove the dressing: then let the swelling subside, and cleanse it gently, and make the incision as before: and take care to avoid the head of the swelling.
Non enim nocebit ei illud.	It will not cause any damage to it.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod consolidat uulnus ex pulueribus, quos narrauimus in tractatu de pulueribus: et si inciditur ex cute supra mensuram, et euadit ad superiora, non nocet ei illud etiam.	Treat it with the care that consolidates the wound from its fragments, as we have narrated in the treatise on fragments: and if it happens that it breaks through the skin beyond the measure, and reaches the upper parts, it does not cause any damage to it even then
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod diximus, donec sanetur.	Treat it with the care we have mentioned, until it is healed
¶ De extractione Vrinae retentae in uesica.	Of the extraction of a retained vein in a swelling
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58.
Urinae retentio in uesica, fit ab opilatione facta ex lapide, aut sanguine congelato, aut pus, aut carne nata, et similibus illis ex eis quae diximus ex modis curationis in diuisione.	The retention of urine in the swelling is caused by a stone, or frozen blood, or pus, or flesh born, or similar things of that kind that we have mentioned in the section on treatment of diuresis.
Et si non soluitur Vrina, et uides retentionem eius esse propter Lapidem, qui iam est in collo uesicae: tunc oportet ut sit infirmus super genua sua curuatus.	If the urine does not pass, and the retention is known to be caused by a stone which is in the neck of the bladder: then it is necessary for him to lie with his knee bent over his heel
Deinde componantur pedes eius super dorsum eius, et extendat uentrem suum ex superiori parte dorsi eius, et stringat infirmus anhelitum suum quantum possibile est ei.	Then they should place his feet on his back, and extend his belly from the upper part of his back, and grasp the painful area as tightly as possible for him
Cogitur ergo cum collo uesicae ad expulsionem Lapidis ad posteriora: quare absoluitur Vrina.	It is thought therefore that when the collar of the bladder approaches the expulsion of the stone to the back: the bladder is obstructed.
Quod si non soluitur cum eo quod diximus, et uehemens sit res super infirmum: tunc oportet ut administres extractionem eius cum instrumento, quod nominatur siringa, cuius haec est forma Sit ex argento, et sit subtile, lene, concauum sicut cannula pennae auis in subtilitate radii, longum in similitudine palmi unius et medii: cui sit cannula subtilis in capite eius.	If it is not solved with this, and the disease be great: then it is necessary that you perform the extraction of it with an instrument, which is called a siringa. It is formed of silver, is subtle, soft, and concave like a pennaceous quill in the smoothness of a ray, long like the palm of one hand and a half: which has a fine cannula in its head.
Et modus exitus Vrinae per ipsum est, ut accipias filum duplicatum, et liges in extremitate eius lanam, aut cotum, ligatura bona: et intromittas extremitatem fili in inferiori parte Siringae: et incide cum forficibus si superfluit aliquid ex lana, uerum intromitte in cannulam cum uehementia, sicut alzer.	The way to evacuate the bladder is through itself: take two threads and tie them at their extremities with good ligature. Insert the extremity of the thread into the lower part of the siringa: and pierce with forceps if anything comes out through the wool. But insert into the cannula with certainty, as if lifting.
Deinde inunge siringam cum oleo, aut cum butyro, et albugine oui: et fac sedere infirmum super sedem, et embroca uesicam, et ipsius uirgam cum oleis humidis, et oleo oliuae, et aqua tepida.	Then pour oil, butter, and vinegar on the siringa: and make the patient sit over a seat, and support the bladder, and draw out the urine with oil, butter, and warm water.
Deinde intromitte siringam in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat ad radicem uirgae.	Then insert the siringa into the urine until it reaches the root of the bladder.
Deinde dupla ipsam superius a parte umbilici.	Then take hold of the upper part above the navel
Deinde impelle siringam intra ipsam, donec perueniat ad Vesicam, et sentiat eam infirmus iam peruenisse ad rem uacuam: et non fit hoc secundum hunc ordinem, nisi quoniam meatus, in quo uadit, est in quo est tortuositas.	Then push the siringa into itself until it reaches the bladder, and let the patient feel that it has gone to the painful area: and do not do this except when the meatus through which it passes is tortuous
Deinde extende filum cum lana paulatim.	Then draw out the thread gradually with the wool
Vrina enim sequetur lanam.	The bladder will follow the wool.
Deinde extrahe eam, et fac currere Vrinam per uiam urinae: et itera siringam, et non cesses facere illud, donec euacuetur uesica, et inueniat infirmus alleuiationem.	Then draw out the urine, and make the bladder flow through the opening of the urine: and repeat the siringa, and do not cease doing this until the bladder is emptied, and the patient feels relief.
¶ De qualitate clisterizationis uesicae cum Clepshydra.	Concerning the quality of the bladder's irrigation with Clepshydra.
Caput LIX.	Regarding the quality of the irrigation of the bladder with Clepshydra.
Quando accidit in uesica ulcus, aut sanguis in ea congelatur, aut coartatur in ea pus, et uis distillare in eam aquas et medicinas: tunc fiat cum instrumento quod nominatur Clepshydra, et haec est forma eius.	When there is a wound in the bladder, or when blood is frozen in it, or congealed in it into pus, and when it is distilled into water and medicines: then it is done with an instrument called Clepshydra, and this is its form
Est enim surda, id est, clausa.	It is blunt, that is, closed.
Et in eo sunt tria foramina, duo ex parte una, et unum ex parte altera, sicut uides.	And there are three holes in it, two from one side and one from the other side, like urine
Et locus concauus, in quo est illud quod impellit, sit secundum quantitatem quod opilet ipsum sine additione, donec quando trahitur cum eo aliquid, ex humiditatibus attrahatur: et quando impellitur, cum eo expellatur ad longinquum: secundum quod facit clepshydra, qua proiicitur naphta, id est, ignis graecus in praeliis martis.	And the spigot hole, where that which drives it is located, should be according to the quantity that is desired to be driven without addition, until when it is pulled with it something is taken up from the humilities: and when it is driven, when it is expelled at length: according to what the Clepshydra does which ejects oil, that is, Greek fire in battle.
Cum ergo uis proiicere humiditates in uesicam, intromitte extremitatem clepshydrae in humiditatem, et trahe cum eo quod impellit ad superiora, humiditas enim trahitur in concauitatem clepshydrae.	When it is desired to spray moisture into the bladder, introduce the extremity of the Clepshydra into the moisture and draw it with that which drives it up, the moisture is then drawn into the concavity of the Clepshydra.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem eius in uirgam, secundum quod narrauimus in siringa.	Then introduce its extremity into the urine, as we said in the syringe
Deinde impelle humiditatem cum eo quod impellit illa namque humiditas peruenit ad uesicam statim, ita quod sentit eam infirmus.	Then drive the moisture with that which drives it and immediately the moisture arrives in the bladder, as the sick person feels
Forma clisteris subtilis quo clisterizatur uesica.	The form of the light bladder irrigation.
Fiat ex argento, aut auricalco: cuius caput altius sit simile alcama paruo, et sub eo sinus inter quem cadat ligamentum.	It is made of silver, or gold: whose head is higher like a small bowl, and under it there is a space between which the ligament falls.
Deinde accipe uesicam arietis, et pone in ea humiditatem, qua uis clisterizare uesicam.	Then take hold of the bladder of a sheep, and put in it the moisture which is to irrigate the bladder
Deinde liga eam inter duos sinus ligatura forti cum filo duplo: et calefac illam humiditatem parumper super ignem.	Then bind the two sinuses firmly with a double thread: and heat the humidity above the fire.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem clisteris in uirgam, postea stringe manum tuam super uesicam cum humiditate strictura decenti, donec sentiat infirmus, quod illa humiditas iam peruenit ad uesicam.	Then introduce the extremity of the clister into the abscess, afterwards tighten your hand over the vessel with a tight closure of humidity until the patient feels that the humidity has passed into the vessel.
Si autem non est tibi praesens uesica, tunc accipe frustum pergameni, et fac ex eo circulum, et perfora ipsum ab omni rotunditate sua.	If however the vessel is not present, then take hold of the piece of gut and make a circle of it, and pierce it through from all its roundness
Deinde intromitte filum forte in illis foraminibus, sicut reuoluuntur.	Then introduce the thread strongly through these holes, so that they resemble a twist
Deinde aggrega circulum, sicut aggregatur alsofratu: postquam tu ponis in eo illud quod uis ex humiditatibus, et oleis, et aquis.	Then gather the circle, so that it is like gathering wool: after you have placed in it what you wish of humilities, and oils, and waters.
Deinde liga ipsum in instrumento: et fac cum eo sicut fecisti cum uesica ex expressione cum manu tua, donec perueniat humiditas ad uesicam.	Then bind it in the instrument: and do it like that which you did with the vessel when expressing with your hand, until the humidity has passed into the vessel.
¶ De extractione Lapidis.	¶ On the extraction of the Lapis.
Caput LX.	Chapter LX.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Lapidis, et curationem eius cum medicinis: et dixi differentiam inter Lapidem generatum in renibus, et uesica, et signa illius totius: et dixi Lapidem in quo cadit operatio cum manu et sectio: et est Lapis generatus in uesica proprie: et ille qui figitur in uirga: et ego sum narrans illud cum expositione manifesta et abbreuiatione.	We have already spoken in the treatise on the species of the Lapis, and its treatment with physicians: and we have spoken of the difference between the Lapis generated in the bowels and the uesica, and the signs of the latter: and we have spoken of the Lapis in which the operation is performed with the hand and the section: and the Lapis which is generated in the uesica itself: and that which appears in the abscess. And I shall speak of this with manifest exposition and abbreviation.
Dico ergo, quod Lapis generatus in uesica, plurimum accidit pueris.	I say therefore, that the Lapis which is generated in the uesica, most often happens to children
Et ex signis eius est, quod urina egreditur ex uesica similis aquae in subtilitate sua: et apparet in ea harena alba, et fricat infirmus uirgam suam, et laborat cum ea, et multotiens pendet.	And from its signs it is known that the urine comes out of the uesica like water in its substance: and there appears in it white sand, and the patient feels his wound swelling and throbbing, and he groans with it, and is often fainting
Deinde erigitur, et egreditur cum eo anus in multis eorum.	Then it is erected, and goes out with the anus in many people.
Et est facilis sanatio puerorum, ex eo usquequo consequuntur quatuordecim annos.	Healing is easy for children from this point on until they are fourteen years old.
Et est difficilis in senibus.	It is difficult in old age.
In iuuenibus autem est media, in eo quod est inter illud: et eius cuius Lapis est maior, curatio facilior: et si paruus, est econuerso illius cura.	But in youth it is middle-aged; for that which is between these two is of medium kind: and that which is greater in age, the cure is easier: and if it is slight, the care is less expensive
Cum ergo peruenimus ad curationem, oportet in primis, ut mundificemus infirmum cum clisteri, quod extrahat totum stercus quod est in intestinis suis: ipsum enim quandoque prohibet inuentionem Lapidis apud inquisitionem.	When we come to the cure, it is necessary in the first place to purge the patient with a cathartic, which will evacuate all the stool which is in the intestines: for this indeed often hinders the finding of the stone during inquiry
Deinde accipiatur infirmus cum pedibus suis, et concutiatur, et moueatur ad inferiora: ut descendat Lapis ad profundum uesicae, aut saliat de loco alto aliquotiens.	Then the patient is taken with his feet, and is beaten, and moved downwards: so that the stone may go down to the bottom of the bladder, or may come out from a high place somewhat.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas praeparatum, et manus eius sint sub coxis ipsius, ut fiat uesica tota decliuis ad inferiora.	Then make him sit between your hands prepared, and your hands be under his buttocks, so that the bladder may be entirely inclined downwards
Deinde perquire eum, et tange eum extrinsecus.	Then inquire of him, and touch him externally.
Si ergo sentis Lapidem in spacio, tunc propera statim cum sectione super ipsum.	If you feel the stone in the space, then immediately perform a section above it
Quod si non cadat sub tactu tuo omnino, tunc oportet ut abstergas digitum indicem cum oleo manus sinistrae, si infirmus est puer: aut digitum medium si est iuuenis completus: et intromittas ipsum in anum suum, et perquire de Lapide, donec stat sub digito tuo: et conuerte eum paulatim ad collum uesicae.	If it does not come under your touch at all, then you must remove the index finger of your left hand if the patient is a child: or the middle finger if he is an adult male: and insert it into his rectum, and inquire of the stone, until it is under your finger: and bring it slowly to the neck of the bladder.
Deinde preme super ipsum cum digito tuo, et impelle ipsum ad exteriora aduersus locus, cuius sectionem uis: et praecipe ministro, ut premat uesicam manu sua, et praecipe alii ministro, ut extendat testiculos manu sua dextra ad superiora: et alia manu sua, ut remoueat cutem, quae est sub testiculis in parte a loco in quo est sectio.	Then press above it with your finger, and push it outwards towards the place where the incision is to be made: and command the minister to grasp the bladder with his hand, and command another minister to extend the testicles of his hand to the upper part: and another hand to move the skin which is under the testicles in the part where the incision is to be made.
Deinde intromitte Spatumile incidens, cuius forma haec est.	Then introduce the sponge into the wound, which has this shape.
Et finde in eo quod est inter anum et testiculos, et non in medio, ad latus natis sinistrae: et sit sectio super ipsum lapidem, et digitus tuus sit in ano: et fiat sectio transuersa, ut sit sectio exterius ampla, et interius stricta, secundum quantitatem quod sit possibile egressio Lapidis ex ea non maior.	Then introduce the sponge into the wound, which has this shape. Find in it what is between the womb and the testicles, and not in the middle, at the side of the left hip: and let the incision be above the highest stone, and your finger be in the rectum: and make a transverse incision, so that the external incision is wide and the internal incision is narrow, according to the quantity that it is possible for the stone to issue from it not greater.
Fortasse enim comprimit digitus, qui est in ano Lapidem apud sectionem, et egreditur absque difficultate.	Perhaps the finger that is in the rectum will be compressed by the stone at the incision, and will issue without difficulty.
Et scias, quod ex Lapide est cui sunt anguli et margines, quare fit difficilis exitus eius propter illud.	And you know that the stone has angles and margins, because of which its exit is difficult
Et ex eo est lenis, similis glandulae, et rotundus: et fit facilis egressus eius.	And from this [stone] is soft, like a gland, and round: and its exit is easy
Ei ergo cui sunt anguli, et margines, adde in fissura.	Therefore, to the stone which has angles and margins, add in the fissure
Quod si non egreditur ita, tunc oportet ut ingenies super ipsum: aut stringas super eum cum gesti decenter, cuius extremitas sit sicut Luna, quae stringat super Lapidem, et non euadat ab ea: aut ut intromittas sub eo instrumentum subtile, curuatae extremitatis.	If it does not issue thus, then you must know that you must place something above it: or that you must grasp it with a forceps with a handle like the moon, which grasps the stone and does not slip from it: or that you must introduce an instrument under it, curved at its extremities.
Si autem non potes super cum, tunc amplifica foramen parumper.	If you cannot do this, then enlarge the opening nearby.
Quod si uincit te aliquid ex sanguine, abscinde ipsum cum zegi.	If anything else flows out from the blood, cut it off with a saw
Si uero lapis est plus quam unus, tunc impelle in primis magnum ad os uesicae.	If there is more than one stone, then push out the big one first to the bone of the hip
Deinde incide super ipsum.	Then cut over it
Postea impelle paruum post illud: et similiter fac si sunt plures duobus.	Then push out the small ones afterwards: and do the same if there are more than two.
Quod si magnus est ualde, tunc ignorantia est ut seces super ipsum sectione magna.	If the wound is great, then ignorance is equal to the section above it.
Quoniam accidit infirmo una duarum rerum, aut ut moriatur, aut accidit ei distillatio urinae assidua: proptera, quia non consolidatur locus omnino.	For if a sick man is seized by two things, either he will die, or he will suffer a persistent discharge of urine: because the place is not consolidated anywhere.
Verum administra expulsionem eius, donec egrediatur: aut ingenia in fractura eius cum forficibus, donec extrahas eum frustatim.	But give him an enema to expel it, until it comes out: or take hold of the fracture of it with forceps, until you have driven it out frustrated.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc imple uulnus thure, et aloe, et sanguine draconis: et stringe ipsum, et pone super ipsum pannum infusum oleo et uino, aut oleo rosato, et aqua frigida: ut sedetur apostema calidum.	When you have finished your operation, then put on a coverlet, and aloe, and dragon's blood: and bind it up, and put upon it a soft dressing of oil and wine, or rose water and cold water: so that the swelling may subside
Deinde resupina infirmum super collum suum, et non soluas ligamentum, usque ad diem tertium.	Then rest the sick man on his side, and do not relax the ligaments, until the third day.
Cum ergo solueris ipsum, embroca locum cum aqua, et oleo multo.	When you have relaxed it, stitch up the place with much water, and oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dyafinicon, et unguento basilicon, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with rue balm, and alum, until it heals.
Si autem accidit in uulnere apostema calidum additum, et corrosi, et illi similia: sicut si congeletur sanguis in uesica, et prohibeatur ex eo urina: et cognoscitur illud ex egressione sanguinis cum urina.	If indeed in the wound there is added a soft swelling, and corruption, and such like: as if blood is congealed in the bladder, and is withheld from it: and this is known from the discharge of blood with urine.
Intromitte ergo digitum tuum in uulnus, et extrahe illum sanguinem.	Insert your finger into the wound, and draw out the clot of blood.
Nam si remanet, prouocat ad corruptionem uesicae, et putrefactionem eius.	For if it remains, it causes corruption of the bladder, and its putrefaction.
Deinde ablue uulnus cum aceto, et aqua, et sale: et oppone omni speciei cum eo quod conuenit ex curatione, usquequo sanetur.	Then wash the wound with vinegar, and water, and salt: and apply all kinds of things which are useful for the cure, until it heals
Et oportet in horis curationis totius, ut liges duas coxas, et aggreges, caussa medicinarum quae ponuntur super locum.	And it is necessary in the course of the cure of all these things, that you bind up two thighs, and bind together, the cause of the physicians who put things upon the place.
Quod si lapis est paruus, et sit in meatu uirgae, et figitur in eo, et prohibetur urinae exitus: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod narro antequam peruenias ad sectionem.	If the stone is small and lies in the bladder, and it projects into it, and prevents the discharge of urine: then care for it with that which I have mentioned before until you reach the section.
Multotiens enim a sectione excusaris per hanc curationem, iam enim probaui illud.	You must not evacuate from the section for this treatment, for I have proved it to be effective.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut accipias Perforatorium ex ferro alferico, cuius haec est forma, triangulatae extremitatis, acutum, fixum in ligno.	And it is that you take a perforator of iron, which is triangular at the extremities, acute, and fixed in wood.</start_of_turn>
Deinde accipe filum, et liga cum eo uirgam sub lapide ut non redeat ad uesicam.	Then take a thread, and tie it with it under the stone so that it does not return to the bladder.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte ferrum perforans in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat Perforatorium ad ipsum lapidem: et reuolue Perforatorium manu tua in ipso lapide paulatim: et coneris perforationem eius, donec facias ipsum penetrare a parte altera.	Then insert the perforator into the bladder with ease, until it reaches the stone: and withdraw the perforator gradually from the stone: and make the perforation through it from the other side.</start_of_turn
Urina namque absoluitur statim.	The urine will immediately cease.</start_of_turn>
Deinde preme manum tuam super illud quod remansit ex lapide ab exteriori parte uirgae.	Then press your hand over that which remains from the stone from the exterior part of the bladder.</start_of_turn
Ipse enim frangitur, et egreditur cum urina, et sanatur infirmus.	It will itself break, and go out with the urine, and the infirm will be healed.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non praeparatur tibi haec curatio, propter aliquid quod prohibet ab illo: tunc liga filum sub lapide, et filum aliud supra lapidem.	If however this treatment is not prepared for him, because of something that hinders it: then tie a thread under the stone, and a thread above the stone.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca super lapidem in ipsa uirga inter duas ligaturas.	Then dry over the stone in the very urine between two ligatures.</start_of_turn
Deinde extrahe ipsum.	Then extract it.</start_of_turn>
Postea solue ligamentum, et mundifica sanguinem congelatum, qui fit in uulnere.	Then dissolve the ligament, and bind the frozen blood, which is in the wound.</start_of_turn>
Et non est necessarium ligamentum fili sub lapide, nisi ut non redeat ad uesicam: et ligamentum aliud desuper, nisi ut quando soluitur filum post egressionem lapidis, redeat cutis ad locum suum, et cooperiat uulnus: et propter illud necesse est tibi illud quando ligas filum superius, ut eleues cutem ad superiora, ut redeat apud complementum tuum, et cooperiat uulnus, sicut diximus.	And it is not necessary to tie a thread under the stone, except that it does not return to the bladder: and to tie one above, except when the thread is dissolved after the evacuation of the stone, the skin returns to its place, and closes the wound: and for this reason it is necessary for you to tie that above when you have ligated the thread below, so that you elevate the skin to the upper parts, so that the skin returns to its proper place and closes the wound, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione Lapidis mulierum.	On the extraction of the stone from women.
Caput LXI.	On the extraction of the stone from women.
Parum generatur Lapis in mulieribus.	Stones are rarely generated in women.
Si autem accidat alicui earum lapis, tunc difficilis est curatio, et prohibetur propter modos multos.	If, however, it should happen to any of them that a stone should occur, then its treatment is difficult, and is prohibited by many methods
Vnus eorum est: quod mulier fortasse est uirgo.	One of them is: perhaps the woman is pregnant.
Et secundus est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem quae detegat seipsam medico, quando est casta, aut ex habentibus maritos.	And the second is, because you will not find a woman who will confess to a physician that she has a stone when she is chaste, or out of fear of her husband
Tertius est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem bene scientem hanc artem, praecipue operationem cum manu.	The third is, because you will not find a woman who is well-informed concerning this art, especially the operation with the hand
Et quartus est longinquitas a loco lapidis: quare indiget sectione profunda, et in illo est timor.	And the fourth is the distance of the stone from the place of its origin: because it demands a deep section, and there is fear in that
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad illud, tunc oportet ut accipias mulierem medicam, bene scientem: et parum inuenitur.	If necessity compels you to do that, then you must take a woman physician, who is well-informed: and few are found
Si uero priuaris ea, tunc quaere medicum castum, subtilem, et praesenta mulierem obstetricem bene doctam in re mulierum, aut mulierem quae in hac arte innuit partem artis: fac ergo eam praesentem, et praecipue ei, ut faciat totum quod praecipis ei ex inquisitione super lapidem.	If you do wish to do this beforehand, then seek out a wise physician, discreet, and present to her a skilled woman in matters concerning women, or a woman who has been trained in this art to a certain extent: make her do everything that you have learned from your inquiry concerning the stone
In primis quod est, ut aspiciat si mulier est uirgo: tunc oportet ut intromittat digitum in anum eius, et quaerat lapidem.	Firstly, that she may see if the woman is pregnant: then she must insert her finger into her belly and search for the stone
Si ergo inuenit ipsum, coartet eum sub digito suo, et tunc praecipe obstetrici, ut intromittat digitum suum in uuluam infirmae, et inquirat super lapidem, postquam ponit manum suam sinistram super uesicam, et comprimit eam compressione bona.	If she finds it, she should grasp it under her finger and then command the midwife to insert her finger into the lower belly, and inquire about the stone after she has placed her left hand over the waist and has pressed it firmly
Si ergo inuenit lapidem, tunc oportet ut gradatim moueat eum ab orificio uesicae ad inferiora cum summa uirtutis suae, donec perueniat cum eo ad radicem coxae.	If there is a stone in the bladder, it is necessary that he gradually move it from the orifice of the bladder to the lower parts with all his power, until it reaches the root of the hip bone.
Deinde secet super eum apud oppositionem medietatis uuluae apud radicem coxae, ex quacunque parte praeparatur ei, et sentit lapidem in illa parte: et digitus eius non remoueatur a lapide, coartans sub eo: et sit sectio parua in primis.	Then he should secrete above it toward the middle of the vulva toward the root of the hip bone from whichever side it is prepared for him, and he feels the stone in that part: and his finger does not move from the stone, coiling under it: and let there be a small incision at first
Deinde intromittat radium super illam sectionem.	Then he introduces the radium through that incision.
Si ergo sentit lapidem, tunc addat in sectionem secundum quantitatem proportionatam quod lapis egreditur ab ea.	If he feels the stone, then he adds to the incision according to the quantity that the stone comes out from it.
Et scias, quod species lapidis sunt multae.	And you know that there are many kinds of stones.
Ex his enim est paruus, et magnus, lenis et asper, longus, et rotundus habens ramos.	Among them is the small one, and the large one, the soft one and the rough one, the long one and the round one having a branch.
Scias ergo species eius, ut significetur tibi per hoc super illud quod uis.	You know therefore the kind of these, so that you may recognize them by this sign above that
Si ergo uincit te sanguis, tunc adde in loco zegi tritum, et tene ipsum hora una, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If there is blood, then add in the place of the wound a compress that has been soaked for an hour, until the blood is stopped.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis: et fac, ut praepares tecum ex instrumentis, quae dixi in extractione lapidis in uiris, ut adiuueris per ea in operatione tua.	Then return to your operation, until the stone comes out: and make ready with the instruments that I mentioned in the extraction of the stone from the bladder, so that you may help with these in your operation.
Quod si uincit te fluxus sanguinis, et scis quod expulsio sanguinis est ex arteria quae incisa est: tunc pone puluerem super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis strictura decenti: et non mutes illud: et dimitte lapidem, et non extrahas ipsum.	If there is a flow of blood, and you know that the evacuation of blood is from the artery that was cut: then put powder on the place, and bind it with fine threads: and do not move it: and let go of the stone, and do not pull it out
Fortasse enim morietur mulier infirma.	Perhaps the woman will die.
Deinde cura uulnus.	Then care for the wound.
Cum ergo sedatur acuitas sanguinis post dies, et putrefit locus, tune redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis.	When blood flow subsides after a day and the place putrefies, return to your operation until the bone has healed.
¶ De sectione suiper Herniam aquosam.	In the event of a supernumerary hernia with fluid.
Caput LXII.	Chapter XII.
Ramex aquosa non est, nisi aggregatio humiditatis in sifac albo, quod est sub cute testiculi continente ouum: et nominatur sifac.	A swelling filled with fluid is not a hernia, except for the gathering of moisture under the white membrane covering the testicles which is called a hernia
Et quandoque est in panniculo proprio sibi, quem praeparauit ei natura in parte oui, donec putetur: quod est ouum aliud, et est cutis testiculi inter sifac album, quod diximus: et non fit illud nisi raro.	When it is inside the scrotum itself, which the nature has prepared for it in part or all, until it bursts: which is the testicles themselves, and is the white membrane surrounding the testicles which we mentioned before. And this does not happen except rarely
Et generatio quidem huius ramicis, est ex debilitate quae accidit testiculis: quare effunditur ad eos haec materia.	The origin of this swelling is from the weakness which occurs in the testicles: from which this material flows out
Et quandoque accidit ex percussione super testiculos.	And sometimes from a blow to the testicles
Et haec humiditas est habens colores multos.	And this moisture has many colors
Aut enim est color eius decliuis ad citrinitatem, aut est sanguineus rubeus, aut faeculentus, niger, aut est aquosus albus, et est illud quod est plus.	Or it is of a yellow-orange color, or it is a reddish-brown, or greenish-brown, or black, or white like water, and the like is more
Et signa quibus scitur ubi sit aggregatio aquae, sunt ista.	The signs indicating the presence of such an accumulation of fluid are these
Nam si est in sifac albo quod diximus, tunc apostema est rotundum ad longitudinem parumper sicut figura oui: et non apparet testiculus, quoniam humiditas continet eum ab omni parte.	For if there is fluid in the white membrane which we mentioned before, then the swelling is round like the figure of an egg: and the testicle does not appear, because the moisture contains it from all sides
Et si est humiditas in panniculo proprio sibi, tunc apostema est rotundum cum parte oui, et propter hoc extimat homo quia est ouum aliud.	And if there is moisture in the scrotum itself, then the swelling is round with a part of the testicles exposed, and for this reason the man knows that there is another testicle
Et si humiditas est inter cutem testiculorum et sifac album, tunc cadit sub sensu.	And if the moisture is between the skin of the testicles and the white membrane, then it falls under the sense.
Quando ergo uis cognitionem coloris humiditatis, tunc experire colorem humiditatis in apostemate cum Intromisso quadrato, cuius forma praecessit.	When therefore one desires cognition of the colour of moisture, then to experience the colour of moisture in the apostemate with an introduced square, whose form precedes.
Secundum illud ergo quod egreditur in uestigio Intromissi, iudica de illo quod est inter ipsum.	According to that, therefore as it proceeds in the cavity of the introduced square, judge concerning that which is between them
Cum ergo uenimus ad curationem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, ut phlebotometur si possibile est ei illud, et uides corpus eius plenum.	When therefore we come to the treatment with the iron, then it is necessary to apply pressure to the patient, so that a bloodletting may be performed if possible, and to fill the body with liquid.
Deinde resupinetur super dorsum suum super rem altam parum, et pone sub eo pannos multos.	Then it is rested upon its back upon a high thing, and under it are placed many cushions
Deinde sede tu super sinistram eius, et praecipe ministro, ut sedeat a dextra eius, qui extendat uirgam eius ad unum duorum laterum cutis testiculorum, et ad partem mirach uentris.	Then sit on its left side, and command the attendant, so that he may sit on its right side, who extends the arm of its left side to one of the two sides of the skin of the testicles, and to the part near the navel
Deinde accipe spatumile latum, et seca cutem testiculorum ex medio per longitudinem, usque prope pectinem: et fiat sectio secundum rectitudinem aequedistantis lineae quae diuidit cutem testiculorum, donec perueniat ad sifac album comprehendens: et excoria ipsum et obserua, uel caue ex hoc, ut seces ipsum: et sit excoriatio tua qua ipsum excorias, ex parte quae suspenditur cum ouo plus: et subtiliter scrutare cum excoriatione secundum quantitatem quod tibi possibile est.	Then take a broad spatula, and dry the skin of the testicles from the middle along its length, until almost to the navel: and make a cut according to the rule of an equidistant line which divides the skin of the testicles, until it reaches the white membrane which encompasses it: and scrape it off and observe, or cut through from this, so that you may dissect it: and let your scraping be as great as that which you can manage.
Deinde perfora sifac plenum aqua perforatione ampla, et extrahe totam aquam.	Then pierce the full bladder with a wide perforation, and drain out all the water.
Deinde separa inter duo labia sectionis cum uncinis, et extende sifac ad superiora, et non tangas cutem testiculorum comprehendentem: et incide sifac qualitercunque est possibile tibi incidere ipsum, aut cum totalitate sua, aut frustatim, praecipue latus eius subtile.	Then separate between the two lips of the incision with hooks, and extend the bladder upwards, and do not touch the membrane encompassing the testicles: and cut the bladder in whatever way seems possible to you, or with its entirety, or in pieces, especially its wide side superficially
Nam si tu non exquisite perscrutaris, in incisione eius non fit securitas, quin aqua redeat.	For if you do not carefully examine it, in its incision there will be no security, as the water will return.
Si autem procedit ouum exterius a cute sua in hora operationis tuae: tunc quando compleueris sectionem sifac, reduc ipsum.	If, however, anything external proceeds from its socket in the hour of your operation: then when you have completed the section of the gut, reduce it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cutis testiculorum cum sutura.	Then gather up two lips of the skin of the testicles with sutures.
Deinde cura ipsum sicut reliqua uulnera, donec sanetur.	Then care for it like the rest of the wounds, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si inuenis ouum corruptum ex nigredine alia, tunc oportet ut liges uasa, quae sunt suspensorium, timens fluxum sanguinis.	If you find anything corrupted from the black bile, then it is necessary that you bind up the wound which is the source of the bile, lest the blood flow be delayed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde abscinde testiculum cum suspensorio, et extrahe ouum: postea cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then cut off the testicle with the suspension, and extract the matter: afterwards care for it as we have said.</start_of_turn
Si uero aqua est aggregata in duabus partibus, tunc scias quia sunt duae ramices: seca ergo partem aliam secundum quod fecisti in altera aequaliter.	If indeed water is gathered in two parts, then you know that there are two branches: dry therefore the other part equally.</start_of_turn
Et si aequatur tibi, ut sit operatio una, tunc fac: deinde absterge sanguinem.	And if you make it even, as for a single operation, then do so: then drain the blood.</start_of_turn
Et intromitte in sectiones lanam submersam in oleo, aut in oleo rosato: et pone deforis lanam aliam quam submersisti in uino et oleo, et expande eam super duos testiculos, et mirach uentris: et pone desuper pannos duplicatos, et sunt puluilli: et liga eos desuper cum ligamento, quod est habens sex secundum hanc formam.	And introduce into the sections a soaked lamb's wool in fat, or in rose oil: and put outside the wool another lamb's wool which you have submerged in wine and fat, and expand between the two testicles, and see the belly: and put above them doubled cloths, and are nails: and bind them up above with a ligament, which is having six like this shape.</start_of_turn
Deinde sumantur duo panni, et suantur, et impleantur la na carminata, secundum hanc similitudinem: et fiant extremitates quibus premitur ex coto, aut lana humida: et aggregentur cum strictura in lumbari bracharum: et una extremitatum accipiat super anum usque ad dorsum, et secunda accipiat ad partem pectinis: et duae extremitates super duas coxas inferius, et duae extremitates aliae super duo inguina, et aggregetur strictura tota in lumbari bracharum.	And take away two cloths, and wash, and apply the saffron cloth, according to this likeness: and let the extremities which are carried out from the socket, or wet wool: and gather them with the tightening in the lumbar region of the flanks: and one extremity shall take over upon a buttock until the back, and the second shall take over at the part of the groin: and two extremities upon two lower thighs, and two extremities else upon two buttocks, and gather the whole tightening in the lumbar region of the flanks.</start_of_turn
Et, quandoque artificialiter medicatur haec ramex cum cauterio loco sectionis cum ferro: et est, ut accipias cauterium cultellare subtile, et seces cum eo cutem testiculorum: et est ignitum, secundum quod narrauimus: donec quando detegitur sifac album continens aquam: tunc accipe cauterium, secundum hanc formam.	And when it is necessary to treat these swellings artificially with the cautery in the place of incision with the iron: take the cautery with a fine handle and cauterise the skin of the testicles. When the fat surrounding the testicle has been consumed as much as it can be: then take the cautery once more, this time in the manner we have described.
Assimilatur literae graecae.	And when it is necessary to treat these swellings artificially with the cautery in the place of incision with the iron: take the cautery with a fine handle and cauterise the skin of the testicles. When the fat surrounding the testicle has been consumed as much as it can be: then take the cautery once more, this time in the manner we have described.
Deinde perfora cum eo illud sifac, et est ignitum, donec egrediatur humiditas tota.	When the fat surrounding the testicle has been consumed as much as it can be: then take the cautery once more, this time in the manner we have described
Deinde extende sifac cum uncinis, et excoria cum cauterio subtili ignito, et incide ipsum secundum quod possibile est tibi, donec eradices totum eius.	When the fat surrounding the testicle has been consumed as much as it can be: then take the cautery once more, this time in the manner we have described.
Et caue ex ouo, ne tangat ipsum ignis.	Take care not to touch the tissue with the flame.
Et scias, quod haec operatio est saluior, et longinquior a fluxu sanguinis, et melior quam operatio cum sectione.	You know that this operation is safer and more reliable than incision, and brings about a better result
Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit in hora sectionis, aut in hora cauterii apostema calidum, aut fluxus sanguinis, aut aliquid aliud: tunc oportet ut cures quod contrarietatem tibi facit ex illo cum curatione quae conuenit ei, secundum quod praemissum est.	If, however, you should find resistance to the operation at the time of incision, or afterwards when the cautery is applied, or there is bleeding or some other complication: then you must cure the cause of the complication in the way which is appropriate to it, as has been explained before
Si autem infirmus est timidus, et non expectat super hanc operationem, propter horribilitatem suam: tunc administra perforationem secundum quod ego narro illud: et est.	If, however, the patient is timid and does not expect to survive this operation because of its horror: then administer perforation as I have described above: and this is sufficient
Quando certificatur tibi apud te per illud quod diximus de significationibus, quod ramex est aquosa: tunc oportet quod facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	When you have confirmed that the swelling is aqueous as we have said: then you must make the patient sit up on an elevated seat
Deinde perfora apostema in inferiori parte sui cum spatumili lato: et pone perforationem secundum longitudinem corporis, et sit apertio ampla, donec currat aqua tota.	Then perforate the abscess in its lower part with a wide spatula: and make the perforation according to the length of the body, and let the opening be wide, until water flows out completely.
Deinde pone super locum cotum, et liga ipsum, et dimitte ipsum ut currat residuum aquae: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then place a compress above the place, and bind it tightly, and let it drain out the remaining water: then care for it until the wound is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si autem contrarietas sit egressioni aquae in hora qua perforas ipsam: et non sit illud nisi propterea, quia panniculus albus contrarietatem facit in orificio uulneris, et prohibet exitum aquae: tunc oportet ut intromittas pennam in uulnus, aut instrumentum cum quo extrahitur aqua hydropicorum, cuius forma praecessit: aut adde in operatione uulneris parumper.	If however resistance to the outflow of water exists in the hour when you perforate it: and this does not happen except for the white plug that opposes the exit of water through the wound, and hinders its outflow: then it is necessary that you introduce a needle into the wound, or an instrument with which the watery humour is extracted, whose form has gone before: or that you add in the operation of the wound a little of the aforementioned.</start_of_turn>
Et scias, quod aqua redit, et aggregatur post sex menses, aut circiter eos.	And you know that the water returns and accumulates after six months, or thereabouts.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo aggregatur, tunc pertoretur secundum eundem modum, et pertransibit infirmus dies suos.	When it accumulates again, then it must return in the same way, and pass over the unhealthy days of its life.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Ramicis carnosae.	Note: The provided text does not include the subsequent portion of the sentence, therefore I am unable to translate it.
Caput LXIII.	(The provided text does not include any further content beyond this point.)</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod in sectione super hanc Ramicem, est ex timore perducente ad perniciem in pluribus dispositionibus.	You know that in this section above this Ramus there is fear of producing poison in many situations.</start_of_turn
Quapropter uidetur mihi eius dimissio saluari ex ea.	Therefore its salt is seen to be discharged from it.</start_of_turn
Et ego sum rememorans operationem in ea, et species apostematis.	And I recall the operation in this very matter, and the kind of abscess.</start_of_turn
Dico ergo, quod accidunt apostemata multa in corporibus, ex quibus componuntur testiculi: et fit illud ex caussis multis, scilicet.	I say, that many abscesses happen in bodies, from which testicles are composed: and this happens from a wound of many kinds, namely.</start_of_turn
Aut ex superfluitate acuta, uel acri, quae effunditur ad testiculos.	Whether from acute swelling or from acridness, which flows down to the testicles.
Aut ex percussione.	Or from impact.
Et est color apostematis secundum colorem corporis, et non inuenitur ei dolor: et est apostema graue.	And it is pale according to the colour of the body, and is not painful: and is a grave swelling.
Et fortasse est apostema lapideum, cuius color est fuscus, et non est sensus ei.	And perhaps it is a stone swelling, whose colour is dark, and there is no sensation in it
Et quandoque fit ex nodatione arteriarum, et inflatione earum: sicut iam praecessit eius rememoratio: aut ex inflatione uenarum.	And sometimes it is from the swelling of arteries, and the swelling of the veins: thus is its memory recalled: or from the swelling of the veins
Quod ergo est ex eis ex inflatione arteriarum, cognoscitur per dispositionem apostematis, quando comprimis ipsum digitis tuis.	Which, therefore, is from the swelling of the arteries, is known by the arrangement of the swelling, when you press it with your fingers
Et non oportet ut tangas ipsum prorsus.	And it is not necessary that you touch it immediately.
Illud uero quod fit ex inflatione uenarum, non dispergitur ex eo aliquid apud compressionem cum digitis.	That which is from the swelling of the veins, does not disperse from this by pressing with the fingers
Et iam possibile est, quod super hanc speciem fiat sectio, et super reliquas carnes: et est, ut seces cutem testiculorum.	And it is possible that above this kind of swelling there should be an incision, and above the rest of the flesh: and it is like cutting the skin of the testicles.
Deinde extende ouum ad sursum, et extrahe ipsum cum sifach albo: et libera suspensorium ex uasis, et liga uasa: et incide suspensorium postquam tu liberas ipsum ab omni parte ex partibus oui.	Then spread out the palm of your hand upwards, and pull out the swelling with white silk: and liberate the swelling from the tissues, and ligate the vessel: and cut through the swelling after you have freed it from all parts of it.
Si ergo ouum consolidatum est cum illis carnibus natis, tunc oportet ut attrahas ouum, et incidas ipsum.	If indeed the swelling is consolidated with those natural parts of the body, then it is necessary to grasp the swelling and cut it through
Et si adhaerentia est inter aliquid ex siphaket, aut in eo quod est inter uasa: tunc oportet ut liberes totam illam adhaerentiam, et incidas eam incisione rotunda.	And if there is adhesion between something of the substance of the veins, or in that which is between the vessels: then it is necessary to free the whole adhesion, and to make a round incision
Si autem est natiuitas carnis in loco adhaerentiae quae est retro: tunc oportet ut incidas totum eius, et extrahas ouum, sicut diximus.	And if there is a natural protrusion of the flesh in the place of the adhesion which is behind: then it is necessary to cut through all of that, and pull out the swelling, as we have said
Cum ergo completur operatio tua, tnnc imple uulnus in lana infusa in oleo rosato, et uino: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When the operation is finished, take a walnut and infuse it into the lancet that is filled with fat, and mix it with wine. Then care for the patient with the rest of the treatment until he is healed.
¶ De cura Ramicis, quae est cum Vite.	Take care of the incision, which is with the vite.
Caput LXIIII.	The head of the book is LXIIII
Uitis est apostema inuolutum quadam inuolutione, simile botro, cum mollificatione testiculorum: et fit difficilis super infirmum motus et exercitium, et deambulatio.	A swelling is a swelling that has infiltrated the quadam, similar to a bag of beans, with softening of the testicles: and it makes it difficult for the infirm to move and exercise, and to walk
Et in curatione huius aegritudinis est ex timore, propter illud cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And in the treatment of this swelling is fear, because of which there is recollection.
Verum oportet, ut dicamus operationem in ea secundum quod fecerunt primi.	It is true that we must say that the operation in this case must be as the first ones did
Dico ergo, quod oportet ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	I say therefore, that you must make the infirm sit on a raised seat
Deinde impelle suspensorium testiculorum ad inferiora.	Then push the swelling of the testicles downwards
Deinde tene cutem testiculorum cum digitis tuis, cum uasis quae sunt propinqua uirgae: et teneat ea minister alius, et extendat ea extensione uehementi.	Then hold the testicles with your fingers, with the nails towards the veins: and hold them with another person, and extend them with an extension of the hands
Deinde incide cum spatumili lato acuto sectione transuersa in directo uasorum, donec detegantur uasa.	Then make an incision with a sharp knife with a transverse section in the direct line of the veins, until the veins are detected
Deinde excoria ab omni parte, sicut diximus tibi in extractione Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then scrape away from all parts, as we said to you in the extraction of the arteries when they are in their time
Postea fige in eis acum in qua sit filum duplum, et liga ipsum in primo locorum quibus accidunt Vites: et liga ipsum iterum in ultimo eorum.	Then fix in place a sponge in which there is a double thread, and bind it in the first place where the veins are found: and bind it again at the end of them
Deinde seca ea in media sectione recta secundum longitudinem corporis, et extrahe quod aggregatur ex humiditatibus faeculentis corruptis.	Then dry it in the middle section straight according to the length of the body, and extract what is gathered from the humours of rotten faeces.
Deinde cura uulnus cum curatione reliquorum uulnerum, in quibus uis generari saniem, ut cadant uasa quae nutriunt unum testiculorum.	Then care for the one with the ailment along with the care of the remaining ailments, in which is the desire to generate health, so that the masses that feed one testicle fall away.
Non est enim malum per illud.	There is no evil in that.
Si autem accidat Vitis omnibus uasis, tunc oportet ut extrahantur propter hoc testiculi cum uasis: ut non priuetur ouum nutrimento, propter incisionem, et tabescat, uel arescat, et non sit iuuamentum cum eis.	If, however, the masses fall upon all the masses, then it is necessary to remove the testicles along with the masses: so that they do not be denied nourishment by incision, and that they be destroyed, or that they be damaged, and not be in agreement with them
¶ De cura Ramicis intestinalis.	Of the care of the intestines.
