Caput LXV.	Chapter 65.</start_of_turn>
Euentus huius Ramicis est ex sectione, quae accidit in sifach extenso super uentrem in parte inguinum ex mirach uentris.	The event of this ailment is from the section which occurs in the large intestine above the belly in the groin from the wonder of the belly.
Quare descendunt intestina ex illa Ruptura ad unum testiculorum.	Why do the intestines descend from that rupture to one testicle?
Et haec Ruptura est aut ex sifach, aut extensione eius.	And this rupture is either from the siph or from the extension of it
Et accidunt istae duae species ex caussis multis: aut ex percussione, aut saltu, aut clamore, aut eleuatione rei grauis, et similibus.	And these two kinds of ailments occur from many wounds: either from a blow, or a jump, or a shout, or an elevation of a heavy thing, and the like
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	And the sign when it is from the extension of the siph.
Est quod accidit paulatim in tempore longo, et non accidit subito: et est apostema aequale uersus profundum: propterea, quod sifach comprimit intestinum.	It is that which gradually happens in a long time, and does not happen immediately: and is equal swelling all around: because the siph compresses the intestine
Et signum eius quando est ex sectione sifach, quia facit accidere ex principio sui dolorem uehementem subito: et est apostema diuersum, apparens sub cute propinque: et illud est propter exitum intestini, et cursus eius ad exteriora sifach.	And the sign of it when it is from the section of the siph, because it makes the pain that immediately arises from the beginning: and is diverse swelling, appearing under the skin nearby: and that is because of the exit of the intestine, and its course to the outside of the siph
Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	And when it comes out with the intestine raw: and this is called intestinal rupture, and bursting: and when it is with vomiting.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	When the stool runs into the intestine and remains there, it brings about the suffering of the patient. For it makes the pain of the buttocks grow worse, especially when it is expelled.
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	In the treatment of this disease there is fear of the iron: therefore it is necessary to avoid this situation.</start_of_turn>
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	The method of operation is to expel the main part of the patient's intestine into the concave part of the belly.</start_of_turn>
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	Then it is placed over the hump of the belly between the hands and the flanks are elevated.</start_of_turn
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	Then the skin following the skin to the upper part is stretched out, and the skin of the testicles is completely dried along its length.</start_of_turn
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then two stitches are made at the two corners of the wound, according to what is necessary to open the part with the least amount of damage: and the cutting should be as little as possible, so that it may be expelled from it easily.</start_of_turn
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then the fat and what is under the skin of the testicles is excoriated until the white fat is detected, hard from all parts: then insert your finger into that which follows the testicle, in that which is between the white fat which is under the skin and the fat which is below, and alongside that which is in the back part of the testicle.</start_of_turn
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then move with the right hand the fat inwards towards the skin of the testicles: and with this stretch the white fat upwards, with the left hand: and elevate the testicles with the fat until the part which was cut is reached: and order the minister to stretch the testicles upwards: and you will have solved the adhesion which is at the complete solution.</start_of_turn
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And look with your fingers, that there is nothing left in the white fat or hard fat.</start_of_turn
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If, however, you find something from there: then drive it downwards into the lower belly.
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	If, however, you find something from there: then drive it downwards into the lower belly.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	If, however, you find something from there: then drive it downwards into the lower belly.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	If, however, you find something from there: then drive it downwards into the lower belly

¶ De Ramice uentosa.	If, however, you find something from there: then drive it downwards into the lower belly
Caput LXVI.	Chapter LXVI.
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In the cavity of the rectum, no one has ever dared to perform an operation with an iron.
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	Indeed, the first ones said that it is like what we have told you about the rectum which is with the veins.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	That is, as the veins are ligated below the section above, and dried in the middle, and the operation is completed by opening it up to the end, until the veins have fallen away: and the cautery is applied, as we have already said, until the wound has healed.
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	Concerning the disruption which takes place in the groin.
Caput LXVII.	Chapter LXVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a rupture takes place in the groin, as we have already said, and the place protrudes, and does not descend to the testicles anything from the intestines: and if it descends, it is a little and returns in every hour: however if it is prolonged with this time, an opening is added in the groin, until the intestines descend into the groin
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this happens from the extension of the groin, which is in the groin as we have already said
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	That is, because the groin is stretched: then it is softened, and the place is protruded, and the bulge emerges
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And its treatment is with cautery, as we have already said.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And when it is treated with an iron, in this way: and the patient lies down on his back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then dry the place of the rupture after it has protruded and emerged, by cutting across the width, according to the quantity of three fingers wide
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then ligate the veins which are under the skin, until the groin is white, which is under the skin following it.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then grasp the radium and place it over the prominent place from the sac, and press it down into the depth of the belly.
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then two prominent places will be seen on the extremity of the radium from the sac, and join them with a suture one with the other: then draw out the extremity of the radium.</start_of_turn>
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut through the sac entirely, neither tear any membrane, neither anything else, as I have told you in the treatment of intestinal branches.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then take care of the wound.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When you have cut the suture, bind it up and restore the wound, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	Do not make the wound tense, and do not add prominence to the rupture.</start_of_turn
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And the cautery is better in this place: because it is closer to the vein.</start_of_turn>
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	¶ Regarding the softening of the skin of the testicles.</start_of_turn
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	The skin of the testicles is softened in many people, because the flesh which is between them is softened, and its aspect is improved.</start_of_turn
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for him who is being treated for this to make the patient lie down on his back, and to cut away the softened skin over the natural skin.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then gather together two lips with a suture: and if you wish, remove the excess of softened skin by three or four sutures, and fix the suture.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then cut between the sutures.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then care for the remaining wounds until they are healed, and the stitches will fall out.
¶ De Castratione.	Then care for the remaining wounds until they are healed, and the stitches will fall out.
Caput LXIX.	Then care for the remaining wounds until they are healed, and the stitches will fall out.
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You know that castration is forbidden in our law: and for that reason I will not mention it in this book: and it is not necessary to mention it, except for two cases.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	Except that in the science of medicine, when it is asked about it, and to know its cure when it happens to someone
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And the other case is that we often do not need castration of some animals, because of our love for them, such as horses, gazelles, and goats, and similar animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that castration is done in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by attrition
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by incision and section
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In the former method, the operation is to make the animal sit in warm water, until the testicles soften and become limp, and hang down: then grasp the testicles with your hand and pull them out until they are resolved and no longer appear under the touch
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	But in castration by incision and section, it is necessary to hold the animal firmly, and grasp the skin of the testicles with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then ligate the suspension, and dry over the whole of the incision a single time, until two holes appear: then cut through them after you have scraped away the surrounding tissue. Do not let anything except for the fine blood clot remain on them
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than that by attrition: because attrition sometimes leaves something behind in the testicles which the animal dislikes during coitus
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound until it heals.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	Then care for the wound until it heals.
Caput LXX.	Then care for the wound until it heals.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	Then care for the wound until it heals. For a hermaphrodite is like two wounds.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	Then care for the wound until it heals. For a hermaphrodite is like two wounds because it appears in the place where the space is between the scrotum and the testicles, where there is a figure like a female vulva, which has hair, and from which urine sometimes runs out from the scrotum.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	Then care for the wound until it heals. For a hermaphrodite is like two wounds because it appears in the place where the space is between the scrotum and the testicles, where there is a figure like a female vulva, which has hair, and from which urine sometimes runs out from the scrotum. In women, however, there is one kind, which is like a female vulva placed over the testicles like small testicles altogether, protruding outwards: of which one is like the penis of a man, and two are like two testicles
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the care of three kinds, two of which are from the males, and one from the females, is this: because it is necessary to cut away the added flesh until the impression of these has fled.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then care for the wound until it heals.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	Then care for the wound until it heals. But as for the second kind of wound from which urine comes out, which is in the scrotum, there is no operation, nor any care for it
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	Then care for the wound until it heals.
Caput LXXI.	Then care for the wound until it heals
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	A tentule perhaps is added over the natural thing, until it is eaten away and its aspect is spoiled: and when it is grown in some women so much, until it expands like in the males, and persists until coitus.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is necessary therefore that you tighten the superflous Tentiginis with one finger, or with two, and cut: and do not stop cutting until you have reached the root, especially in deep incisions, lest there should occur a flow of blood.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound itself until it has healed.
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	The carbuncle is a wound which is born in the orifice of the matrix, until it has filled itself up: and perhaps it goes out to the exterior according to the fashion of a tail: and because of this some call it a carbuncle of the tail
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that we cut like we cut the Tentiginis, and care for the wound, until it has healed
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	As for the care of the wound of a woman which is not pierced.
Caput LXXII.	Chapter 72.
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	The alratica is like a wound of a woman which is not pierced, or like a small hole.
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	It is either natural or accidental
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	The accidental one is from a wound which preceded it: and this is either born from flesh added to it, or from fine pus, or from a spiss, and it is either in the deep of the matrix, or in its flanks, or in the upper part of it, or in the lower part of it: and it hinders coition and conception, and delivery, and perhaps hinders menstruation.
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	And the knowledge of this is by the aspect of the obstetrician, if there is an apparent prolapse nearby
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	If not, then inquire with your fingers, or with an X-ray
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	If however the prolapse is from fine pus, and is close to two teeth: then restrain it, and break it
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And it is, that you put over two lips the little cushions.
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then put your fingers of both hands together, and the woman should sit with her back against her thighs spread wide open.
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then stretch out the two lips with force, until the soft tissue is broken and the hair is opened up.
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	Then take the sponge, and soak it in oil, and put it on the place: and the woman should keep it moist every day, so that it does not harden in another place
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	If, however, the soft tissue is thick and tough: then it is necessary that you cut it out with a blunt knife like the edge of a myrtle leaf.
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	If, however, the hair has sprung from the flesh: then suspend the oil with the nails, and cut it: and be with physicians who can stop the flow of blood without causing a wound, such as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus aggregated with alum or white of egg.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then give a wide lead pencil made of lead, so that it does not adhere to the wound too quickly, keep it for a few days: and give a decoction of dry rue, then care for the rest of the cure, until it is healed
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when the birth of other flesh occurs in the womb: it is necessary therefore that they be cut according to this method: while there is no cancerous tumor that is in the womb, do not make opposition to iron in any way whatsoever
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	With regard to the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil, and Bothor of the red in women's buttocks
Caput LXXIII.	(The remaining text is not included in the request.)
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Hemorrhoids are indeed a bursting of the veins, because there is much blood flowing from them.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When many are affected with hemorrhoids, they become little ones: and I have already spoken of the kinds of these and their signs: and I will now tell you what they receive for treatment and what they do not.
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say then, that those hemorrhoids which are in the rectum and are not visible to the sense: then there is no treatment for them with iron
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	Those, however, which are in the rectum above which the sense falls, are those which are cured.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary therefore that you put the woman in a cold house.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then extend the little ones with forceps, or with rough cloth, and cut away their roots.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then powder over the wounds with some of the powder from one incision without causing any damage: like acacia, and the blood of a dragon, and thus, and similar things.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then compel her feet to the wall for one hour.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Then put her in cold water afterwards
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the bleeding persists: then make her sit in a decoction of rue, and nutmeg seeds, and barley, and similar things.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take barley flour, and mix it with honey and vinegar, and make a plaster with it over her back
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If blood is thereby detached with it, that is good: and if not, make them adhere to the swelling, and blisters, without scarification
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take wool, and soak it in pitch juice, or in pomegranate juice, or in the juice of elderberry leaves, that is, aglanter, pontico wine, and make them adhere to the wound.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When the limb is quiet after the incision, then care for the place with unguents until it heals.
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	When the limb is quiet after the incision, then care for the place with unguents until it heals.
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that you cut away what appears from it, as I have said before, and care for the place, until it heals.
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	Regarding the perforation of the uterus which occurs in the matrix.
Caput LXXIIII.	Chapter LXXIV.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	There are many kinds of abscesses which occur in the matrix, such as cancer, and stone abscess, and ulcer, and tumours, and carbuncles, and herpes, and haemorrhoids, and fistula, and thelia, and abscesses which are cold to the touch
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I will say concerning all these ailments and their kinds, their signs and their treatments in general: it is necessary to speak of the cold abscess which occurs in the matrix, when it is from abscesses which join health, and how it is opened with a knife
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary therefore to consider it
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	When the pain of the abscess is acute at its beginning, with percussion, flame and fever: and you see it turn red: if it falls outside of its sense, do not attempt to perforate it: care for it with something which will promote its maturation, until the acute pain has subsided
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	When it is necessary to make her sit on a chair which supports two chairs, and to recline, or to place her on her back, and to bring her feet down to the lower part of the belly: and let her hips be spread out, and put her arms under her armpits, and bind both her ligaments conveniently to that
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then let the obstetrix sit at the right side and handle the instrument which opens the opening of the uterus.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Whose shape comes in the shapes which are after it
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is necessary when you are about to handle this instrument, so that the liver rests upon the Radio of the deep matrix of the woman: so that there is not that which enters through the instrument more than that which is deep in the matrix, and that harms the lower part.
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	But if the instrument is thicker than the depth, then it is necessary to put sponges upon the covering of the deep matrix: in order that the entrance of the whole instrument into the depth of the matrix be obstructed: and it is necessary to put a sponge, which runs in the instrument, from the upper side: and to hold the instrument, and to rotate the minister of the sponge, until the depth of the matrix is opened
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When therefore the Exitura appears, and it is grasped by the hand, and is soft and gentle: then it is necessary to cut it off at its head with a broad spatula.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When therefore the pus is evacuated, then it is necessary to put into the wound a piece of lint submerged in saffron oil: or in olive oil, in which there is some astringency: and put on the lint, and draw out the section from the depth of the matrix.</start_of_turn>
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And put externally upon the matrix, and upon the abdomen wool soaked in water, in which are bad blood clots.</start_of_turn>
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then care after two days with an unguent that agrees with it, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And when the matrix and the wound are washed, it is to be plastered with water and honey: then with water in which is the radix of lily, or long aristolochia: then return to the unguent.</start_of_turn
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	If a vein is hidden deep within the matrix, it is necessary to prohibit treatment with iron, and indeed to treat it with that which we mentioned in the discourse.
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	How a doctor should treat fetuses which emerge in an unnatural form from their mothers' wombs.
Caput Lxxu.	Chapter Lxx.</start_of_turn>
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	An Obstetrician must first recognise the natural form of childbirth.</start_of_turn>
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	When a woman is in labour and she desires to smell the air and moves her head above what is above her, and makes haste to bring forth the child: then you know that this birth is of a natural form, and that the head comes forth first, and the second after.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When you see these signs, then it is necessary to grasp the uterus, so that the fetus may descend more quickly.</start_of_turn
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when the head comes down, the second part also comes down with it, and they go out with these excessive movements in a good delivery.</start_of_turn
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	Whoever is outside of this delivery is unnatural and harmful.</start_of_turn
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For when the fetus comes out on his feet, and his body comes out before his head, and his feet and hands together, or one of his feet: or his head and hand together: or his belly comes out: and perhaps he turns over his neck, and is similar to those figures which are harmful.</start_of_turn
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to be prudent and cautious in all these matters, and to avoid error and miscarriage: and I show you all the figures and the wit which is in them, and I signify it by this, and I stand over it.</start_of_turn
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the fetus emerges from its head during its natural delivery and grasps the woman, and its delivery becomes difficult for her, and the man's power is slackened: then let the man sit down, or the women hold the man: and let them vaporize the woman's breath with fumigation of incense and with oily unguents.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the obstetrician inserts his fingers between the fetus's toes and finds the navel, and cuts it with his nail, until it runs clear of the moisture: and he presses the woman's abdomen until the fetus descends
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If it does not descend, then it is necessary to cause the woman to strain with a suppository of incense, with poppy seeds.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then command her to strain after the suppository: and let her clench her abdomen with concentration, and grasp her teeth and nose for an hour.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	The fetus will immediately emerge.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If two hands of the fetus emerge at the first, it is necessary to reduce them gradually with ease
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If it does not obey in delivery, then let the woman sit down, and lift her feet above her head: then sit down on the earth: and the woman shall be held, that she may not fall from the shock
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If, however, the hands do not emerge, and the fetus dies: then cut off the hands, and extract the fetus: and bind the hand with cloth, and extract it with evenness: for it will emerge by itself
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The exit of the fetus from its feet
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus emerges from its feet, then it is necessary to push it upwards: then gradually turn the fetus: afterwards straighten it out.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then he shall grasp one foot of it and extend it gradually.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When they are gone up to the hips, then command him to bend, so that he may be compressed, and make him draw in: they will go out again, if God wills it.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	And if they do not go out with that, then gradually reduce the foot, until you have set it according to the natural form
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For it will go out of itself when its time comes.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	If it is opposed by all this, then take hold of the upper part of the wound with the thumb and index finger, and with the other hand take a sponge dipped in oil and gum Arabic: and strike all over the wound with a good blow: then lay over it the palm of the woman's hand, and the lower part of her belly.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make him sit in warm water, until the hypocondria follows
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When the lower parts are relaxed by the warmth, then make him drink a mixture of myrrh: and put him to bed.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When an hour has passed, then make him sit on a seat.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make him draw in: and bind his jaw and nose: and press the lower part of the belly with ease
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the foot will go out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	The foot comes out over the knee and hand.
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When it comes out in this form, then put your hand in slowly
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman lies down on his neck, and hangs his feet down: and she herself lies down on the bed, and puts her hands together
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then first above the belly of it slowly.
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then withdraw that which is under its feet from the heel, until it is prepared in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not come out, then grasp its feet and move them by movement of the hand
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then first above the navel slowly, until the fetus ascends to the upper part
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then insert your hand inside, and stabilize the fetus slowly: and command the woman to compress, until the fetus comes out.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The fetus comes out lying sideways from the hands
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	It is finished with the reduction of its hand
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	If however it is not possible to reduce it, then elevate the woman, and make her walk
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If she is indeed unable to walk, then make her lie down on the bed: and strike her thighs with the hand of the other hand
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then administer the unguents which you prepared from the mucilage.
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she bears a part, then make her sit on a seat
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then stay in the reduction of the hand, and stabilize the fetus according to the natural figure: and command the woman to compress, and tell her to breathe, until it comes out
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The fetus comes out over its collar, with its hands spread out, and its face is towards the back of the mother
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	The midwife must hold the foot of the fetus, then slowly turn it around, and stabilize it with ease
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When it is thus stabilized, then place over its vulva what we have mentioned of the wax and mucilage
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then command him to move slowly.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done that, then make him sit down on a chair, and command him to lean to his right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then command him to breathe: and make him clench his abdomen with his hand
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The fetus is prepared on the right side
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it has descended to the birth opening in this way with the second hand, then cut the second one with your nail until it is evacuated from the moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If it is suspended on the face of the fetus and its neck, then cut it from the navel: so that it does not remain and die
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then push the fetus inwards, until you place your hand according to what is necessary: and command the woman to compress herself slightly: I myself will come out through the easy way.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The birth of twins, or many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are often born: and sometimes three or four are born.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	This is extraordinary, and rarely happens.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Five or more is a thing beyond nature, and does not endure: and it contains these [fetuses] which, although multiplied, are one: and they are separated by the navel cord of each of them
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And sometimes they come out like a single fetus through a natural birth: easily: and sometimes they come out through an unnatural birth, as we have said.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If there are any difficulties with some of them at the birth, and they arrive at that which we have mentioned from unnatural figures, then care for them as we have said: and let the midwife be gentle, and do what she does with ease and delay, and adapt to every figure as she is prepared for it from the ingenuity guiding her to safety
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remember that its formation is in the womb from embryos, and it is aborted.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	When it is formed in the womb, one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, and many ten: and I have seen that a woman has aborted seven, and another fifteen, all of them being formed
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	Since it is established by the measurement of a glorious wise man.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	Therefore all this must be known in the science of Obstetrics.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps it will come to the like of this: let it be opposed to that which must be opposed to it.
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	Of the extraction of a dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter LXXVI.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you care for a dead fetus with medicine as I have said in the discourse, and it does not go out, and you must do it by operation with the hands, then you must consider
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If a healthy woman is virtuous, and there is no other cause for fear of loss of life: then you must cause the woman to lie down over the bed, over her back, and let her head be inclined downwards, and her legs be raised: and the minister should hold the patient firm from two parts, or bind her to the bed, so that her body is not pulled out during the extraction of the fetus
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the os matricis with oily things with high mucilage, with alum, and poppy seed meal.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then let the Obstetrician wet his hand with these things and oils: then he will introduce it into the womb with ease
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then seek the place where the nails of the fetus are fixed, and the convenient place for it
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Consider therefore at all times, if the fetus is prepared to descend upon his head: then fix the hooks in his eyes, or in his neck, or in his mouth, or in his palate, or under his beard, or in his armpits, or in the nearby parts of his ribs, and under his navel.
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If he has descended upon his feet, then in the flanks and the middle ribs.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	It is necessary to hold the hook with the right hand: and place the curvature of his hand in that which is between the left thumb and little finger: and introduce it with the thumb with ease, and fix the hook in some of those places which we mentioned until it reaches the desired thing
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	Then fix the other or the third hook, if necessary: so that there is an equal tension, and it does not incline to one side.
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	Then extend the extension equally, and do not let it extend only according to the rule of the straight line, but move it to all parts, so as to alleviate his exit: just as it is done with a tooth when extracting it.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it is necessary at that point to soften the extension.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	Which if it is retained from that part, then it is necessary for the obstetrician to grasp some of his fingers with his thumb and introduce them from the side, so that he may rotate with what is retained
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If therefore his part of the fetus comes out, then exchange the hooks to another place which is higher: do this until the whole fetus comes out
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If therefore his hand comes out before the other, and it is not possible to reduce it because of its adhesion: then it is necessary to cover over his hand with the palm of the hand
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then extract the thumb when it goes out, either at the joint of the thumb and the palm, or in the cubit: and so it should be done in the other hand, and in both feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If however the head of the fetus is large, or if there is a constriction in its exit, or if there is water in its head: then it should be introduced between the fingers of Spatumile spinosum, and find with it the head, and extract the water: or break it with the instrument which is called Almisdac: whose form comes with the forms of the other instruments in the following chapter.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Likewise do this if the fetus is of great head size: then it should be severed with the clamp: or extract it with the hook, as we have said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then draw out the bones with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	When the head comes out, and is caught at the collar: then it is found, until the humidity which is in the chest is discharged
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	If however it does not become complicated, neither obeys the exit: then cut off the head roughly, as much as possible for you
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If however the lower belly is apostemated, or there is water in it: then it should be perforated, until the humidity comes out from it.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	If however the fetus is above his feet: then its traction is easy, and its direction to the maternal bone is smooth
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	If however it is constricted in the belly, or the chest: then it should be extracted with the cloth which you have covered over your hand: and find the belly, or the chest, until it comes out naturally
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If however the rest of the limbs are delivered, and the head returns: then the Obstetrix puts in his left hand.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If any opening is found in the matrix, then the hand is introduced into the depth of the matrix, and it grasps with the head, and pulls it until it reaches the os of the matrix. Then one or two hooks are introduced into it, and it is pulled with them.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If the os of the matrix is closed, because of a thick clot that has happened to it: then it is not necessary to toil over it, rather it is necessary to administer an effusion of moist things, fats: and administer plasters. And sit in the waters that soften and moisten them.
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus is above its side, then it is possible to equalize it: then the thing which we said concerning the fetus above is administered for it
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If it is not possible to do this, then a perforation is made carelessly, and it is extracted
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And it is necessary that you do not let anything escape from the second part altogether.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have completed your operation, then administer what we said concerning the cold clots which happen in the matrixes.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If blood flows, then descend into the styptic waters, and administer the rest of the treatment.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I myself have seen a woman in whom there was a dead fetus: then it was impregnated over her again with oil, afterwards the other fetus also died.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	It happened to her after a long time that a clot formed in her navel, and it became inflated, until it opened: and pus began to emit from it.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I was called to treat her, and I treated her for a long time: and it did not consolidate.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I placed over it some strong-adhesive plaster: and it came out from its place.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then some days passed by, and another bone was discharged.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I am amazed at this, for there is no bone within.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I think therefore, because there were dead bones of a fetus within.
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I asked the woman, and she extracted many bones from me, which were in a better position: and I did so without pain for a long time, and I sent out a little pus from that place.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I did not touch this foreign thing, except that there is knowledge in it, and help for that which the skilled physician gives with his hands from the art of healing.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	Concerning the forms of the necessary instruments for extracting a fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter 77.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here below is the form of the Strictor, with which the books are equaled, having two rings equally distant at the extremities of two sticks.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	Indeed these rings must be subtler than the strictor: and that they may be made either of ebony or of seasoned wood
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And the width of each stick is like two fingers: and the margin of each of them is like a single finger, and the length of each of them is from the wrist to the middle of the palm: and in the middle of the two sticks are two additional pieces of the same kind of wood, which are fastened in both, whose length is half the palm and a little less: and the width of each is like two fingers, or less
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	And these two additions are introduced into the matrix bone, so that it opens when you rotate the two rings.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	The form of the ring which opens the matrix
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Another form like that, subtler and smoother.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	Made from ebony wood or horn, according to the shape of the forceps.</start_of_turn>
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	Indeed, at its extremities there are two appendages, as here above: and the length of each appendage is like the palm of the hand, and the width of each is like two fingers.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When you wish to open the matrix with this, then make her sit over a lectum, with her feet hanging down, and open what is between her thighs.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then introduce these two appendages joined together into the matrix: and you hold the lower extremity of the instrument between her thighs.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, like you do with forceps, equally according to the quantity of the opening of the matrix, until the Obstetrix wishes to stop.</start_of_turn
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	Another kind of Vertigo is called "Impelling Force" by the ancient writers.</start_of_turn
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The "Almisdac" form, by which the great head is countered: and it is assimilated to the forceps, which have teeth at the extremities, like the hooks.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And when it is oblunged, like the forceps in this form, like the hooks, which have teeth like those of a saw, with which it incides and counters.</start_of_turn
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The "Almisdac" form by which the small head is countered.</start_of_turn
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The surrounding form which has one spine.</start_of_turn
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The surrounding form which has two spines.</start_of_turn
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The forceps form which has teeth like those of a saw, with which the fetus's head is countered.</start_of_turn
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The form of the Spatumilis has two extremities to abscind the head.
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The form of two Spatumilis also has two extremities.
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	These instruments are all used, and the more numerous the kinds of them are that are prepared by the artificer, the faster will be the operation and the greater will be its effect on men, on account of their quantity
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	There is no need to despise any of these instruments, for they are all prepared for you
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	It is not unreasonable to expect these things of them
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	About the extraction of the Second
Caput LXXVIII.	Head LXXVIII
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the Second is retained in the part, then it is necessary to grasp the lower part, in order to retain the breath
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make the incision with the forceps: and grasp the hand over his jaw, and take hold of his breath.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If he comes out through this, that is good
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then grasp his head, and pierce in the middle of the cheek: and place in it herbs that open the bone like fennel, rue, and plantain, and chamomile, and hyssop, and cassia twig, and centaury: grasp all these herbs, or some of them, and immerse them with water, and place them over fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then place a poultice of reeds over the hole of the cheek and the other extremity in the bone of the matrix: and hold it until the vapor has reached the depth of the matrix
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make the incision as we have said before
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	The Second will come out easily
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If, however, after this treatment, the patient remains and does not depart: then command the Obstetrician to immerse his hand in pure sesame oil, or in high mucilage.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then plunge it into the belly, and seek with it the Second [i.e., the uterus].
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When it has grasped it, then take hold of it, and extend it little by little.
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If, however, the appendix be in the depth of the belly, then plunge the hand in, as we have mentioned, until it grasps the Second [i.e., the uterus], and draw it out little by little along the straight line, so that the belly does not tear from excessive tension: it is necessary therefore to mix [the procedure] with facilitating movements towards the right and left: and afterwards add in the quantity of tension.
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	It will then obey, and be restored, and depart from the adhesion.
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	As for the os of the belly being closed [i.e., contracted], as we have mentioned: care for it with sternutation, and from an oil medication with herbs.
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	If, however, it does not depart with all that we have mentioned: then beware lest you tire yourself out in the course of the extraction process.
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	It is true that it should depart from the os of the belly to the woman's hip.
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then administer an enema with four drugs.
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	This will cause the belly to soften after a few days, and dissolve, and depart
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	Indeed when it has putrefied, it will emit a foul smell from the belly and head, and will cause pain which will make the patient weak.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	It is necessary therefore that suitable fumigations be administered for this.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the ancient experts are experienced in fumigation with nasturtium and dried figs.
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The form of the instrument with which a woman is fumigated for the retention of the second [menstrual] blood and the period.
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let it be like a cauldron, or a jar: and put the wide end over the flame: and let the fumigation rest on the berries: hold it there until the fumigation is consumed: and do it again another time
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	Concerning the care of an unpierced animal
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter 79.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys are born with their nails unpierced, whom I have seen to have been oiled with subtle saffron.
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	It is necessary therefore that the midwife pierce that nail with her finger: and if not, pierce it with the pointed Spatumili: and beware tears, lest it touch him
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then put upon it infused wool in wine and oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the nails, until it is healed.
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	If indeed it is to be oiled, then put in the hole a lead cannula for many days, and take it away when the boy wants to urinate.
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And indeed the oiling of an animal may also be from the consolidation of the wound, or after-effect.
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	It is necessary therefore that the consolidation be dried, then care for it as we said before concerning the care and lead
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	Concerning the care of fistulas which happen in the lower part
Caput LXXX.	Chapter 80
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Fistulas which happen in the lower part are Nodulation and Swelling which happen near any limb: or in the space of one part: and there is one fistula, or more
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When the old Nodatio is relaxed, it opens and white watery moisture or subtle pus issues from it.
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	Or when there are penetrating fistulas from them.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	They are recognized by that which comes out with the discharge and by swelling, when the patient is in pain: and perhaps comes out with worms.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	There are fistulas when they extend from the penetrating area to the cavity or to the muscle of the belly
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And from the penetrating area to the hip joint, and to the knot of the tailbone
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	From this, however, it is recognized that the penetrating fistula is known until it reaches the anus, even if it is not penetrating, as when you insert your finger into the anus: and you insert a needle sub-externally into the fistula from outside.
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	If there is a twist in it, then introduce in the gut a lead needle or a hair from a horse's tail until you feel the needle or hair, or until the hair comes out on your finger
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not feel the needle itself, neither that anything comes out with the discharge, neither swelling, neither worms as I have said: then you know that it is not penetrating: take care of the cure then.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	When the fistula is penetrating until the cavity or the bladder muscle: then its meaning is the discharge of urine from it, and the prohibition of this so that the place may be consolidated with the physicians.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	When it is penetrating until the hip joint or the hip bone: then its sign is that the attempt reaches up to this point, if there is no twist up to the bone: and a sensation of pain in the circumference of the part, and that pus always comes out from it: and that there is no benefit in it from the medication, neither is it consolidated with oil
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	In these penetrating fistulas, there is no complete cure: the cure is toil and perseverance from the stupid doctors who form them.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	In these non-penetrating and non-ancient fistulas, healing is expected with a clamp: as I have said before, and as I have proved: let the patient lie between your hands over his belly: elevate his limbs until above his knees, and let his knees bend towards his belly
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then introduce lead or air into the fistula, if there is a tortuousness in the fistula, until you know where it ends.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If, however, the patient feels around the belly, then you must introduce your finger into the belly.
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If you feel in your finger that it is attempting to penetrate through the recognized area, except for what you feel between your finger and the flesh, or carrion: then you know for certain that it is penetrating: there is no work in this, because it is not its cure, as we have said
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They say that in some people, the cure is in the flesh itself, and from the medicine which is expected to be applied: thus you should apply gentle cautery under the breadth of the fistula, as has been said before, and introduce the flame itself into the fistula until it disappears from around the belly
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then do this twice or thrice, until you know that all the fatty flesh which is similar to the veins of a bird's wing has been consumed by the filter.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then care for it with buttered bandages until those fatty tissues have gone: then care for it with unguents that generate flesh and consolidate.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If it heals well, that is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	If not, it does not recover with any other treatment at all.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	If not, it does not recover even if you take away the finger that is in the groin and that is between the thumb and the fleshy swelling from the bone, or if you lance it: and you should know that if you do this, dry the skin from the start of the fistula, and take away the fleshy swelling with the thumb that is in the fistula, until the drying out reaches the end of the swelling, and the fleshy swelling is freed.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then wash the surrounding flesh thoroughly, so that no pus remains from the cannula of feathers of birds.
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If, however, blood flows and mixes with you and the operation, so that you must cut through the flesh: then it is better that you cauterize with fire or with acute medicine.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For indeed, cauterization with fire unites the good habits, brings together the added flesh, and stops bleeding, and dries up moisture
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then care for it with cloths dipped in butter, or with bruised grapes, until the place discharges pus, and the added flesh is expelled in the pus.
