Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then care for it with solid bandages, containing substances that promote the formation of tough flesh: and these are medicines that have stypticity and drying qualities.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	For when it is healed, then it is cured: and not by doing it repeatedly.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	If, however, the fistula has persisted to the depth of the abdomen, and has become prolonged by the excess of the body: then insert your finger into the abdomen and inquire about it
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	If you feel the fleshy swelling and between you and the fistula is close to penetration: then there is no operation in this case, except according to the degree of trust and hope
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	Whatever is done by one of three methods: either by cauterizing it as we have said; or by dissecting it until its concavity is complete, so that one may afterwards insert instruments and perform the cure.
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	Proceed not too far with the dissection, lest you cut through the membrane of any organ, and cause an unfavorable outcome of the evacuation without the will of the patient
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for that which we have said.
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps it will recover: or you may stretch the membrane and cleanse it when dry, as we have said, or with hooks, or with some other sharp instrument.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then cleanse the excised tissues which are in the dissection, until fat remains only with the scarp.
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	Then endeavor to restore the entire wound with the dissection, and the upper orifice where it is closed: and there will remain an open fistula in the inner part of the anus, and it will be easier over the infirmity.
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	And when the fistula is sutured in this way: that is, when you insert a hook into the fistula: and it is on the side of the anus around the surface of the body with the skin and the margin of the anus: then grasp the hook with the perforating extremity, which is like a needle, that is, prepared for cutting the skin, in this shape
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	And insert into it a thread of silk wound from five threads, and pass it around it.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	Then insert the hook with the thread into the fistula, until its concavity is complete
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If, however, it is penetrating into the inner margin of the anus, then draw out the thread from that hole: so that you may insert your finger into the anus, and draw out the extremity of the thread, and join the two extremities together: and bind them so that neither slips, and leave it like that for one day, or two days: and the more the thread has penetrated the flesh, the better you must bind it, until those parts of the flesh which are between the two extremities of the thread have become soft and fallen away: then care for the wound, until it is consolidated and healed
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	If the opening of the Fistula is not penetrable: then make it so in whatever way is prepared for you, except that it be in great depth.
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	Except that it be in great depth, make it so in whatever way is prepared for you
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Except that it be in great depth, make it so in whatever way is prepared for you until it is healed.
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	The form of the spindle which is found in the Fistula, whose curvature is acute upwards and the other part is not acute, so that it does not damage that which is not necessary, like urine.
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	Concerning the suture of Hemorrhoids from which blood runs from the incision of them: and the care of the incisions.
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter 81.
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are Hemorrhoids in two ways.
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	They are either inside the rectum, like pieces of charcoal or prunes, or they are like the seeds of the lotus
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And they are either small or large: and blood runs from them always, and there is one, and there are many
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	And they are outside the rectum, and at their extremities
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	However, those which are outside the rectum are mostly small and emit yellow urine, or a slight flow of blood: and they are according to the colour of the body.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And the care of those which are inside the rectum is to make the patient sit upright: and to expel, until the anus goes out, and they appear small to you
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore hold it suspended with hooks: or hold it with your finger
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut it at the root of them
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	If they do not remain within the loop due to moisture of the wound and their softening: then cover them with rough cloth or a coat of lanolin from wool, and extract them with your fingers.
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut them out, and powder over them after cutting whatever powder you wish, so that they remain in place like cautery
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them as it is written in the chapter on cautery.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the wound with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	If it does not obey the anus in its evacuation, then instill a small dose of laxative in the belly where there is a bite, so that it will be evacuated quickly, when the infirmum discharges itself
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If they are outside the anus, then it is easy: grasp them with your finger or with a loop, and cut them off.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for the wound as we have said, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And whoever dislikes an incision with a knife, then he must administer a suture of them in this way.</start_of_turn
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take a thread that has been wound up, and introduce it into the hollow.</start_of_turn
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw out the little ones upwards, and make it penetrate with the needle at its root from the other side: and tie two knots of the thread at the lower part of the needle, and let them be lateral: and tighten the little one tightly.</start_of_turn
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then knot the thread, and draw out the needle.</start_of_turn
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the little ones, and discharge from the wound one at a time: neither their own, lest there should be excess blood from it.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place above the wound a soaked sponge in rose-water, or vinegar, and place the sponge above the wound: and command the patient to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then leave it until it falls off naturally.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When they fall off of themselves, care for them with unguents, and leave the rest of the treatment until they are healed.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	Of the care of wounds.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Many are caused by the evacuation of stool, and the constriction of nature.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When they are thus diminished, and do not avail themselves of medical treatment: then it is necessary to apply mustard seeds with the thumb, or with your finger, until they are softened, and the outer layer which hinders adhesion is removed.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for the wound, until it is consolidated as it should be.</start_of_turn
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If, however, they do not consolidate: then repeat the wound with greater reason than at first, until they bleed much, and are then cleansed with care, until they are healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	Of the care of burns of the body, not of the wound: and of blisters, and of ants.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter 82.</start_of_turn>
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	You know that a burn is not anything but a round knot according to the colour of the body, like the head of a nail: and it occurs throughout the body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and the fingers: and it occurs from pain during walking.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	It is necessary therefore to cut around the nail and hold it with forceps, or with a needle, and extirpate it from its root.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then care for that: and if you wish to cauterize it, do so as it precedes in its chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	And thus there is always one prominence which is small, rough, filtered, and rounded above the surface of the body
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And they are found in the hands of children many times
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its care is that you extend the prominence and break it: or bind it with a silken thread: or with hair, until it falls off
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what is mentioned with fire, or with sharp medicine: and thus you will eradicate the reversed prominence, and not the natural one, with the instrument which I shall mention.
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	There is also a small, filtered prominence, large, above the surface of the body, which extends downwards into the depths: and when it encounters cold, it feels like the bite of a flea, and it causes pain throughout the body: and most of it happens in the hands
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its care is that you take a needle from the wing of a bird, or a strong hair, and put it over the Flea, until the circle of the needle encompasses part of it
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then withdraw your hand with the needle, until you have severed what is around the Flea: and you put it deep into the flesh, and you extract the Flea from its root
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, do it with an air needle, or a needle of iron, according to this form.
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the needle reach the tip of the swelling, so that it alleviates the tension on the finger and its retraction
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish, cauterize the Flea according to what is mentioned in the chapter on cauterization of the prominence
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	Concerning the forms of instruments which are administered to Clisteria in ailments of the soul, and the solution of the inner parts, and the colic.
Caput LXXXIII.	Concerning the forms of instruments which are administered to Clisteria in ailments of the soul, and the solution of the inner parts, and the colic.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When Clistera is made from silver, or gold, or blown glass, or hammered out.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And when made from these instruments, small and large, according to those which are administered
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	This is done in the treatment of young children who are feeble or painful, as well as Clisteria themselves
Clistere magnum.	A large Clistera
Cistere paruum.	A small Clistera
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The upper head of it in which the uterus is bound, be wide in this way: and there should be a distinction so that the uterus is bound like water, and its lower extremity which goes into the belly, be dull, that is, not open, soft, gentle, stretching to thinness: and on one side there are two holes, and on the other side one hole
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And the width of the hole be according to the thickness of the ribs, and less broadly, and the uterus in which the medicines are placed from the animal's urine: or from paper like the asphodel of the small one: whose root is a single palm.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And it is perforated with many holes as it is rolled about, and there is space between every hole as wide as a finger
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into these holes a strong thread from raw thread, which be from ten threads, or about these, and bind together with it the uterus like asphodel.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When it is thus placed in this uterus, it is strung in the head of the Clistera between two distinguishing constrictions of strength.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then cleanse the wound with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the form of the circle which is here drawn, and of the holes.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of the cleansing with it is: that you apply either a portion of earth or a medicine which is warmed according to the quantity of the patient's tolerance: and take care that it is neither too hot nor too cold, neither too warm nor too cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the patient lies on his back, and lifts his legs up towards the shoulders: and put under it fat, that is, skin which men lie upon, or linen
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then wash the limb with oil, or with alum or with mucilage of barley, or like these.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert it into the wound with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then take hold of the limb with both hands and press it with pressure, until it has evacuated everything which is in the wound into the intestines
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then remove the Clister and lift the patient's legs to the side
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	And if the medicine orders you to leave it, then keep it as much as you can
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps with it all night, it is most excellent in healing
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you cleanse it with the solution of vinegar and it speeds up its healing: then cleanse it again until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	And if there are hemorrhoids or painful abscesses in the year: then let the Clister be subtle and cold, soft, from the Clisters which are used to cleanse children.</start_of_turn>
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of the subtle Clister which is over the strict skin.</start_of_turn>
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the treatment of head wounds without fracture of the bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Head wounds without bone fracture.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already spoken concerning the treatment of wounds in general, which is contained in the book. Here I will speak of the treatment of these wounds with the hand and with the aid of physicians according to their custom
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	Wounds are of various kinds according to the cause of the wound and the place where the wound has fallen
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Wounds are thus of various kinds, as when caused by a stone, or by a sword or knife, or by a blow with a spear or wood or arrow, or by like things
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds which are caused in different parts of the body are also of various kinds, as for example a wound which falls on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the stomach, or the limb: or like those on the joints
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I will speak of the treatment of other wounds, so as to give the reason and rule concerning the rest of the wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple head wounds: for the memory of the compound wounds will come at the beginning of the third chapter.
Dico ergo.	I say thus.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When a simple wound occurs in the head and there is no fracture of the bone: then consider whether it is from a stone or something similar. Then break only the skin: and the wound is great and the time for the inflammation of the surrounding area is great: then proceed with care and perform a cephalic phlebotomy immediately: do not delay this: and extract from him from the blood according to the quantity of his virtue. If there is anything which prohibits phlebotomy, especially if there is little blood flowing from the wound, do not do it
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the bloodletting be from the opposite side of the wounded part.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the patient beware of repletion (excess), of wine, and of coarse food
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If, however, something hinders the reduction (of the wound), then let the food be diminished, not increased, and let meat and wine be avoided
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And let there be placed upon the wound if it happens to have a thick scab, a cushion of infused alum on pure salt, or with wine in which there is styptic action.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If, however, you are secure from the thick scab, then let there be placed upon the wound, if there is a clot adhering to the blood, and has not altered its air, some powder which I will tell you of later: and if it has altered the air, then let there be placed upon it some unguent until it is healed
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If, however, the wound is large, or is from a wound made by a sword, and the like: and the edges do not adhere by little hairs, then let them be brought together with sutures, as I shall say concerning the sutures of these wounds
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If, however, the wound has been detected from a bone, and hangs loose, and its retention is not necessary except in a small suspension: then cut it off
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then care for the wound with physicians, and restore to it solid flesh in the place of the skin, and command the patient, that he eat coarse food, such as heads, and cooked barley, until the pulse be regular: and similar things.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find in the wound corruption, and it does not adhere to the bone: then cut away the corrupted part entirely, and cast it out: then care for the wound
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If, however, in these wounds there is an artery, or vein from which blood flows: and it is not severed by medicines, then inquire concerning the artery
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If then you find the wound not closed, you must dry it with Spatumili, or bind it up.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If necessity compels you when it does not conform to what we have said, then cauterize the wound until the blood is excised
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If the wound is small and simple, then the matter is easy and light: thus as to powder over it this powder: because it strengthens it before it changes from air
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of applying powdered gypsum.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Recipe: mix one part of olive oil, two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of unburnt lime: grind them all together, and make a paste: apply it to the wound, and bind it securely, until it adheres well to the wound itself and is clotted with blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then string the wound over with lint, and let it go, neither wash it until it has healed, so that it does not burst open
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For it is not driven out by medicine until it has healed.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And when it does make this calcification alone, when there is neither oil nor dragon's blood in it, it does the same operation in many great wounds when it happens that it is placed over them and bound, and when there are fresh wounds with their own blood, which have not altered from air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	When it has altered the air somewhat by any alteration, especially when it is in summer, then the intention of this powdered gypsum is not there: care for it as we have said, thus as to place over it some digestive unguent: or place over it balls of barley flour made with water and honey, until pus comes out of it
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the rest of the cure until it heals
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If indeed it happens that there is a fracture of a bone and it is small, then extract it with a grasper: and I will tell you the treatment of head fractures in this which the future is.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Of head fractures.
Caput LXXXV.	Head fractures.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If indeed it happens that there is a fracture of a bone and it is small, then extract it with a grasper: and I will tell you the treatment of head fractures in this which the future is.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	If indeed it happens that there is a fracture of a bone and it is small, then extract it with a grasper: and I will tell you the treatment of head fractures in this which the future is. If however the nerve of the head is cut, or an artery: then if it is a nerve, it is not in vain that it is fractured, except that it must be treated with something which brings about hemostasis, such as sponges and eggs, and things of that kind.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	For indeed the nerves are unknown, and against them there is no remedy.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not put anything cold on the wound at all: for the substance of the nerves is cold, and its continuity is with the brain, which is the soul of the limbs: and let this be how it is cured by physicians gently, such as lime with honey or with rose oil and pitch, when it is washed even with sweet water: and the rest of the mineral stones, according to this method, and oily unguents.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	If indeed the fracture is large, then administer a suture: or close its lips with wool.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If indeed the wound is deep, or has happened in a sinus in its lower part, in which pus is gathered, then perforate it in a depressed place in that place
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If indeed a blood vessel has been cut, and its blood flow has followed: then separate it, or dry it up, and bind it: or cauterize it, if that is necessary for this.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If, however, the teeth have penetrated the guttur, either completely or partially, and the gums are swollen: then aggregate the lips of the skin with a suture above the canine tooth of the guttur, and do not touch the guttur itself, but rather equalize it with the surrounding area, and reduce it to its natural position.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then tighten it with a proper suture, and discharge it in a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents in which there is stickiness and exudation, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If, however, a nail has made an imprint in the bone, then inquire about it: then if there are fragments of bone in the same, extract them all, or whatever can be extracted from it: and what cannot be prepared, discharge it, since the nail will putrefy and separate and the discharge will be alleviated.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	And if the nail has been embedded, then grind over it with the powder which I mentioned before.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If, however, it is seen in the nail, and a fistula has formed: then care for it as is fitting for its situation in its chapter.</start_of_turn>
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	Of the nail in the palate.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter 86.</start_of_turn>
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is percussion of a lance or a knife, and you see its depth, then consider it.</start_of_turn
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If, therefore, from the nail there escapes blood, when he breathes out from it the sick person, then you know that the nail is mortal.</start_of_turn
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If, however, it does not have great depth, and is embedded with blood: then do not immediately grind over it, or suture it, so that the blood does not remain in its depth, and return to the heart, and kill the patient: but put in it a nourishing unguent, and leave it for two days.</start_of_turn
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If indeed an unguentum is not present, then place in the opening of the wound a seasoned cushion, that it may absorb what proceeds from it from the humilities: and cause the patient to sleep upon the wound, that it may mend what accumulates in it.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If indeed three days or more have passed since the wound, and no spasm or bad tremor of the heart, nor bad breath, nor stricture in the bowels, and the patient's other conditions are good: then you know that the wound is healed.</start_of_turn>
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Care for it diligently and with treatments, and with other cares, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If indeed the healing is excused, and it always opens, then you know that a fistula has been made.</start_of_turn>
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Care for it from its chapter.</start_of_turn
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a cut of a sword or knife, and is simple on the surface of the breast or back: then care for it with that which precedes from the suture, if it is large: or with dust, if it is small.</start_of_turn
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if indeed it has made an impression in the bone, and has broken from it: then inquire about the wound, and properly extract that which is separated.</start_of_turn
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	But if indeed they are not separated, then leave them alone, until the wound putrefies, alleviating the extraction of them.</start_of_turn
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	As for the rest of the accidents of wounds in the rest of the limbs, the judgment in their care is their own.</start_of_turn
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Of wounds of the belly, and the exit of the intestine, and the issue of them.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXXVII.	Head Chapter LXXXVII.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The disruption which happens from inside is great, middle, or small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	It is great when the intestine or the number of intestines comes out from the great one
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore there is an introversion of the bowels, and the suture is more difficult and arduous
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And the small disruption is also difficult in another way
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore, it follows that the reduction is more difficult if you do not properly perform the introversion back to its place immediately: because it swells, opens, and swells up: and thus the entrance of it becomes difficult.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore, the middle disruption is better: because with this one the reduction of the intestine is not difficult, as it is with the two other kinds
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	You know that the suture of the belly is according to four methods.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two sutures are common in the suture of the belly, and in the suture of the remaining wounds of the body: and two other sutures are proper for the rest of the wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However, there are other methods which are more proper for the suture of the belly: and I will narrate one of them with its exposition and declaration
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say, because when the wound is small, and something from the intestine comes out of it, and it is difficult to reduce it: then it is for one of the two methods.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the disruption, as we said: or because of the inflation of the intestine due to the cold of the air
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When it is like this, then one must warm it up, so that you may immerse a sponge or a wet towel in warm water
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil them in water a little bit, and cypress, and fennel, and embroil with them the intestines, until the swelling is resolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	When it makes that liquid in which there is stickiness: it is better than plain water in resolving the swelling.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When you have thus resolved the swelling, then moisten the intestines with the water in which they have been boiled, either high or low.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For thus it alleviates its entrance with a small thing.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	If, however, its return is delayed after this treatment, then find in slight disruption, with the instrument with which hemorrhoids are cut.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first treatment is better when it is prepared than the section: and does not cause a pressing need to cut after necessity and the fault of the instrument.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part be sharp and acute, and the other part not acute: and the extremity should not be fine like that of Spatumilis, but rather obtuse like a bean: and this is what resembles a wound, like the liquid
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When the wound is thus strengthened, and the intestine is introduced, then it should be brought about that there is a reduction of it according to its natural form in its own place, if possible over that: because that is better
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When indeed the disruption is wide in the lower part of the belly: then it should be made to lie flat on its back, and place its knees higher than its head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the belly, then place its head, and its chest higher than its lower parts
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And similarly if there is a disruption in two parts of the belly, then place your intention and your consideration always in this, that the part in which the wound is should be higher than the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	It is thus necessary that the surgeons perform this work in large wounds and in medium wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	In small wounds, however, place this [dressing] according to what is prepared for you
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make it so that your hands rest comfortably between your fingers, which hold the entirety of the hand together: and gather its lips together.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then draw out from it [the wound] whatever follows the suture one thing after another: and this is the manner of common suture of one
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is necessary that you take an awl, or the number of awls according to the quantity of the wound's breadth.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then withdraw from the edge of the disruption the quantity of the finger of the hand, namely the physician: and fix the awl one beyond which you enter into the skin in two extremities of the skin, with two extremities of fat which is under the skin from the inside, until you make it penetrate from another side, and you gather together two extremities of the skin and two extremities of fat: and there are four orders thus formed
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then bind with a double thread around the circumference of the awl several times from two parts together, until two lips of the wound are gathered together by a decent aggregation.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then withdraw the length of the finger also, and fix in the flesh another awl: afterwards tighten the skin with the thread, as you did with the first awl.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Do not cease to do this until you have completed the constriction of the whole wound
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And the middle awls between the length and the thickness: because the fine awls slip easily through flesh: and the thick ones are difficult to enter the skin: for this reason it is necessary that they be of middle thickness in the skin, and thick
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	It is not permissible that a needle should remain in two contiguous parts of the skin for a long time: for the flesh will otherwise quickly decay and a wound will open before consolidation has taken place, and will not be lengthened even when sutured, for it will be prevented from consolidating by the suture.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then pierce the extremity of the needle, so that it does not wound the patient during sleep: and place wool pads around the needle from all sides, which will hold the needle in place: and draw it out, until you know that the wound has consolidated
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this is the kind of suture which is most suitable for small wounds
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For indeed one, or two, or several needles suffice in a suture.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second common suture is that in which four extremities are bound together: two of the skin and two of the fat in one wound, with the needle through which the thread is passed being equal in thickness and consistency.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced with the needle the four extremities, reduce the needle from the part from which you began, so that the thread be drawn out from the upper part of the wound: so that the suture be like the stitching of cloth. Place between every suture as much thickness as the breadth of a little finger
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	This kind of suture they know already.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And when I did this suture to him, the wound which had happened to him in his belly, which had been wounded with a knife, and was a disruption of the greater part of the intestine for two palms: and it had escaped from the intestines about two palms from the middle intestine, and there was a disruption in the middle of the belly
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	I reduced it therefore after it had rested outside the wound for twenty-four hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The swelling has subsided in the space where it remained for about fifteen days; I have treated it, and it has healed: and since then it has not returned, having become accustomed to its own condition.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	The physicians declared that it would not recover.</start_of_turn>
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And indeed, a miracle occurred, for I did not treat it with unguent.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where unguent was not to be found, neither did I have any from the physicians.</start_of_turn
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	I placed upon the swelling a warm compress twice a day, and I bathed it with scented water until it healed.</start_of_turn>
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	I used two kinds of sutures according to the narration of the sermon.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is that you begin with the acute suture: and you insert the point from the exterior to the interior part.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When the needle has penetrated the skin, and has reached the abscess according to the length and breadth of the whole body: withdraw the point of the needle in the side in which you inserted the point, and make penetrate from the inside outwards at the opposite end.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When you have thus made the penetration, then make the penetration once more in the same place outwards from the outside, and withdraw the point which is in this side, and make the needle penetrate from the inside outwards in the opposite end: and withdraw the point which is in this side, and make the needle penetrate again from the inside outwards in the opposite end, until it has penetrated the whole abscess.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	And then begin also from this side, and tie it with the point which is outside, and withdraw the needle from the skin where it penetrated.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then reduce the skin to that area, and its outer limit to the side which is opposite to that which has the mark: and draw out the skin from that part which is on the side of it, and make it one with this, and the other: and make this one after the other, until its outer limit is like that example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the sum of all these sutures is like the sutures of the leatherworkers which join skins: so that you make one from one side of the skin-edge: and you let go of the other from the other side, until you have completed it.</start_of_turn>
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of suture which Gale has spoken of.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This is the way in which he has spoken, that you must join all parts according to their similarity, as do some physicians, so that you join the outer limit of the skin to the outer limit which is opposite to it, and the outer limit which has the mark to the outer limit which is opposite to it.</start_of_turn>
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is done according to what I have told you.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary that the ligature be made in the outer limit which has the mark, close to the outside, and that you make the skin penetrate inwards only in that place: and you let go of the two skin-edges.</start_of_turn
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then draw up the ligature, and make the skin penetrate from the outside inwards through the two skin-edges, namely on both sides.</start_of_turn
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then draw up both of them, and also make them penetrate both from the inside outwards through the two outer limits, to the two other outer limits which are on the opposite side.</start_of_turn
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this way of suturing is better than the common way, and is the suture whose progress is remembered.</start_of_turn
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is indeed the word of Galen.
Et dixerunt quidam.	Some have said this before Galen.</start_of_turn>
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The gut suture is corrected with two squares.</start_of_turn>
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is, insert in the belly two threads: and begin with the insertion of the needle from where it is to you, and make it penetrate until it reaches the opposite side, following the suture that is between the layers of skin.</start_of_turn
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	You know that when the middle of the gut is ruptured: then the suture of that is more difficult than that of the rest of the gut.</start_of_turn
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment of the healing of an ulcer is the judgment of the healing of the rest of the ulcers.</start_of_turn
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is, because when you follow an ulcer with its own blood, before it changes itself: and you reduce the intestine, and hold it, and put over it the powder of incense.</start_of_turn
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	If the air has changed the ulcer: then put over it some unguents that are in your presence, until they make pus: and the thread breaks, and consolidates the mucus, and heals.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it in the same way as the healing of the rest of the ulcers, until it heals.</start_of_turn
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if there are no remedies available, then put over it immediately, from which it begins to emit pus, a soft tumor: and change it twice a day, as I have taught you, until it heals.</start_of_turn
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you must not apply other remedies to many conditions, when the ulcers are simple.</start_of_turn
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If, however, you are afraid that the ulcer communicates with the principal parts of the body in its lesion, then you must immerse fine wool in lukewarm oil, or in rose oil: and put it around the parts between the groin and the armpits.</start_of_turn
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or swelling, or putrefaction in his intestines (for this often happens to him), then let him drink a cluster of wine with black vinegar and warm water: especially if the putrefaction has already penetrated the intestine, and an opening has been made through it until it reaches its cavity.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that that which is excised from the great intestine is easier to heal: and that which is excised from the small intestine is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	The small intestine, however, which is called Ieiunum, does not suffer healing from the wound which occurs in it throughout: and this is because of the multitude of its veins, and the greatness of their number, and because of the subtleness of its body, and because of the proximity of its nature to the nerves
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If, however, that which proceeds from the wound is a bone, and you see it, do you not remove it? Reduce it according to your reduction which you make of the intestines equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If, however, it has passed beyond that space, and is black or dark: then it is necessary to ligate it with a thread above the place which is rent in it, so that there may not be a flow of blood.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in a bone there are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut that which is beyond that ligament, and put two hanging threads from the lower part of the wound outside of it: so as to support above its traction, and extraction of it from the case of the bone, and emission of the pus of the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remember the wound which occurs in the Intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When a disruption occurs in the Intestine, and it is small: then it is possible, in certain persons, that it will be restored: because I saw one who was wounded in the belly by a lance, and the wound was on the right side of the stomach, and was old: and there was made a fistula, and it went out of itself through an egestion, and there was a swelling.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I leave it until the cure is complete, until I am not compelled by his condition: neither do I cease to work until he is healed and his place is firm.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	Until his place is consolidated, I refrain from working on the patient, for fear of causing him further harm: neither do I leave him until that harm has ceased to exist.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And I remain in better conditions, eating and drinking, trusting in God, and having bathed, exercising in my diet.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some physicians say that when there is a wound in the intestine, even if it is small: then it is necessary to suture it in this way
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is like taking large ants.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then join together two lips of the wound, and place an ant between them over the two lips of the wound
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When you have put it over them, and closed its mouth, cut off its head, and bind its tail to it, and do not break it off
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one, and do not stop doing this until you have done as much as the size of the wound requires
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce it, and suture the wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	These heads remain joined to the intestine until the intestine is healed, and is not subject to any sharp or rough document
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And it is possible to suture the intestine even with a fine thread: which has been taken from the intestine of an animal, and is joined to it after it has been introduced into the knot
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And take hold of the end of this thread from the intestine, and remove a great deal of it
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then the thread in its extremity is passed through a fine loop of linen.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then pass the thread into the knot, and afterwards with it the intestine
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce it to disruption
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of stitching with hooks and intestine is not without risk, except according to the degree of trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	You know, a wound that is large, broad, especially if it is in a graceful intestine: then there is no skill except meticulous handling, and its healing is not at all guaranteed
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	Regarding care of ulcers and fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 88.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	You know that every wound, or abscess when it grows old and decays, becomes an ulcer, and does not consolidate, and emits pus always, and does not heal: then it is called a fistula in every member in which it occurs.</start_of_turn>
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula is indeed a filtered node, hard, white: with which there is no pain, which has the shape of a wing of a bird: and for this reason they call some of them Risati, that is, wings.</start_of_turn
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And sometimes in wet weather it emits pus.</start_of_turn>
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And sometimes the humidity breaks in some hours.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And when this humidity is great and little, and is large and thin.</start_of_turn
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I say in general that any wound that does not heal, neither is born in this body, is not due to anything other than one of these causes.</start_of_turn
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	When one of these things is absent, either because of the scarcity of blood in the body, or because of its malice, or because between it and the lips there is a hard substance which hinders the natural growth of flesh, or because of the presence of many ulcers and pus, or because an ulcer in itself is putrid, and the matter which issues from it is of bad quality, or because the medicine is inappropriate for its treatment, or because there is corruption descending in the region which is a kind of pestilence, or by a peculiarity in the region, like that which occurs in Caesaraugusta, in which there is difficult digestion of food and a delay in its healing after a wound, by nature itself: or because in that place there is but one bone, or a number of bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have mentioned all these causes and signs of them, and their treatments with physicians. It is necessary for you to write here the treatment of fistula and stone, which is done by one operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	You know therefore that fistula can occur in all parts of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	There are fistulas which extend to great veins and arteries, or nerves, or the bladder, or the intestines, or the belly, or to some bones: or to some part of the backbone, or to some joint composed of several bones, such as the hand and foot. And there are those which arise from nearby parts of the great limb and are similar to these
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Therefore, the fistulas of this kind are caused by difficult healings and do not receive treatment, and are associated with labor and ignorance
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	If however there is any fistula which does not extend to these places which I have mentioned, and if you hope and trust in its treatment, and wish to reach an understanding of it, then attempt to close it by air or by iron, since the fistula follows the straight line. Ask for help with it.</start_of_turn>
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If, however, in the fistula there is a twist, then investigate it with a fine lead weight.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Since lead with its softness conforms to the body, and curves around the twist
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	When there are many holes in the fistula, it is not possible to indicate the upper part with a hook
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	It is necessary therefore to explore from the holes towards the holes.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the moisture which fills the fistula, comes out through other holes, and runs from the holes.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then inquire diligently in what way it is possible: whether it is bone or nerve, and whether the fistula is of great or little depth: or whether the fistula is one which has many holes, and lies above all that with the sum of your strength: with your questioning of the patient and the finding of pain on compression with your hand at the place, and similar signs and symptoms following.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have stood on all these stations truly, then go on to the treatment with confidence: and it is that you consider at that time if the fistula is close to the surface or far from the junction, or from a nerve, an artery, a vein, or a place which I have mentioned: then dry the fistula according to what has been said before from my narration, and remove what is in it from the filtration, and corrupt flesh, which is born in its orifice from the flesh, or pus, and like things: and care for it until it is healed
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If, however, the fistula is of great depth and is according to the rule: then it is necessary to dissect it as deep as possible.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then remove from it all the corrupt flesh from it.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer the ligature which is involved in acute medicine: and introduce it until it reaches the extent of the fistula which you have grasped with the iron: do this with the utmost care, until the acute medicine has eaten away the whole of what remains in the fistula from corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore the limb with the unguents which produce healthy flesh, until it is healed
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If indeed it does not heal by this, then cauterize it as we have said before.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If indeed the cause of the fistula is bone, and you are certain of that: then inquire about it, and dry it as I have told you: if it does not prevent you from doing anything from the hip joint downwards, or from the elbow downwards, as we have said
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If indeed it is detected that the bone is corrupted and black: then burn it out until the corruption of it is completely removed
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which nourishes it, until it is healed
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	Which if it does not heal, and emits pus like this: then you know that you have not reached the whole eradication of the corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Observe it carefully further on, and make a reason for it, and bring it to perfection with your utmost skill and care
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If indeed it heals, that is good: and if not, then you know that the corruption is profound and distant in the body, which you have not been able to overcome
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	It is not in your power in this matter, except to yield to the nature of things.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If indeed the small bone is corrupted, and it is possible for you: draw it out with fine forceps which are suitable for that.</start_of_turn>
