Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then make exquisite attraction of them all, and do not emit anything from the body with your fortitude.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If, however, it makes an emission from the humors, and there is no fear of that in the incision, or an error: then incides those humors and tissues, if there are any, and frees the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If, however, you are not prepared to remove the bones from your hour, then place over it that which putrefies itself: and emit it, until it putrefies what is around the bones from the flesh and humors
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the limb so that it does not solidify.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And the section should be closed as you closed it in your operation
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	And put over it, if necessary, a bandage soaked in sulfur grated with oil: or a bandage soaked in Egyptian unguent or any other unguents.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when they putrefy, these humors, and separate from the bones, the wound will be soothed by their separation and their attraction.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If, however, there is a single large bone, such as the femur or the tibia, and the like of these, and that which is corrupted from it, is great: then break it off with the utmost care, until that black and corruption is removed
Deinde restaura uulnus.	And then restore the limb.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If, however, that which is corrupted in it is great, and the corruption has gone through to the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to cut it off and open it up to the place where the corruption remains: then care for it until it solidifies
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you what happened to me in my leg: that you may take it as an example and an assistant for your operation
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	A youth of about thirty years of age suffered pain in his leg, because something had moved above the middle of his body inwards, that is, from within, until it reached the leg, and there was a large swelling: and there was no external cause for it.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	It has been extended for a long time with an error of the doctors, until the swelling was opened, and many materials came out with it.</start_of_turn>
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after that the cure was delayed, until the leg was bandaged, and many holes were made in it: which all emitted pus and moistened the body.</start_of_turn>
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	They treated him for a long time with many doctors, for two years at least, but there was no skill in their art, until I saw him and washed his leg and the things which were coming out of his holes were of great size: even all the men of the place fainted, and his colour was pale.</start_of_turn>
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	They attempted to reach one of the holes in his body, and they reached the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the holes: and I found that they were all communicating with each other from all parts of the leg.</start_of_turn
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I treated him accordingly, and I closed up one of the holes, until I found a piece of bone: and I found that it was corrupted: for it was rotten, putrefied, and perforated, until it had penetrated as far as the marrow.</start_of_turn
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I saw that what had been detected was prepared from the rotten bone.</start_of_turn
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I concluded that there was no soundness in the bone except for that corruption, which I cut off and cauterized.</start_of_turn
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I cured him of it.</start_of_turn>
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I place restoration of the wound with the physicians consolidated in a spacious area.
Et non est consolidatum.	It is not consolidated yet.</start_of_turn>
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried again, and I found upon the second examination above the first detection: and I found continuous corruption with the bone: and I saw that what appeared to me from that corruption also appeared from the corruption itself.</start_of_turn>
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I attempt to restore it.</start_of_turn
Et non est restauratum.	It is not restored.</start_of_turn
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I found it therefore upon the third time above all, and I did not cease to cut the bone piecemeal, and to try to restore it: and it is not restored, until I cut through the bone round about the palm of the hand, and I extracted that with its marrow.</start_of_turn
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the physicians, and it was consolidated quickly, and healed: and no further operation was necessary for this purpose, except for the disposition of the infirmity of the patient, and his little tolerance, and my fear of death for him, because it was threatening him in every hour from the excessive evacuation of his bowels.</start_of_turn
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He is thus healed whole: and was born in the place of the hard bone, and a good disposition was made in his body, and his strength returned to him: and he returned to his usual activities: and did not suffer from any difficulty in walking ever after.</start_of_turn
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the prominent bone in the body is fractured: then it is necessary to support it thus: take hold of the ligament, and bind it at the extremity of the prominent bone: and command someone to extend it upwards: and place another ligament from a thicker thread than the first.</start_of_turn
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the ligament over the flesh which is over the bone: and extend its extremity, so that you pull the flesh downwards: and you will see the flesh over the place where you wish to cut, so that it does not wound the flesh.</start_of_turn
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the lower bone in the middle: for when you do this, it does not prevent the knife from cutting through decayed flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	The incision should be made above the corrupted area, not in its concavity, so that it does not cause further corruption of the bone: and it must not appear to the patient in its own sense, and must urge him towards its own healing process or another incision
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is corrupted and does not protrude, the part which is corrupted must be continued with the part itself: and the corruption is in the middle of it, or in part of it: then remove the flesh from all sides
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood under the lower bone.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	And then cut through from the first part where the corruption is, until the incision is continued from the other side: and let the incision be at a distance from the corruption as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is at the junction, cut through the corrupted junction and cut the bone where the incision is continued on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed the corruption is in the continuation of two junctions, then it is not within it except by abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the palm of the hand, or in the sole of the foot: then things are difficult there
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary that you inquire about the nature of the corruption.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape the wound, and wash it according to whatever way you are able, and with whatever ingenuity you can: when it does not cause you to go against the vein or the nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And you know that the saws and knives for cutting bone are many, according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their size, and their shape, and the degree of their sharpness, and their rarity
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Wherever it is necessary, one must prepare an instrument suitable for each kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	You know that these operations are very significant for their kind, requiring a specific instrument for each of them when one has a great deal of experience.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And you must know the modes of this art, the testimony of the modes of sickness: for then you will find for each of them what is suitable from instruments for all illnesses.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	I am firm in the last of this chapter concerning the number of instruments, which I shall demonstrate by examples of those which you mention, and the proof which you will experience from others.
Forma Serrae.	The Shape of the Scalpel.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The Shape of the other Scalpel
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Shape of the other Scalpel again
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Shape of the other Scalpel once more
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of the Scalpel is made with the blade slightly offset from the center.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its arc be at the upper part, its keenness from the iron: and its handle from boxwood, and make it pyramid-shaped with the offset at the center
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The Shape of Scissors for Sutures
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of these Scissors be in the shape of the head of a star: and their points according to the shape of the needles of an embroidery needle
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not suffice unless, when they touch each other's heads, they break when they are forced together, or when the bone is large and broken
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The Shape of the Larger Scissors
Forma medii Rasorii.	The Shape of the Medium Scissors
Forma Rasorii lati.	The Shape of the Small Scissors
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Shape of the wound where the edges are joined together.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Shape of the wound where the edges are closely approximated.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Shape of the wound where the edges are bent outwards at the extremities
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Shape of the wound small and slight tension
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Shape of the wound where bones are fractured
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Shape also of the wound large
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a wound like a saw, and the edges are like a saw: it appears in many places because of the reason of the bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Shape of the wound which agrees with the reason for its perforation by bones
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its extremities are triangular, and the edges are acute
Fit ex Indi.	Like that of India
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And it is like that which must be made in respect of wounds and cuts and saw-like shapes.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Regarding the incision of the extremities, and the closure of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities become gangrenous, either by an external cause or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have treated the disease with medical remedies, and the disease does not yield to treatment: and you see that the disease has advanced to the cutting of the limb, which does not recover anything: then you must cut off that limb until the disease has ceased, so that the patient may be saved from the death or the bad consequence which results from the defect of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this must be done is when the limb is blackened, until it is consumed: for fire burns it, or it becomes gangrenous after blackening: until that gangrene is cut away throughout the body to that extent which follows the limb, and it spreads throughout the whole body
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Properly therefore with the incision, and similarly if the cause of corruption is percussion of some of the veins: as for example of the scorpionfish, and of spiders, and of bloodworms, and of things of a like nature.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore corruption exists, or percussion in the extremity of a finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave space for corruption, until it reaches the other hand
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the palm, then cut off the hand from the root of the bone, and do not leave space for corruption, until it reaches the elbow of the arm
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it occurs in the forearm, then cut off the arm at the elbow in its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If however the corruption has passed, and you see it around the elbow: then in that is the death of the patient.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to give something beyond this from the cure, is the amount of the antidote.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And do the same with the foot, when corruption occurs in the finger, then cut off the finger at one of the joints: and if it reaches the heel of the foot, then cut off the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	And if it reaches the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	What if the corruption has gone above the knee? Then it is not in that there is life, except for dismissal, and leaving the patient to death
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And as to the cutting off of a limb, or preserving it, it is like this, that you string the lower ligament which you wish to cut off: and string the other ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And stretch out one ligament downwards: and stretch out the other ligament upwards
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you cut away the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with a spatula of a broad kind, until the whole flesh is detached
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it happens, or it returns.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	Then it happens, or it returns. It is necessary to support the entire circumference of the wound with linen, and not to touch the healthy tissue: and it is added to the patient's pain, and the swelling is calmed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, blood flows inwards during the operation, then cauterize the place quickly: or place above it some powder which absorbs blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medicine until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with the appropriate bandage, and care for it, until it heals
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened to me in my foot, for this is what I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because in his foot there was a blackness, with a scorching which assimilates with the burning of fire: and this corruption first happened in his finger, until the whole foot was affected
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	He did this, however, when he saw the corruption increasing in the limb with its suffering, because of the pain and the scorching: and he cut off the corruption at the junction, and it healed
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And when some time had passed, the same corruption happened to him in the nail of his middle finger of his hand
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I attempted to restore the superfluousness with what I found on the hand from the physicians after the purification of his body: and the superfluousness was not recovered, and it began to advance into another finger: until the corruption reached the hand
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to amputate his hand: and I did not do it, hoping for the recovery of the superfluousness: and I was also afraid of making an incision in his hand which might cause his death
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Since the man was very strong on the case.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	When he had recovered from me, he returned to his home: and he came to me again because he had been hurt, and he had broken his whole hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I do not approve of this narration, except that it is of use in this case: and that it has a signification which is to be known, and according to how it is done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	About the care of bones, and the quality of blistering with physicians.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When a swelling occurs in some limb by a fracture, and the space of the swelling is prolonged until the collection of pus has been made: then it is broken open, or pierced, and the pus which is in it is ejected, and that which remains is like a wound: and the skin which is over it is like a membrane which has been thinned out: and it does not reach its ultimate corruption, neither does it reach the bone, nor the nerve, nor the ligament: it is called a Sinus, and is not called a Fistula, except when the space of the swelling is prolonged until it causes corruption in some part of the limb, then it is called a Fistula, or swelling
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its care is that you cut off the whole skin as it returns: and especially when it is thinned out, and is made like a membrane: and trust that it does not adhere to the place, because of its corruption
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you hope that the skin will adhere, and that this will not be the last consequence of the corruption: and if there is thickness in the skin from the flesh, then care for it with blistering: and consider it as a Sinus
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is great, and the pus which comes out of it is foetid of odor: then blister it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, and oil, and alum, equal parts, mixed together: and apply them over a fire, until the medicine boils: and then bring in the fat of bees
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from this what you need: dissolve it with water and honey, and administer it with vinegar: and bind up its orifice, and give the medicine for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression: do this for several days until the sinus becomes softened, and the stench is gone.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is administered with water of cinnamon, when it is not present in this medicine: then take cinnamon of wood or of the ilex tree: and sprinkle it over water.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then rest it, and administer it with vinegar, until you are confident that the sinus is softened.</start_of_turn>
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine, neither vinegar of cinnamon, then administer it with water and honey, to which something of ground mastic has been added.</start_of_turn
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or administer it with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey to soften and loosen, and the wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in the wine.</start_of_turn
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this several times, and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has passed away: then administer it with that which makes the flesh grow in it.</start_of_turn
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is good to take from pounded gypsum: and dissolve it with rose water and wine of vinegar: or administer it with some medicine, and anoint with others, whose properties are written in the treatise on unguents.</start_of_turn
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the orifice of the sinus is narrow, in which the canula of the syringe will not pass: then widen it with a small piece of iron: or put in the cavity a piece of lint soaked in Egyptian unguent, or in balsamic ointment, until it is widened.</start_of_turn
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	Likewise, if the opening is large, then gather its lips together with sutures: and discharge from it the amount that enters without adding anything.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	If pus flows from the opening, elevate it upwards: then dry it in the lower part which is in the same place, so that it flows downwards: for pus, when it is contained in depth, hinders the generation of flesh in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible to dry the cavity downwards, then attempt to prepare the limb by facilitating the flow of pus outwards with the preparation which is to be made.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Attempt to retain nothing of the pus in it: and take consolidating medicines which are placed over the sign, suitable for this purpose.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over the edge of the wound
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the size of the wound be such as to allow communication of the entire cavity.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with scissors directly at the opening of the cavity, widening the opening of the cavity slightly.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then stretch out from soft bands over the wound, according to the size of the opening: and place it over it in a distant position from the opening of the cavity, so as to facilitate the discharge of pus from it: and do not tighten the dressing too much, except after a few days or until one has healed
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is over the opening of the cavity should move in every hour, so that it may be discharged from what is aggregated in it from the pus: and you know that what comes out of it is much, or little, or digested, or undigested
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you have done this again, consider the place of the cavity itself, whether it feels pain in it, or whether there is no pain in it, or whether there is swelling in it, or whether there is no swelling in it
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When the remedy has been rendered as aforesaid, and you see that the material issuing from the sinus opening has ceased, then you know that the sinus is adhered or is approaching adhesion: then you must remove it either on the first day or on the third day. And when you have removed the abscess, then you must change the dressing and renew the unguentum.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	When, however, the material issues from the sinus for a long space with a fine discharge, you must not despair of adhesion, for its healing approaches, because there are people who are slow to generate flesh in their wounds, and others who act contrariwise to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	When, however, the material issues from the sinus after many days in undigested pus, then you know that the sinus is not adhered
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	When, however, the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its condition is prolonged: then physicians must join in the excision of remedies, for they make the remedies both humidy and dry: like the unguentum of aloe, which, when added in excess, has a superabundance of addition of alum.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last of all, when it is cured, it is necessary to take the unguentum of aloe and dissolve it with rose water, and apply it over the old wound equal in quantity to the substance itself
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then apply it with this, and use it on it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it does the same thing to this, when it is not present with the unguentum of aloe, honey, when you dissolve it, until it is digested, and use it with this.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloe, and olibanum: all of them together, and grind them up on honey while it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then apply on it a layer of the dressing, and bind it over the sinus: and line with the honey which you have boiled until it is digested: and sprinkle over it the powdered species, and put on the dressing again, and bind it over it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	When it is administered in that noble ointment, long aristolochia, lily roots of heaven, and lily flower, and barley herb, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	When it is administered with those simple substances, either singly or together, and the unguents themselves: and powdered cinnamon over honey as I have mentioned before, and use that.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If, however, the condition of the sinus persists and does not recover with this treatment: then you know that there is corruption in its depths: or that it makes an imprint in the bones, or in the other hard parts, or ligaments: then treat the fistula according to what has been said before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Concerning the treatment of fistula and nail fracture, and the addition of incision of the finger and section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter XC.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritis is a swelling that arises under the nail of the thumb or finger, or perhaps in the other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When it persists, and neglect of its treatment makes it swell, or when the swelling becomes inflamed, pus is emitted, until the root of the nail is corroded: and perhaps the whole nail is broken, and perhaps the corruption extends to the bone, whereupon there is a foul odor: and the finger becomes swollen, and its color becomes dark
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you treat it with what we have said before, and the cure does not take effect: then it is necessary to cut off the entire superfluous part that remains of the nail with a knife
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	The cautery must be hot.</start_of_turn>
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If indeed the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the soft parts of the nail are pressing against the meat inwards, and begin to pierce it: then it is necessary to place a thin radium under the angle of the nail that is piercing the meat, and push the nail upwards: and cut the meat easily, and place over it what remains of the meat from the burnings, corrosive, until it is all removed
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If, however, corruption has set in the bone, then it is necessary to cut off the bone and extract it: for it will not heal while corruption remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corrosion and corruption spreading in a finger, then cut it at one joint, as has been previously mentioned concerning its reminder
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, there should occur attrition or percussion of the nail, and there is pain in this: then it is necessary to bleed the diseased part in the first instance.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatula from above downwards to the end.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard, that the cutting does not reach the flesh which is under the nail, for thereby you will cause increased pain and swelling of the flesh itself.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with that which sits there which alleviates the pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	A finger which has been added which is born in the hands of men, is perhaps all flesh: and perhaps in some of them there are bones, and perhaps in that there is a nail: and some of them are born from the root of the joint, or is the nature of it in some joint of the finger
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	He who is born in some joint of the finger does not move: and he who is born near the articulation of the finger, perhaps moves
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	He who is made of flesh is easily cut
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, as you would cut it at the root with a broad spatula
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	As for that one whose nature is in the root of the joint, the care for it is difficult
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
Caput XCII.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then string the limb of the sickly person from the upper part of his hip down to the lower part of his knee with an outturn.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry one place, or two, or three wide sections
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then elevate, that is, draw out blood from the lower part of the leg up to above, and from above bring down as bloodletting for the sick person at first
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the wound downwards: until blood has drained out as much as the amount you wish, and as much as the sickness can tolerate
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind it: and command him to abstain from foods that generate black bile: and repeat the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full, and it is useful for the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of it is like this.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	The limb of the sickly person, if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse it in a bath: or bandage it in his leg with warm water, until it turns red, and swell the veins: or perform an exercise forcibly, if there is no bath for him, until the limb is warmed up
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin in the direct line of the vein section: or at the last of it near the knee, or in the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with needles, and scrape the vein from every side, until it appears sensible: and it is at the appearance of it that the blood turns from red to black decreases.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it has gone out of the skin, the blood is like white thread
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then put under it radium, until when it is raised and comes out of the skin: suspend the blood with a cautery, soft
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry the other section near that one by three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrub the skin from the upper part of the nail downwards until it appears clean.</start_of_turn>
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise the limb like you did with the radix, and suspend it with another finger as you did at first.</start_of_turn>
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry the other section, or the sections more, if you wish.</start_of_turn
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then raise it up, and cut the last section at the heel.</start_of_turn
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then withdraw the limb up to the section which is above the limb.</start_of_turn
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	Do this until you have withdrawn the limb from the upper section, or from the higher sections altogether. Then cut the limb.</start_of_turn
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If, however, it does not obey you to withdraw and elevate: then introduce the needle with a strong thread twice, and bind the limb, and withdraw it: or introduce it under that radix: and twist your hand towards all parts until it comes out.</start_of_turn
Et caue, ne incidatur.	Take heed, lest you cut through.</start_of_turn>
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if you cut through, it becomes difficult to elevate the limb afterwards, and it enters through that wound.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have therefore withdrawn the limb entirely: then place upon the wound a soaked bandage of wool or linen dipped in wine and rose oil, or oil: and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted, having a twist which has a loop towards the parts, and is not as we said according to the rule: then you must find upon the limb towards all parts the loop of the twist itself.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend the thread with the hooks until the vessel has healed completely: and take care at the section above the vessel that you do not cut through it, or damage it: for it is difficult to raise or extract the vessel afterwards.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore be prudent.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The nature of the wound that will restore life to the vessel.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The shape of the closed wound
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not like the rest of wounds, neither acute at the edges, as to cut through it: but rather gross and flexible, for if it were slight, it would tear the vessel by its own softness: indeed, it should be somewhat thick.</start_of_turn>
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the leg vein.</start_of_turn>
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCIII.</start_of_turn>
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the calves in warm regions, like Alizegi, and in Arabia, and in dry and warm regions, few in number, for in them no herb or tree grows.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is also generated in other parts of the body besides the calves.</start_of_turn
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from the putrefaction which happens under the skin, like that which occurs within serpents and worms, and worms which are generated between the skin and the flesh.</start_of_turn
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the commencement of this event is inflammation in the calf.</start_of_turn
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place is to be dried.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein is to be extracted from the place of drying, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When the swelling appears from that extremity, then it is necessary that you cover over the leaden weight, whose weight is from a drachma to two drachmas and a nodus, and let go of the suspended lead from the limb.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	When the swelling appears from that extremity outwards, cover it in lead and tie a knot in it.</start_of_turn>
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it prolongs for a long time, then cut away part of it, and cover the remainder.</start_of_turn>
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	Do not cut through the root before the whole thing has gone out.</start_of_turn
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut through it, it contracts, and enters the flesh: and causes swelling to happen, and putrefaction in the place, and a bad ulcer.</start_of_turn>
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to draw out slowly and gradually, until it comes out entirely from its root: and nothing of it remains in the body: for in this way it goes out through the vein in some people which is as long as five palms and ten fingers.</start_of_turn>
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And I have seen it where it has come out whole from twenty palms.</start_of_turn>
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If, however, it occurs to you at the hour of your treatment: then introduce radium into the cavity of its bone, and perforate the bone with a hole as long as the body, until the whole of that which is in it is evacuated: and administer the treatment of the place with medicines for a few days.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of the aftercare of the wound.</start_of_turn
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein often has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and there are many outlets from every orifice, and they all go out.</start_of_turn
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Care for it herself, as we said before, and with what has been promised.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised.
Caput XCIIII.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	Care for it itself, as we said before, and with what has been promised
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	It is necessary that the patient be cleansed and purified with lukewarm water, with physicians extracting harmful humors from the body.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And take care that he be guarded against foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	About the cutting over an abscess Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This ailment is called in our land Nakir: and it is a pain which occurs in some limb: then it changes from limb to limb
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have seen it happen, as I have told you
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a woman who was sick in some house.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I saw her arm and I found swelling in the armpit of the arm
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed I saw another swelling rise up like a worm, going up to the shoulder of her more quickly than is possible: like silver that is running from one place to another
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain therefore departed from that place and was fixed in the shoulder
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then after an hour it ran through the rest of the body, until it reached the other arm
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	And she told me that it returned throughout her whole body, as I saw
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I am amazed at the speed of its change from limb to limb
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself had never seen such an ailment before like this, in this way
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	But I have heard of many people who suffer from this pain which changes from limb to limb: and I have never seen it with my own eyes like I saw it in this woman
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not think that is the case, except insofar as a woman has been among those from whom the stones have been detected in the belly: from this therefore it appears that the sense of smell has been transposed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that they do not appear according to this ratio in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, and in whom the veins are hidden
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore you see that the patient feels pain in that place, and that the wound appears to him: then if it is seen by the eye, as we have said, then grasp above and below that which is quicker: and dry above that, until the enclosed moisture is driven out: and cauterize the place.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If however you do not see it with your eyes: then care for it with the exclusion of the body, and with that which expels the moisture, and carmine it with unguents like fennel seeds and rue seeds, and the like.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	(The text continues with instructions on extracting stones from the body.)</start_of_turn>
Caput XCVI.	(The book ends at this point.)</start_of_turn>
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Stones are diverse according to their species and according to the place from which they are expelled from the body.</start_of_turn>
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their diversity is such: for some of them have large teeth and few: others are concave and others are convex.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are those which have three angles.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And those which have tongues.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And those which are star-shaped.</start_of_turn
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those which are expelled from the limbs are according to two modes.</start_of_turn
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	All members of the body are composed of primary members which are hollow, such as the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidneys, intestines, bladder, and similar structures.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When any part of these members falls into any other part of the body, and signs of death appear, then it is necessary to remove that arrow from there, for death follows the wound in whatever position it is, in many circumstances
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when no such signs of illness appear, and the arrow is not deeply embedded, then extract it, and care for the wound
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	From the signs of the brain when it is struck by an arrow, and the bone is pierced, and blood comes out from above the brain, it is because the following things happen from that: vomiting, convulsions, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasm, and confusion of the mind, and cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out of the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is stammered, and the voice is destroyed
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there comes out from the wound a white moisture like putty
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there comes out from it like the moisture of meat
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If any of these signs appear, then abstain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not come out on its own.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow which has fallen into the heart are: that it is close to the left breast: and that it feels as though it is fixed in something hard, not in something soft.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow is moving like the pulse: and blood runs out of the wound black.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And following that, there is cold at the extremity, cold sweat, and faintness.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You know therefore that death approaches with uncertain delay.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow when it wounds the lung, is the outflow of bloody foam from the wound: and the after-effects which follow the wound, subside, and change the colour of the patient.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And great, high-flying spirit departs: and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into the chest, which is in the belly: then it is near the flanks: and there is great sighing with pain, with breath coming in short gasps, and all the limbs of the arms are moved
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps it comes out of the wound from undigested food
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the belly, and remains there: something of stool comes out of the wound, or urine, or intestine which has been broken
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope in its cure, neither in the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the bladder, and urine comes out: and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain over the patient is stronger: then you know that it is deadly
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, like the face, neck, chest, belly, and buttocks, and the fingers, and wrist, and elbow, and shoulder, and hip, and thigh, and leg, and similar parts of the limbs move according to various positions: when it does not find the arrow in the artery or nerve: and there is no venomous arrow
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I have seen many such arrows, so that you may know about the cure for your case.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	What is this, since the arrow of care has pierced the pupil of his eye in the root of his nose?
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore I extracted it from the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and no mark remained in his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from his eye, which had pierced him in the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was hidden, and I did not extract from it the point of the arrow which adhered to his wood: and it was a great arrow like those which the Turks make with lead in them, which have no ears
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	He was healed therefore, and no bad thing happened to his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the gut of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab arrow, which is the kind that has ears
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	And I found it between two ribs: and it was submerged in his gut
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I took great care of it until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from his head which had pierced him in his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	When thirty days had passed by and no change appeared in his condition concerning the arrow, we thought that he would not recover; and we took thought for the arrow and extracted it: and he was healed, and no bad thing happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man whose arrow had pierced his back, and his wound was consolidated with a bandage on his wound
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	And after seven years he went out of the arrow from the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And the woman whose arrow had penetrated her body, and whose wound had been consolidated by a foreign body above it, and the arrow remained inside her: and no change occurred in its position from its original arrangement, and the woman did not suffer any discomfort from any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And the man whose arrow had pierced his face, and whose wound had been consolidated, and remained in its place: and he experienced no great pain; similar to these many cases.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted the arrow from the King's nose, which had pierced him in the middle of his nose, and it had inclined towards the right side below: and the arrow was entirely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called to treat him after the arrow wound for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found that the wound of the arrow was very strict and wide
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I questioned him cautiously and he did not feel any pain: and even I could not find the puncture mark or any pain on his right side
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that the puncture was at the extremity of the arrow
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I plastered the place with a soft and adhesive plaster, confident that the wound would heal and the mark of the arrow would disappear; and indeed no other sign of the arrow remained in that place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I continued to plaster it over several days: and no accident occurred, and the wound consolidated meanwhile: and he felt the arrow inside his nose on the following day
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I placed over it a sharp and corrosive medicine which I renewed every few days until it opened: and when I cautiously removed it, I found the tip of the arrow still adhering to the wood
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then did I add in the opening of the wound for the acute physician until it became evident to us the extremity of the arrow: and it passed over with it the space of time which is approximately four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	When the wound had been enlarged, and it was possible for me to introduce instruments into it, and to sew it up, and it did not yield to extraction: then I did not cease to elaborate, and I devised above it with the skill of the engineers, until I had completed above it on a certain day with forceps which I had made with my own hands, according to what would result in the shape of the head in the end of the chapter, until I had extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians say that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it therefore, and the wound was consolidated and healed with perfect health: and nothing whatever was noticed of it
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of the extraction of some arrows: as you may learn from this and from what I have not said
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For indeed the parts of this art and the distinctions of these matters are not comprehended by narration: neither is it comprehended by this book, nor by a prudent craftsman who compares few things with many: and with that which is present, with that which is absent: and he finds a new operation and a new instrument among the descent of all these matters when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrows do not go out of the parts in which they are fixed, except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Except by attraction from the place from which it entered
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by turning back the other part
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered, or the arrow proceeding in the flesh: it is attracted and comes out
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not yield to the outlet at the hour when it falls: then it is necessary that you discharge it for a few days, until the corruption of the flesh surrounding it has taken place: and thereby you will allay its attraction and its egressio.
