Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	If it hangs in bone, and does not yield to you at the outlet, then you must also discharge it for a few days: and do it again every day with its attraction and motion, until it comes out entirely
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not yield to you after days, then you must perform an incision all around the arrow in the very bone with fine silk, until the arrow is fully loosened
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw out the arrow and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in the head of the bone, and has penetrated one of the cavities of the brain, and appears from the diseased part some of those signs which I mentioned: then abstain from the attraction of the arrow and discharge it, until it be equal to its original state after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow persists in the marrow, the putrefaction is not prolonged for it.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except in the body of the bone, and does not penetrate as far as the marrow: and remains diseased for a few days, and no sign of these accidents appears: then think of the attraction of the arrow and its extraction
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If however it is fixed loosely, and does not yield to you in the attraction: then manage the surrounding area of the arrow as I have said: then care for the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If however the arrow has vanished from its place in the body, and is hidden and concealed from sense: then inquire about it with care
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw out the arrow with some instruments that are suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you are unable to perform the procedure above due to the constriction of the wound or because of the length of the arrow in depth: and there is neither bone nor nerve nor fat there: then find above the wound until the wound is enlarged and the arrow can be extracted.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If there are any ligaments which hold the flesh fixed in the bone, then release the flesh from every side by all means, by any skill you are able, and the ingenuity which you can bring to bear, if you are unable to perform the evacuation of the flesh by fracture of the bone and rotation of the ear, until it becomes loose
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you perform the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then use the twist of your hand with the forceps to all parts, until you make the wound discharge: and with the last slight tension, so that the arrow does not break, and that it is difficult for you to draw it, and for its own extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you are unable to perform it from one hour, then let it rest for a few days, until the things around it have decayed
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then do it again: for it is in vain that you do it if it causes the flow of blood. Then administer what we have said from the treatment in its chapter: and guard your virtue from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer all your skill in every way that you can in order to perform the extraction of the arrow: and let this be with ease, and tranquility, or slowly, and firmly, as I have told you
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	It is necessary that you do as you pull out the arrow, that the patient be in the same position as when the arrow was in him.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because of the great pain.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible for you to do this, then administer what is possible from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	If it proceeds from the opposite side, or if anything proceeds from that towards the exterior: or it makes the extremity of the arrow bulge outwards by means of a sensation from the part of the skin which is close above, and it causes the juice to rise: dry therefore above that, and make a section according to the quantity which they take in that.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw out the arrow: for itself makes the evacuation easy.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If however it remains in the bone, then turn your hand according to the roundness, until you press the arrow into the bone, and expand it for itself: then draw it out
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for a few days: then do it again, until it comes out naturally.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow-shaft is in that, then push it out with that (the hand).
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If however the shaft has broken, and you wish to administer an impulse: then introduce an instrument with a concave surface into the cavity, so that the concavity of the instrument may touch the caudal part of the arrow: then push out the arrow with that.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then push out the arrow with an instrument entering into itself.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow will go out by itself.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisonous, then it is necessary to cut away the entire piece of flesh in which the poison is, if this is possible
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for the arrow as it deserves which is suitable for it
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow has fallen into the chest, or the belly, or the back, or the side: and it is close to that which you touch with your hand, and it is possible to cut above that: then cut above that, and burn away from the incision of the vein, or nerve, and draw out the arrow.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then, if necessary, take a pulse, and care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	This is the form of forceps from which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The extremities are like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not recoil
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	There are many kinds of forceps, large, small, medium, according to the quantity of the arrow, the thinness and breadth of the wound, and the constriction of the wound
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape of the hooked handle
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	The shape of the blunt handle
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the shape of the extremities like a radius, so that the entrance of it into the hooked arrow is alleviated, and is driven with it
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The handle of this forceps is concave like the pen of a bird: so that the entrance of the arrow into itself and the driving of it is alleviated
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On the phlebotomy of veins
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 127.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins which are usually phlebotomized in the body are thirty in number
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these, in the head there are sixty: two pulse veins, which are behind the ears, are called Herbae; two arteries which appear in two temporal regions; two veins which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes; a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which is at the tip of the nose
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guide veins which are in the neck
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	For the veins which are phlebotomized in the arms, there are five veins in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic, and it is from the side of the shoulder: and it names the great vein of the head
Et Fusca.	And the Fusca
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Middle vein, and it is composed of the branch of the Basilic vein, and the branch of the Cephalic vein: and it names the great vein of the body
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic, and it is placed on the domestic side: and it is also called the Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it names the great vein of the abdomen
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Brachial vein, and it is placed above the elbow: and it is that in which phlebotomy is done, and that which appears above the thumb with a visible swelling.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Palateal: and it is the vein which is between the ankle and the heel: and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curvature of the thumb from the side of the shoulder.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphenous: and its place is alongside the calcaneus from the domestic side
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the Great Saphenous: and its place is alongside the calcaneus from the shoulder side
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And on the other leg there are three veins like these
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	After the Aures, perform a phlebotomy of two veins.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	After the Aures, perform a phlebotomy of two veins which are post Aures, for treatment of ancient cataracts, and migraine, and sapafi, and old head ulcer.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	The quality of the phlebotomy is according to what is narrated.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is that the head of the patient should be relaxed: and one should press the area of the two veins with a rough cloth with good friction
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then let the patient tighten his neck with his hands, until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are post Aures in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Seek therefore easily with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there is the sign with the imprint.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the phlebotomy knife, which is called Incidens
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce it under the vein into the skin, until the phlebotomist reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and skin towards the upper parts, and cut the vein with the incision which is incidental
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision is the quantity of two joined fingers, or thereabouts: and let blood flow out as much as you wish
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind the patient with bands, and let go of the vein, until it is healed
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And thus it is at the beginning of this book that the incisions and the cauterization of the veins are mentioned.</start_of_turn>
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Paragraph not included in the requested translation.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	If, however, the arteries which are in two positions are bled, it is to an old headache: and the proximate swelling, and the constant vomiting: and the flow of sharp-pointed effusions towards the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	The quality of bleeding is easy according to what I have said to thee.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The patient must hold his head still for a long time until two veins appear to the sense of sight: and the pulse of them is to be shown under thy finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then, signs with encasement.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift the skin over the vein upwards with thy index finger, and make the incision below, and elevate the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut through it, like thou didst in two other veins: and cause the blood to flow according to the quantity which thou shalt need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the clotting of the patient, and place thy finger over the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place over it the cushion and the pillows, and bind it tightly above the constriction: and let it go, until it is healed
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And afterwards came the recollection of these things, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Of the bleeding of the front vein after the cephalic vein has been bled.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The bleeding of the front vein after the cephalic vein has been bled is useful for old facial ailments: and for a headache, and redness: and a wound.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	The quality of bleeding of this is, according to what I have said to thee
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The patient must hold his head still with his hand, until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Which has this shape
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent point which is at the head of the Fossorium over the opening, and pierce through it with the pin or with something else in the same way: and let the blood flow out according to the quantity you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then close the perforation of the patient, and tie it off, until it is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it is opened with a wide phlebotome.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	Indeed it does not suffice that the phlebotome be of acute extremity, like the other phlebotoms, but rather that it be of broad extremity
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And let the phlebotome be according to the passage of the bone: because the bone is close by: and perhaps in this the phlebotome will break when it is slight
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins in the two lacrimal bones.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The support of the two veins which are in the two lacrimal bones of the two eyes, is for the eye from scabies and redness: and for the swelling in the eye, and the pains of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these is, that it tighten the neck of the patient with wit
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the phlebotomy is easy: and you stand over his head
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the phlebotomy be according to the passage to a small length, with a small phlebotome, broad rather than narrow, because there is no flesh in the place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If indeed the phlebotome is slight of extremity, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let the blood flow out as much as is necessary for you
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	Place above the wound a compress, bind it once at night, and resolve it.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	The wound is to be dressed with a compress, bound once at night, and resolved.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	As for the veins of the nose, phlebotomy is useful for acute fever, excessive sweating, facial pain, such as migraine, and redness which occurs in the face: especially when it is longstanding.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	The quality of the phlebotomy is that it tightens the neck of the patient.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take the left hand of the patient and perform the phlebotomy with a slight curve, long: and hold it in the middle of the nose itself, between what distinguishes the nose following a straight line.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the vein does not appear to the sense there, and blood immediately flows out of it
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	It is necessary to take the last hand away from the phlebotomy at the same time: and make the blood flow away from you as you deem necessary
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Bind it once at night
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	The wound itself will soon recover
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the phlebotomy of the Guidegian veins.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	For the phlebotomy of the Guidegian veins is useful for constriction of the throat, the inception of leprosy, melancholy, itching and ulcers, and corrosive diseases, that is, herpetiform eruptions of the skin
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	The quality of these phlebotomies is that they tighten the neck of the patient both under and above with a ligature: and let the artist sit above the head of the patient, and the patient should sit on a seat
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then draw out the vein to the length of the phlebotomy wide enough
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract from the blood an amount suitable, or according to what you need for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise with another vein
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then suture the ligament and bind two veins with a middle clamp: so that the patient is not harmed
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And keep it quiet until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound will then heal.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of the phlebotomy of veins according to Algeberich
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Algeberich are phlebotomized because they cause vomiting at the root of the tongue, corruption of the gums: and sores of the lips, and wounds in the nose, and in the surrounding area
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these veins is that you make the patient sit before you: and bind his neck with a cloth.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then pull down his lip, and look at two veins: one is on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left side of the lip: and their indication is by the blackening of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because around them are small veins, black
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore make an incision on each of them as they happen to lie there
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If however there is doubt to you, and you do not know which of them is which: then you must resort to the greater incision of both of them, and their manifestation
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do the same with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and most frequently this runs in custom with them: and make an incision of two veins which are in the lower lip
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Of the phlebotomy of the vein under the tongue after the phlebotomy of the Cephalic veins
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The veins under the tongue are useful for phlebotomy: for it is the cephalic vein which is useful for the affections of the gut, and of the tongue, and of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	The quality of the phlebotomy which is useful is that the patient should sit between your hands facing the sun: and raise his tongue, and look under the tongue at one side a vein, and at the other side a vein: and the colour of both veins should incline towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Phlebotomy is therefore useful on both sides: and take care, do not put your last hand in phlebotomy.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under these are arteries, and perhaps there will be a flow of blood from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the elbow
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins which are phlebotomized in the elbow are such that phlebotomy is usual in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy of them is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pressing with the thumb alongside phlebotomy: or by lancing with oil to the point of blueness: or by cutting with a knife, and this is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is useful for cutting
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And there are wide and narrow species according to the width of the veins and the tension of them. The form of phlebotomy of the thumb is wide, like water
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening wide veins, full of blood, protruding, visible, large, and those which contain thick blood
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomy is of smaller width and greater fineness
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It is suitable for phlebotomy of slender veins which contain thin yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	It is suitable for phlebotomy of slender veins which contain thin yellow blood.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	However, those veins which are three in number which are called basilicae are suitable for phlebotomy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because they draw blood from the swellings which are under the jaw and the throat, from that which follows the chest, and the belly: and it is suitable for the phlebotomist as well as for the patient, as it is above the risk of that there is an artery there
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If, therefore, it goes wrong, and there is an error in the puncture of the phlebotomy, the artery will be injured, and there will be a flow of blood
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary not to do phlebotomy with the phlebotomist who is puncturing: but rather to do it dry like Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If it does not appear that the basilica is visible, then it is necessary to ask another one, or to ask for another branch of it: or to do the phlebotomy in another place, such as the forearm
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	It is visible itself, and should be done dry with the phlebotomist like Anesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to do phlebotomy of the same one, then it is necessary before the tightening of the arm, to touch the place, until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then sign over the place with the cautery, afterwards the arm, and dry the vein with a concave incision like the phlebotomist Anesil, as we have said
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And be careful not to touch the artery with the incision.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you go, when you tighten the ligature, the swelling in the place which you signed with the cautery, then that swelling is the swelling of the artery: you must therefore stop doing it
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If the blood spurts at the phlebotomy, like the urine of a child, and is thin and red: then you know that it is from an artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then do so promptly, and place your finger over the wide space, and then withdraw your finger.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If the blood is shed (for it is often shed excessively), then grasp the arm and let go of it: and let the patient be aware of its motion: and be over his fear.</start_of_turn>
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for a few days, until it has healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood does not shed, and you fear it: and there is no physician present at your moment, then cut the artery if you see it.</start_of_turn>
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities recoil, and the blood is shed.</start_of_turn
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of cork from the socket of the thumb, and find the place: grasp a middle third, and bind it over the place of the tight nail, with ligature and threads until another day.</start_of_turn
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood sheds, that is good.</start_of_turn
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then care for it as before, remembering the location of the broken blood vessels and the flow of blood: and the cutting of the blood in various positions is not difficult because of the smallness of the wound and the possibility of ligating from the arm.</start_of_turn
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of the phlebotomy of the thumb.</start_of_turn>
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The veins of the thumb, however, are of phlebotomy, because they carry blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because they are composed of the branches of the basilica and the cephalic vein, as we said.</start_of_turn
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is fitting for the phlebotomist to be above the fear of phlebotomy, for under it lies a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If, therefore, he adds too deeply in the puncture of the phlebotomy and finds the nerve, there results in this a stupor, and the healing becomes difficult, and perhaps does not heal completely.</start_of_turn>
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve is much frequented by sensation.</start_of_turn>
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If, however, it is hidden in some people, and is thin, and is not seen: then it is necessary that you should join phlebotomy with Alnesil, and divide the nerve with your skill.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	And if there is one between two nerves, then find the one along its length.</start_of_turn
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the nerve of the head.</start_of_turn>
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomies of the nerve of the head are useful, for it draws blood from the head and supplies it to the eyes.</start_of_turn
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this nerve to do so alone, if you will, with a needle like that of olive oil, or like that of myrtle: for it is safer for all the veins, for there is neither artery nor nerve under it.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	But indeed it is fitting for you to join with the phlebotomy the laceration of the head, and to inquire about a softer place: and it does not harm it, if it is not found at the first percussion, as it returns above with subsequent phlebotomies.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Perhaps indeed it is delayed in some people when it is not phlebotomized at the first percussion, but it does not harm them that.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of Phlebotomy, and precautions to be observed in its practice.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of Phlebotomy, and the accidents that arise from it, require consideration in their rectification.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, know that Phlebotomy is not to be employed except for the conservation of health, and for the preservation of life, and with caution against the hazards.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that it should be performed only on the three veins that are in the elbow, namely the Cephalica, and the Fusca, and the Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that it should be performed at the beginning of spring after fasting, in summer, and autumn, and in winter after a meal, when there are signs of fullness
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	It should be performed on the first or third day after three hours have passed
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy for ailments has no set time: but when it is convenient and necessary for this, in the night or day, and at every hour, and at every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it should not be performed on children until they are at least fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Neither should it be performed on a pregnant woman except from the fourth month until the seventh
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor on the elderly who have passed their sixties years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When anyone wishes to undergo Phlebotomy for whatever reason: it is necessary to loosen his bowels beforehand with a laxative, if there is much retained stool: so that they do not draw blood from the veins with the remnants of putrid feces adhering to the principal limbs
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Neither should it be performed on a feverish patient, that is, one with nausea: nor on a drunkard, or one suffering from intoxication until these symptoms have passed from the body
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy suffer from hydropisi.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then the phlebotomist deposits the needle.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore an opening is made from the vein of one, then that is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat the process with another vein nearby under that place or above it with a twist: if the place does not recover
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	When it has recovered, or if the patient vomits, then send him away on the first or second day: and do not tighten the ligamentum
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps for that reason the swelling will be withdrawn.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither should a poultice be introduced
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small or blood runs slowly: and take care that blood does not escape from the vein in too great quantity: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place according to the rule and add a little more to the operation
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	Do it with a twist, before the place has recovered: for in many people the place is already recovered at the time of the operation itself.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see that the swelling has already gone, then do not repeat over it altogether, for it does not excuse you from doing something else
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put something of the faeces of oil on it: because it will soothe the course of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than pure oil, and than the rest of the oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And do the same with the faeces of oil in all your phlebotomies, which you do on account of the running of the blood: and make them become like tyriaca alfarach and sagzenea, when you put one of them on the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood becomes finer and is resolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	When blood is thick, it becomes finer and is resolved
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary to do this after the blood has been let from the vein itself, with the addition of some of its complement, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If some blackness or redness remains in the place after a day or two, or if there is any swelling, do not be afraid of this: and if you are afraid, put over it some aloe or myrrh, or something from the juice of mint, that is, camphor or something like that.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And very often blood clots and swellings occur at the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand over the place, then if you feel softness under your compression, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, put over it something of what we have mentioned.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps the blood will flow from that artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster of it with something that has styptic properties, so that the place is closed
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	And then care for the rest with the remaining treatment until it is healed
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to draw out of every man from blood according to the quantity of his virtue
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the color of the blood over the blood itself.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then send it away until it turns red: and in the same way if you find it thick, then send it away until it becomes fine: and in the same way if it is sharp, then send away its sharpness until it is gone
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	He who is full, strong, and in need of blood should extract one unit, so as to enlarge the vein, and let the phlebotomist be wide: and in him who is bilious, let it be the opposite of him.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	He must extract in veins and the opening must be narrow: and it is better that the phlebotomy be transverse, not pointed
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	This is the safe method of phlebotomy, from the flow of blood, from nerves: and is more laudable and safer than phlebotomy through breadth and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it has happened to faint during phlebotomy, it is necessary that before phlebotomy he be given a spoonful of honeyed water or dry toast, if he is heated: and extract from him from the blood in three or four veins.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if the complexion is cold, then take before phlebotomy a spoonful of bread infused with honey, or in scented honey, or in scented syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	And if there is fainting during phlebotomy, and the cause of it is excessive bleeding: then it is necessary that he take in the pot a little meat broth and a mild aromatic syrup: and let it be flavored with fennel and mint, and let the patient lie down with these things: and let us do all that we have said in the chapter on fainting from evacuation
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But if he wants to evacuate his arm and solve his blood quickly: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is because of much evacuation, and whose temperament is bilious, to solve the blood gradually in the quantity of his temperament in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	He who wants to evacuate his arm and solve his blood quickly, and whose body is strong: let him do this after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs downwards: it must be done on the second or third day
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And what is the quality of phlebotomy, that it may introduce the patient's hand into warm water, until the wound is red, and the joint appears to swell outwards.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is bound over itself with a bandage of moderate constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then phlebotomy is performed in a transverse direction gradually, not laterally, neither in length: and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be as near to the wrist as possible
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the blood is prohibited from escaping, then repeat the hand into the warm water, and let the blood run in the water, until you achieve your purpose
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in the summer days, then you are excused from the repetition of the hand in the warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And above all, the course of the blood in the warm water is set in the winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this joint is more safe than all the others, because there is no pulsating vein or nerve under it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of the right hand is useful for the treatment of liver ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that you bind the wrist with a bandage, or your hand itself, after you have introduced the hand into the warm water, until the joint swells up and the sense of coldness appears.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then phlebotomy is performed by a transverse cut
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut the vein entirely, it will not cause it any harm in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And take care not to faint from the phlebotomy
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under this, the nerves of the fingers are stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then again, move the hand to the warm water, and let the blood flow out into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	If you do not move the hand into the warm water, the blood will coagulate in the mouth of the [vein], and will be prohibited from running.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have drawn out the quantity of blood necessary, then place upon the vein oil and salt: that it does not solidify too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	It is also necessary to do this with every tight limb.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The true cause of this phlebotomy is the spleen: and in the same way do it in this phlebotomy as in the second [phlebotomy] equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The veins of the phlebotomy are useful for ailments which are in the lower parts of the body, such as abdominal ailments, retention of menstrual blood, kidney disease, ulcers of the groin and ancient buttocks, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	The quality of this phlebotomy is that it allows the sick limb to be introduced into the warm water: and let there be done over it friction, until the veins burst: and ligate above the junction of the limb with ligatures
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	The veins are at the heel, appearing outside the thumb: and they are torn out from it in front of the foot from the ankle bone downwards
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The phlebotomy is therefore better to be done in a larger limb, or at the ankle in its collection: because this is better and safer
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you make the phlebotomy on the face of the foot, then take care of the nerves which are under it over the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And make the phlebotomy from the transverse position, like the surgeon who wishes: and let the phlebotomy be as Nesil
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If blood flow is prohibited, then repeat the foot in warm water: and hold back the flow of blood in the vessel until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the vein has slipped from the first incision, then repeat the incision above the former, for the place is safe, and not liable to cause harm, even if you chance to cause damage to nerves, as we have said
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And in like manner with the other foot's vein.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The veins of the sciatic nerve are situated at the heel on the outer side of the ankle bone as we have said
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	The cause of pain in the ankle is a blood clot
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	The quality of the incision is that it should be made with a soft sponge and should be rapid: and bind the limb from the ankle up to the heel with a fine long strip, so that nothing is visible except for that
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then the incision of the vessel is to be repeated according to whatever means is possible, or according to the passage of the vessel: and it is better to cut through the vessel by incision or by section
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The place of the vessel is safer, and it is usually hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear to the senses at all: then repeat the incision of some branch of the vessel which appears in the heel and is opposite the auricle: and cause the blood to flow out in the quantity that you desire
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the binding, and place over the site of the incision the skin, and bind the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	On wound treatment, and the quality of its material.
Caput XCVIII.	On wound treatment, and the quality of its material.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Wounds are made from bones, air, and pus.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And wound treatment is done in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	By scraping and bleeding extraction: or without scraping.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this kind of wound treatment that is without scraping is done in two ways
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or with heat
Aut est absque igne.	Or without heat
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And those wound treatments which are administered with scraping and bleeding extraction are fourteen in number throughout the body
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is the treatment of the Alnocrati wound, and it is the last of the head: and the Alkehel, and it is the middle of the neck: and the wound treatment of the Alhagdahim, and there are two layers of the neck from two parts together: and the wound treatment of the menti is under the mandible in the lower part of the mouth: and the wound treatment of the two spatulas: and the wound treatment of the Alachosos over the end of the tail: and the wound treatment of the two focilia, and there are two of the biceps: and the wound treatment of the two cubits: and the wound treatment of the two heels.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And wound treatment does not pull out blood from small veins scattered throughout the flesh, and because of this it does not cause a loss of blood, as is the case with phlebotomy
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither is it necessary to administer wound treatment with heat, or without heat in any ailment which comes from excessive swelling, until the whole body is evacuated
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	Which if necessity compels us to do for wound treatment on account of an ailment, or because of custom, we administer it at every hour in the beginning of the month, at the end of the month, and in the middle of the month, and at any other time as needed
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	What is this, since it is from men that when it multiplies in their blood, until it requires extraction from them by means of vomiting, it finds in their head its greatest weight and burden?
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from this is that it brings about swelling and redness in their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from this is that it brings about itching in their face, and forehead, and darkness, and blindness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from this is that it severs the seat of their vomiting.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from this is that their laughter multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from this is that it brings about the taste of blood in their mouth: either the tongue is swollen and expels blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from this is that their sleep multiplies
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from this is that they urinate in their sleep blood and redness, and blood clots, and wounds, which are like these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see any of these things, and it is in the third middle of the month: we command vomiting to be performed immediately, after two or three hours have passed
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The vomiting of the night is thus: because it itself brings about a weight in the head, and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	It is therefore necessary, that after vomiting of the whole body
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	These are like phlebotomies of the head
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not lawful to use these things in those who are cold in complexion, or in whom there is catarrus
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings about a great danger.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	Neither is it proper that these should be used in the case of old men, in whom cold fevers prevail in the head.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever is too assiduous above his limits will generate for himself an aversion.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And therefore it is necessary, that the surgeon should take hold of the wind, that he should place his hand with the windward side downwards, fearing lest an aversion should be generated thereby
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Wind or alcohol is the place of the incision of the veins of the groin and of the veins of the belly, and because of this it confers swelling, constriction of the breath, and loss of strength, and cough, and distension of the belly
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	It is necessary to urge the alcohol of the wind slightly downwards, for if it is placed downwards, it generates stiffness in the heart and the stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The wind or alcohol, when applied too vigorously, causes pain in the head, vomiting, headaches, perforation, and toothache: and it is the place of the incision of the veins of the belly.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary that the surgeon take hold of the wind, that he should not place his hand with the incision: that he may not cut the artery and cause the flow of blood to be obstructed.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The alcohol of the wind under the chin causes swelling in the mouth, corruption of the gums, and similar diseases which are in the mouth: and it is the place of the incision of the veins which are in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The alcohol of the wind causes spitting, which is from reflection and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The alcohol of the wind inside the two cavities of the cheeks causes the drawing out of the veins of the groin, of the veins of the belly, and of the veins of the head: for it attracts blood from all these small veins which are in the flesh: and it attracts these small veins from other large veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	It is necessary, therefore, that the surgeon take heed, not to advance too far in the incisions: for in such a place the flesh is stripped bare, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The winds of the intestines cause swelling over the ulcers of the rectum, and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	It is necessary, therefore, that the surgeon take heed, so that the incisions be large and open to the air: for in such a place the veins are liable to be broken by excessive suction.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The veins of the limbs grow thin from diminished circulation: for they draw blood from all over the body, and cause ancient pains in the buttocks, thighs, and calves: they cause menstruation, and bring about swelling, and pain: and are in the place of two saphenous veins, and the marrow bones.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Indeed, they weaken the body greatly, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The marrow bones are very near to the veins of the limbs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The position of the veins is such that you should apply the incision to the first wound and moderate the suction: and do not prolong the position of the incision, but place it easily and remove it easily, so that the humors may rise to their proper place: and do not desist from this process until the area is red and swollen, and the blood appears red: then indeed you may perform the incision, and slowly resume the suction.</start_of_turn>
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Consider also the position of the body.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who has little flesh and few hairs, it is necessary to make the incision once, not twice: so as not to tear the place.</start_of_turn>
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And advise the Wind-Surgeon, that he increase the scarification, and make it shallow: and temper the suction to facilitate, and speed, and the movement of the instrument.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is thickness in the blood, then it is necessary, that he make the incisions twice
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first incision he opens a small opening for the evacuation of blood, and washes it: and in the second incision he makes an exquisite extraction of the thick blood
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is dark green, then make a third incision: in order to obtain the utmost
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	Finally, when we wish to extract the blood slowly, or little by little, sufficeth us one incision.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	When we wish to extract a great quantity of blood, we make many incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick: then it is necessary, that he make a deep incision: and the equal endpoint of the incision is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What must be administered from the oils at the position of the Wind-Surgeon, and what is the cause of the wind-surgeon?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that which the skin is thick, hard, rough, and has close pores, it is necessary that you anoint the area of the Wind-Surgeon with open, soothing, dissolving oils: if it is in summer, such as almond oil, or oil of violets, or sweet fennel oil, or cucumber seed oil
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in winter, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or camomilla oil, or salve: and the like.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If there is excessive coldness, the oil must be amaranth oil, or balsam oil or white oil, or almond oil: and the like.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.
